ARTICLE II. - ADVERTISING MATERIAL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Litter, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-11. 

Sec. 6-31. - Posting advertising matter on public property. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to post or place any advertising matter on any public property in the town. 
(b)  Any person who posts any showbill, notice or advertisement upon a utility pole or other public property in the town shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor punishable as provided in section 1-15. The showbill, notice or advertisement shall be confiscated by the police department. 
(Code 1974, §§ 3-1, 3-3) 
Sec. 6-32. - Advertising on public property within limits of highway. 
    Any person who in any manner paints, prints, places, puts or affixes any advertisement upon or to any rock, stone, tree, fence, stump, pole, mile-board, milestone, danger sign, guide sign, guidepost, highway sign, historical marker, building, or other object lawfully within the limits of any highway or street shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor and shall be punished as provided in section 1-15. 
(Code 1974, § 27-49) 
Sec. 6-33. - Posting advertisement without consent of property owner. 
    Any person who posts any showbill, notice or advertisement upon the building, wall, fence or property of another person without first obtaining the consent of the owner of such property shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor punishable as provided in section 1-15. 
(Code 1974, § 3-2) 
Sec. 6-34. - Painting signs without consent of property owner. 
    Any person who brands, writes, marks or paints any signs, letters or characters upon the building, wall, fence or property of another person without first obtaining the consent of the owner of such property shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor punishable as provided in section 1-15. 
(Code 1974, § 3-4) 
Sec. 6-35. - Putting advertisements in vehicles or handing them to pedestrians. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to put any advertisements or advertising literature in any vehicle parked on the streets of the town or to distribute such material except to hand any advertisement or advertising literature to pedestrians on the streets or sidewalks of the town. 
(Code 1974, § 3-7) 
Cross reference- Traffic and vehicles, ch. 82. 
Secs. 6-36-6-65. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - LOUDSPEAKERS[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Noise, § 42-131 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 6-66. - When use prohibited. 
    No loudspeaker shall be used on the streets or public places of the town between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. 
(Code 1974, § 3-8) 
Secs. 6-67-6-85. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT FOR USE OF STREETS FOR ADVERTISING 

Sec. 6-86. - Required. 
    No person shall use the streets of the town for advertising, soliciting, canvassing or the like by means of a loudspeaker or amplifier, whether such loudspeaker or amplifier is mounted on a vehicle or not, unless he shall first have obtained a permit from the mayor. 
(Code 1974, § 3-9) 
Sec. 6-87. - Application. 
    Any person desiring a permit as required in section 6-86 shall make application to the mayor. Such application shall set out the program to be presented and the manner and means of presenting it and shall contain such other information as may be required by the mayor. 
(Code 1974, § 3-10) 
Sec. 6-88. - Issuance or denial. 
    An application filed as provided in section 6-87 shall be considered by the mayor. Upon such consideration, the permit applied for shall be issued unless the mayor shall be of the opinion that the manner, subject or language of the program in question will likely lead to a breach of the peace. 
(Code 1974, § 3-11) 
Chapter 10 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 26; drinking while operating a motor vehicle, § 50-386; profane swearing and intoxication in public, § 50-435; hunting with firearm while under influence of intoxicant or narcotic drug, § 50-696. 
State Law reference- Alcoholic beverage code, Code of Virginia, § 4.1-100 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 10-1. - Definitions. 
    Terms, wherever used or referred to in this chapter, shall have the same meanings as set forth in Code of Virginia, § 4.1-100 unless a different meaning clearly appears from the context. 
(Ord. of 7-1-93, § 17-51(14)) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 10-2. - Hours of sale. 
    Times for the sale of beer, wine, or whiskey shall be regulated by state statutes. 
(Code 1974, § 5-1) 
State Law reference- Hours of sale of beer and wine by local ordinance authorized, Code of Virginia, § 4.1-129. 
Sec. 10-3. - Drinking in public. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to take a drink of alcoholic beverages or to tender a drink thereof to another, whether accepted or not, at or in any public place. The violation of this subsection is punishable as a class 4 misdemeanor under section 1-15. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to any person drinking alcoholic beverages or offering a drink thereof to another in the dining room or other designated room, as defined in Code of Virginia, § 4.1-308, or in any other establishment duly licensed to sell at retail for consumption such alcoholic beverage if such alcoholic beverage drunk or offered was purchased in such establishment. 
(Code 1974, § 5-2) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 4.1-308. 
Secs. 10-4-10-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ANNUAL LICENSE TAXES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Taxation, ch. 78. 

Sec. 10-36. - Levied on alcoholic beverages. 
    Annual license taxes shall be assessed and collected by the officer assessing and collecting other municipal licenses from persons licensed by the state alcoholic beverage control board to manufacture, bottle or sell within this town in the following sum: 
(1)  Distiller's license ..... $500.00 
No such license tax shall be prorated or required for any person who shall manufacture not more than 5,000 gallons of alcohol or spirits, or both, during the license year. 
(2)  Winery license ..... 500.00 
(3)  Brewery license ..... 500.00 
(4)  Bottler's license ..... 150.00 
(5)  Wholesale beer merchant license ..... 75.00 
(6)  Wholesale wine merchant license ..... 50.00 
(7)  Retail on-premises wine and beer license ..... 37.50 
(8)  Retail on-premises beer license ..... 25.00 
(9)  Retail on-premises wine license ..... 30.00 
(10)  Retail off-premises wine and beer license ..... 37.50 
(11)  Retail off-premises beer license ..... 25.00 
(12)  Retail off-premises wine license ..... 30.00 
(13)  Combined wine and beer off-premises and on-premises license ..... 75.00 
(Ord. of 7-1-93, § 17-51(1)-(13)) 
State Law reference- Authority to require local license, Code of Virginia, § 4.1-205. 
Sec. 10-37. - Method of calculating taxes. 
(a)  In imposing local wholesale merchants' license taxes measured by purchases, local retail merchants' license taxes measured by sales, and local restaurant license taxes measured by sales, alcoholic beverages shall be included in the base for measuring such local license taxes the same as if the alcoholic beverages were nonalcoholic. 
(b)  No local alcoholic beverage license levied under this chapter shall be construed as exempting any licensee from any local merchants' or local restaurant license tax, but such local merchants' and local restaurant license taxes shall be in addition to the alcoholic beverage license taxes levied by this chapter. 
(Ord. of 7-1-93, § 17-51(16)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 4.1-233C. 
Sec. 10-38. - Stated amount of beer and wine purchases to be disregarded. 
(a)  In ascertaining the liability of a beer wholesaler to local merchants' license taxation under this chapter, and in computing the local wholesale merchants' license tax on such beer wholesaler, purchases of beer up to a stated amount shall be disregarded, which stated amount shall be the amount of beer purchases that would be necessary to produce a local wholesale merchants' license tax equal to the local wholesale beer license tax paid by such wholesaler. 
(b)  In ascertaining the liability of a wholesale wine licensee to local merchants' license taxation under this chapter, and in computing the local wholesale merchants' license tax on such wholesale wine licensee, purchases of wine up to a stated amount shall be disregarded, which stated amount shall be the amount of wine purchases that would be necessary to produce a local wholesale merchants' license tax equal to the local wholesale wine licensee license tax paid by such wholesale wine licensee. 
(Ord. of 7-1-93, § 17-51(16)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 4.1-233C. 
Sec. 10-39. - Levied on mixed beverages. 
(a)  Every person holding mixed beverage restaurant and caterers' licenses for establishments located within the town shall be taxed annually the following sums: 
(1)  Persons operating restaurants, including restaurants located on premises of and operated by hotels or motels: 
a.  For each restaurant with a seating capacity at tables for up to 100 persons ..... $200.00 
b.  For each restaurant with a seating capacity at tables for 101-150 persons ..... 350.00 
c.  For each restaurant with a seating capacity at tables for more than 150 persons ..... 500.00 
d.  For each caterer ..... 500.00 
(2)  For mixed beverage special events licenses, for each day of each event ..... 10.00 
(3)  A private nonprofit club operating a restaurant located on the premises of such club ..... 350.00 
(Ord. of 7-1-93, § 17-52(a)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 4.1-233A.5. 
Sec. 10-40. - State license required. 
    No license under this chapter shall be issued unless the holder of the license shall hold or shall secure simultaneously therewith the proper state license provided for in the Alcoholic Beverage Control Act, Code of Virginia, § 4.1-100 et seq. If any person shall hold any local license without at the same time holding the proper state license provided for by such act, the local license shall, during the period when the person does not hold the proper state license, confer no right, powers or privileges under the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. of 7-1-93, §§ 17-51(15), 17-52(b)) 
Sec. 10-41. - Mixed beverages included in base tax. 
    In imposing retail merchants' license taxes measured by gross receipts under any other section of this chapter, there shall be included mixed beverages in the base for measuring such license taxes. No mixed beverage license levied under this chapter shall be construed as exempting any licensee from any merchant's license tax, and such merchant's license tax shall be in addition to the mixed beverage taxes levied by this chapter. 
(Ord. of 7-1-93, § 17-52(c)) 
State Law reference- Local alcoholic beverage license taxes, Code of Virginia, § 4.1-233. 
Chapter 14 - AMUSEMENTS AND ENTERTAINMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 26. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 14-1-14-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CARNIVALS, CIRCUSES, SPEEDWAY AND SIMILAR ENTERTAINMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to levy tax on carnivals, etc., Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3728. 

Sec. 14-31. - Bond required; penalty. 
(a)  No carnival or other like exhibition or show shall exhibit within the town unless the person proposing to exhibit shall have given bond payable to the town, with security approved by the treasurer, in the sum of $1,000.00, with the condition that such person shall not exhibit or permit the exhibition of any obscene show in violation of the Code of Virginia, § 18.2-375, and shall not permit the maintenance or operation of any illegal game of chance on the exhibition grounds. The exemptions from registration, bonds and licenses in the Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3728, shall apply. Proof of the exhibition of any immoral or indecent show or of the open maintenance and operation of any illegal game of chance on the premises occupied by such carnival or other exhibition shall be prima facie evidence that the game of chance or indecent show was maintained and operated with the consent of the proprietor of the carnival or exhibition. This section shall not apply to carnivals or other like exhibitions showing for only one day within a period of 12 months. 
(b)  The proprietor of any carnival or other like exhibition who permits the exhibition of any obscene show or the maintenance or operation of any illegal game of chance on the premises occupied by the carnival within the town shall be deemed guilty of a class 4 misdemeanor and shall be subject to a fine as provided in section 1-15. The proprietor and the surety on his bond shall be liable under such bond for any fine imposed by this section. 
(Code 1974, § 17-57; Ord. of 7-1-93, § 17-53(b), (c)) 
State Law reference- Carnivals, circuses, speedways, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3728. 
Secs. 14-32-14-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - COIN-OPERATED MACHINES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Amusement machines, Code of Virginia, §§ 58.1-3720, 58.1-3721. 

Sec. 14-61. - License tax. 
    Any person selling, leasing, owning, renting or otherwise furnishing or providing a coin-operated machine or device operated on the coin-in-slot principle shall be deemed a retail merchant and shall pay an annual license tax, not prorated, as imposed on other retail merchants under section 78-108. This section shall not apply to pay telephones, stamp machines, machines vending sanitary napkins or coin-operated locks on toilets. 
(Ord. of 7-1-93, § 17-91) 
Cross reference- Taxation, ch. 78. 
Sec. 14-62. - License transferability; payment. 
    The licenses provided for in this article are not transferable and shall not be prorated. The total license tax assessed shall be paid in one sum at the time the license is issued. 
(Ord. of 7-1-93, § 17-92) 
Sec. 14-63. - Oath of applicant. 
    Before any license is issued under this article, the town treasurer shall require the applicant to state an oath that no element of chance enters into the operation of the machine for which a license is desired and that all information given on the application is true and correct. The applicant shall also provide the treasurer a list of the machines and their location. 
(Ord. of 7-1-93, § 17-93) 
Sec. 14-64. - Unlawful to keep unlicensed machines. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person other than one duly licensed as a coin machine operator to have on his premises or on any premises under his control, or to keep or place or permit to be placed or kept on such premises any machine or device for which a license is required by this article, unless such machine or device has been licensed and the proper license tax paid therefor. 
(Ord. of 7-1-93, § 17-94) 
Sec. 14-65. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be punished as provided in section 1-15. The coin machine or other device shall be forfeited to the town to be disposed of at public auction after having been advertised in the local newspaper, with the proceeds from the sale to be paid into the town treasury. 
(Ord. of 7-1-93, § 17-95) 
State Law reference- Amusement machines, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3720 et seq. 
Secs. 14-66-14-95. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - POOL ROOMS, BILLIARD PARLORS 

Sec. 14-96. - License required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to operate or cause to be operated within the town any pool hall or other business establishment primarily engaged in the playing of pool, billiards or other similar amusement except under the following conditions, regulations and restrictions: 
(1)  No such business shall be operated in the town without a license issued in accordance with the provisions of section 14-97. 
(2)  No license shall be issued to any person unless or until the council issues a certificate to the owner or proposed owner or operator of such business certifying that the applicant has not been convicted of a crime involving moral turpitude, certifying the applicant's fitness for operating such business, and approving the location of the business. 
(b)  Any person denied a certificate required for the issuance of a license may appeal the decision of the council to the circuit court. 
(Ord. of 7-1-93, § 17-64(1), (2), (5); Ord. of 5-12-03) 
Sec. 14-97. - Application for certificate. 
(a)  Application in the form of an affidavit under oath for the certificate required by section 14-96 shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The applicant's name and address. 
(2)  The name under which the applicant proposes to do business. 
(3)  The location in the town wherein the applicant proposes to operate. 
(4)  The number and type of equipment the applicant proposes to operate. 
(5)  A list of all convictions of the applicant by any court under the criminal laws of any state, setting forth in detail the date, type of convictions, and in which court so convicted. 
(b)  Applications required in this section shall be filed in duplicate with the town treasurer at least five days prior to a regular meeting of the council. The council shall, after proper investigation, grant or deny the certificate within two months after receiving the application. 
(Ord. of 7-1-93, § 17-64(3), (4)) 
Sec. 14-98. - When closing required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for the owner or the keeper of any place of business where billiard or pool tables or bagatelle tables are available for use by the public and is licensed under the alcoholic beverage control laws of the state, to keep his place of business open or to offer his billiard, pool or bagatelle tables for use between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 7:00 a.m., unless a permit for longer hours related to a nonrecurring special activity is obtained from the chief of police. During the period between 12:00 midnight and 7:00 a.m., every day, such places of such business shall be closed and kept closed. 
(b)  Hours of operation for a family poolroom are defined under section 14-103. 
(Code 1974, § 23-1; Ord. of 5-12-03) 
Sec. 14-99. - Minors playing in, loitering in. 
(a)  No minor under 16 years of age shall frequent, play in or loiter in any public pool room or billiard room operated in conjunction with any establishment licensed under the Alcoholic Beverage Control Act, Code of Virginia, § 4.1-100 et seq.; nor shall the proprietor of any public pool room or billiard room or his agent permit any minor under 16 years of age to frequent, play in or loiter in any such place in violation of this article. 
(b)  Any such minor or any such proprietor or agent violating the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a class 3 misdemeanor, punishable as provided in section 1-15. 
(Code 1974, § 23-2; Ord. of 5-12-03) 
State Law reference- Authority to prohibit minors in certain places, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-432. 
Sec. 14-100. - Visibility of interior. 
    It shall be unlawful for the view, from the nearest public street or from any entrance opening immediately on such street, of the interior of any place of business where billiard or pool tables or bagatelle tables are available for use by the public to be in any manner obstructed, whether by curtains, screens, stained glass or otherwise. During the period when such place of business is required to be closed, pursuant to section 14-98, there shall be kept and maintained in the room in which such business is conducted sufficient light to enable the entire interior thereof to be plainly seen from the street or entrance. When such interior is wholly visible only from the entrance or vestibule, it shall be so visible at a distance of not more than five feet from the street line; and it shall also be visible in part at least through a window outside for the entrance opening on or towards the street. 
(Code 1974, § 23-3) 
Sec. 14-101. - Access. 
    When access to any place of business where billiard or pool tables or bagatelle tables are available for use by the public is by means of an entrance or vestibule, there shall be no other entrance and there shall be free access thereto at all times; however, this requirement shall not be construed to prohibit such an establishment from being provided with an emergency exit. 
(Code 1974, § 23-4) 
Sec. 14-102. - Exceptions. 
    The provisions of sections 14-100 and 14-101 shall not be construed to apply to pool rooms and billiard rooms in hotels having 50 or more rooms. 
(Code 1974, § 23-5) 
Sec. 14-103. - Family poolroom. 
    Family poolrooms which allow the playing of pool or billiards shall be a licensed establishment under section 14-96 and meeting the following criteria: 
(1)  It is not licensed under the alcoholic beverage control laws of the state, and is not operated in conjunction with any other licensed dispenser of alcoholic beverages. 
(2)  Has no petitioned or closed off areas other than those for toilet facilities, office space, storerooms, kitchen or pantry areas, all playing areas, pool tables and billiard tables being visible from the public way or street. 
(3)  Has a window open to view from a public way or street, having a minimum of 100 square feet of glass area, which window shall not be permanently covered or otherwise obstructed. 
(4)  Contains only regulation size (minimum measurements: 41/2 feet × nine feet) pool or billiard tables, which shall not be of the coin operated type, and such center shall contain a minimum of three such tables. 
(5)  Has separate restroom facilities for both sexes. 
(6)  It shall be unlawful for the owner or the keeper of any place of business that is designated as a family poolroom to keep his business open between the hours of 12:00 a.m. and 7:00 a.m. on any day, unless a permit for longer hours related to a nonrecurring special activity is obtained from the chief of police. 
(7)  Has a permit from the chief of police which indicates that the above criteria have been met. 
(Ord. of 5-12-03) 
Secs. 14-104-14-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - PUBLIC SOCIAL HALLS 

Sec. 14-131. - Definitions. 
    [The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:] 
    Public social hall means any place open to the general public or by invited admission where music, dancing or other similar activity is permitted to which an admission fee is charged or for which compensation is received either directly or indirectly by cover charge, ticket sales, donations, membership fees or otherwise. 
    Responsible party means any individual or organization representative responsible for all activities related to an event at a public social hall to which an admission fee is charged or for which compensation is received either directly or indirectly by cover charge, ticket sales, donations, membership fees or otherwise. Where the event sponsor is an organization, an individual must register as the responsible party in addition to the organization. 
(Ord. No. 2016-1, § 1, 4-11-16) 
Sec. 14-132. - Public social hall permit required. 
(a)  No person or organization shall operate a public social hall unless such person or organization has obtained an approved public social hall operator permit from the chief of police. The permit shall be valid for one year from its date of issuance. 
(b)  A public social hall operator must comply with all laws, regulations, ordinances and other requirements and stipulations issued by federal, state and local authorities. 
(c)  Any person or organization operating a public social hall without a valid permit shall be guilty of a class 3 misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 2016-1, § 1, 4-11-16) 
Sec. 14-133. - Reporting. 
(a)  Public social hall operators must inform the chief of police of any event scheduled by a responsible party at least 21 days prior to the event. The information shall be reported in a manner prescribed by the chief of police. 
(b)  Failure to timely report any event scheduled by a responsible party shall result in suspension or revocation of the public social hall permit at the sole discretion of the chief of police. 
(Ord. No. 2016-1, § 1, 4-11-16) 
Sec. 14-134. - Hours of operation. 
    It shall be unlawful to operate a public social hall between the hours of 1:00 a.m. and 9:00 a.m. 
(Ord. No. 2016-1, § 1, 4-11-16) 
Sec. 14-135. - Responsible party event application, background check and permit required. 
(a)  A responsible party must submit a public social hall event application and a nonrefundable fee of $100.00 to the chief of police at least 14 days prior to the date on which an event is to be held. The nonrefundable fee shall be in lieu of a business license. The application shall be submitted on a form prescribed by the chief of police. 
(b)  After conducting a background check of the responsible party the application may be approved or denied at the discretion of the chief of police. The responsible party will be notified of approval or denial within seven days after delivery of the application to the chief of police. 
(c)  The responsible party must display the permit in a prominent location throughout the duration of the event. 
(d)  The responsible party must comply with all laws, regulations, ordinances and other requirements and stipulations issued by federal, state and local authorities, including occupancy limits of the location. 
(Ord. No. 2016-1, § 1, 4-11-16) 
Sec. 14-136. - Violation and termination. 
(a)  A responsible party operating a public social hall event without a valid permit shall be guilty of a class 3 misdemeanor. 
(b)  A public social hall event may be terminated at any time at the discretion of the chief of police in the interest of public safety. 
(Ord. No. 2016-1, § 1, 4-11-16) 
Sec. 14-137. - Exemptions. 
    Charitable, educational, civic and local government organizations and performing arts and movie venues shall be exempt from the responsible party provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2016-1, § 1, 4-11-16) 
Chapter 18 - ANIMALS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Unauthorized use of animal, § 50-108; failure of bailee to return animal, § 50-148; handling or using snakes so as to endanger human life or health, § 50-376; withholding information about animal biting human beings, § 50-378; leaving disabled or dead animal in road or allowing dead animal to remain unburied, § 50-385; fighting cocks or other animals, § 50-436; shooting pigeons or other birds or fowl for amusement and renting premises for such purposes, § 50-437; use of ponies or horses on or upon sidewalks, § 70-45; disposal of animal excrement, § 86-147. 
State Law reference- Animals generally, Code of Virginia, § 3.1-796.66; authority to prohibit cruelty to animals and animals running at large, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-870; rabies control, Code of Virginia, § 32.1-48.1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 18-1. - Allowing livestock to run at large. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to allow any livestock belonging to him or in his custody to run at large on or near any street in the town. 
(Code 1974, § 6-1) 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate animals running at large, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-870. 
Sec. 18-2. - Dogs, cats and other domestic pets and animals. 
(a)  Dogs, cats and other animals that are generally and reasonably considered domestic or household pets shall not be allowed to run at large outside the confines of the owner's property. 
(b)  No domestic pet shall be allowed to cause a nuisance in the form of noise, odor, waste or any other manner. The owner of every domestic pet shall be held responsible for all behavior of such pet, including behavior that results in property damage, personal injury, or death. Upon notification by a town official, a pet owner must immediately remove any animal causing a nuisance. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or have in the town any pet or animal that is dangerous or unruly. 
(d)  Domestic pet owners shall ensure that their pet carries identification at all times in the form of a microchip, tag, or other means to allow easy determination of the owners. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any owner or person in control of any animal to allow the animal to defecate on public property or the property of other persons without their consent or consent of the authorized agent having control of the premises. Immediate removal and sanitary disposal of the defecated matter shall not constitute a violation. The defecated matter shall be placed in a sealed container and disposed of in a proper waste receptacle. 
(f)  Upon receiving a complaint that an animal or animals are dangerous, destructive, unruly or causing a nuisance the animal control officer or law enforcement personnel shall: 
(1)  Upon the first complaint immediately issue verbal notification to the owner or custodian of the animal(s) to remedy the situation within 24 hours; 
(2)  Upon the second complaint issue a written warning to remedy the situation immediately; 
(3)  Upon the third complaint seize and impound the animal(s) in accordance with section 18-6. 
(g)  Individuals failing to comply with this section shall be charged with a class 3 misdemeanor punishable as provided in section 1-15. 
(Ord. of 11-9-09; Ord. No. 2011-4, 8-8-11) 
Editor's note- Ord. of Nov. 9, 2009, amended § 18-2 in its entirety as set out herein. The former § 18-2 pertained to keeping dangerous or unruly animals generally and derived from the Code of 1974, § 6-2) 
Sec. 18-3. - Keeping or raising certain animals. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or raise in the town certain animals generally not considered domestic or household pets, including, but not limited to, alpacas, chickens, cows, emus, goats, hogs, horses, pigs, ponies, sheep, or any other creature that may reasonably be considered a farm animal or livestock. 
    Further, it shall be unlawful for any person to keep or raise in the town exotic animals or animals that typically live in the wild, including, but not limited to, alligators, apes, bears, chimpanzees, foxes, lions, monkeys, raccoons, reptiles, snakes, squirrels, tigers, wolves or any other creature that is generally not considered a domestic pet. 
(Ord. of 11-9-09) 
Editor's note- Ord. of Nov. 9, 2009, amended § 18-3 in its entirety as set out herein. The former § 18-3 pertained to keeping or raising hogs or pigs and derived from the Code of 1974, § 6-3. 
Sec. 18-4. - Cruelty to animals; penalty. 
(a)  Any person who: 
(1)  Overrides, overdrives, overloads, tortures, ill-treats, abandons, willfully inflicts inhumane injury or pain not connected with bona fide scientific or medical experimentation, or cruelly or unnecessarily beats, maims, mutilates, or kills any animal, whether belonging to himself or another; 
(2)  Deprives any animal of necessary sustenance, food, drink or shelter; 
(3)  Willfully sets on foot, instigates, engages in, or in any way furthers any act of cruelty to any animal; 
(4)  Carries or causes to be carried in or upon any vehicle, vessel or otherwise any animal in a cruel, brutal or inhumane manner, so as to produce torture or unnecessary suffering; or 
(5)  Causes any of the above things, or being the owner of such animal permits such acts to be done by another; 
shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor, punishable as provided in section 1-15. Prosecution for violations of this subsection shall commence within five years after commission of the offense. Prosecutions of this subsection regarding agricultural animals, as defined in Code of Virginia, § 3.1-796.66, shall commence within one year after commission of the offense. 
(b)  Any person who abandons any dog, cat or other domesticated animal in any public place including the right-of-way of any public highway, road or street or on the property of another shall be guilty of a class 3 misdemeanor, punishable as provided in section 1-15. 
(c)  Nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit the dehorning of cattle. 
(d)  The word "animal" as used in this section shall be construed to include birds and fowl. 
(Code 1974, §§ 6-4, 20-114) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 3.1-796.122. 
Sec. 18-5. - Disposition of dead animals and fowl. 
(a)  Any person who knows of a death of any animal or fowl owned or kept by him, or is given notice thereof by any person, whether such animal or fowl be dead on the owner's premises or any other place, shall immediately cause the dead animal to be buried or cremated. If the person responsible shall fail, neglect or refuse to comply with the foregoing provisions of this section, any judge of a general district court, after notice to the owner if he can be ascertained, shall cause any such dead animal or fowl to be cremated or buried by the health officer or other person designated for the purpose. Such officer or other person shall be entitled to recover of the owner of every such animal so cremated or buried the actual cost of the cremation or burial, not to exceed $75.00, and of the owner of every such fowl so cremated or buried the actual cost of the cremation or burial, not to exceed $5.00, to be recovered in the same manner as officers' fees are recovered, free from all exemptions in favor of such owner. Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a class 4 misdemeanor, punishable as provided in section 1-15. 
(b)  Nothing in this section shall be deemed to require the burial or cremation of the whole or portions of any animal or fowl that is to be used for food or in any commercial manner. 
Cross reference- Leaving disabled or dead animal in road or allowing dead animal to remain unburied, § 50-385; solid waste, ch. 66. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-510. 
Sec. 18-6. - Authority to impound animals found within town limits. 
(a)  The animal control officer and law enforcement personnel are hereby authorized to seize and impound any animal suspected of: 
(1)  Suffering a direct or immediate threat to its life, safety or health which the owner or custodian has failed or refused to remedy; 
(2)  Being abandoned at large; 
(3)  Being cruelly treated; 
(4)  Being unlicensed; 
(5)  Being used for gaming or other illegal activity; 
(6)  Being a nuisance in violation of section 18-2; 
(7)  Being a destructive dog in violation of section 18-71; 
(8)  Being a dangerous dog or vicious dog in violation of section 18-72. 
(b)  Any animal seized pursuant to this section shall be impounded at a town designated animal shelter or animal management facility. The animal will be held and disposed of according to the rules, regulations and guideline of the shelter or facility. Any expense incurred in seizure or impoundment including, but not limited to, boarding, veterinary care, license, disposal and other fees shall be the responsibility of the owner or custodian of the animal and become a lien on the owner or custodian of the animal impounded. 
(Ord. No. 2011-4, 8-8-11) 
Secs. 18-7-18-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BIRD SANCTUARY[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Protection of homing pigeons, § 50-116. 

Sec. 18-36. - Generally. 
    The town, within its corporate limits, shall be a bird sanctuary for the protection of all birds protected by the Migratory Bird Treaty Act, adopted by the U.S. Congress, not including starlings or English sparrows. 
(Code 1974, § 6-6) 
Sec. 18-37. - Signs. 
    Signs stating that the town is a bird sanctuary may be erected in the town by any civic club. Such signs shall be of such type and erected at such public places as may be approved by the council. 
(Code 1974, § 6-7) 
Sec. 18-38. - Molesting birds. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to shoot missiles of any description from any bow, sling, bean shooter, air rifle, spring gun, or similar weapon at any of the birds for which a bird sanctuary is provided in section 18-36 or otherwise destroy such birds, their nests or eggs, unless the birds constitute a nuisance or health hazard, which destruction may be authorized by the council. 
(Code 1974, § 6-8) 
Secs. 18-39-18-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - DOGS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of town to regulate running at large of dogs, Code of Virginia, § 3.1-796.93; authority to control dangerous or vicious dogs, Code of Virginia, § 3.1-796.93:1; rabies control, Code of Virginia, §§ 3.1-796.97-3.1-796.100, 32.1-48.1. 

Sec. 18-71. - Destructive dogs. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to permit or allow any dog belonging to him or in his custody to go upon the premises of a person other than such owner or person so having the dog in custody and to commit acts of destruction, such as soiling, destroying or injuring lawns, gardens, vegetables, shrubbery, flowers or any other property of such person. Dogs committing such acts may be seized and impounded by law enforcement personnel. Owners of such dogs shall be charged with a class 3 misdemeanor punishable as provided in section 1-15 and required to pay all costs of impoundment. 
(Code 1974, § 6-9; Ord. No. 2011-4, 8-8-11) 
Sec. 18-72. - Dangerous, vicious dogs. 
(a)  As used in this section, "dangerous dogs" means a canine or canine crossbreed that has frightened, bitten, attacked or inflicted injury on a person or domestic animal, or killed an animal; and "vicious dog" means a canine or canine crossbreed that has: 
(1)  Killed a person; 
(2)  Inflicted serious injury to a person, including multiple bites, disfigurement, impairment of health, or impairment of a bodily function; or 
(3)  Continued to exhibit the behavior that resulted in a previous finding by a court that it is a dangerous dog, provided its owner has been given notice of that finding. 
(b)  Any animal warden who has reason to believe that a canine or canine crossbreed within his jurisdiction is a dangerous dog or vicious dog shall apply to the judge of the district court for the issuance of a summons requiring the owner or custodian, if known, to appear before a general district court at a specified time. The summons shall advise the owner of the nature of the proceeding and the matters at issue. The animal warden shall confine the animal until such time as evidence shall be heard and a verdict rendered. The court, through its contempt powers, may compel the owner, custodian or harborer of the animal to produce the animal. If after hearing the evidence the court finds that the animal is a dangerous dog, the court shall order the animal's owner to comply with the provisions of this section. If after hearing the evidence the court finds that the animal is a vicious dog, the court shall order the animal euthanized in accordance with the provisions of Code of Virginia, § 3.1-796.119. 
(c)  No canine or canine crossbreed shall be found to be a dangerous dog or vicious dog solely because it is a particular breed, nor shall the local governing body prohibit the ownership of a particular breed of canine or canine crossbreed. No animal shall be found to be a dangerous dog or vicious dog if the threat, injury or damage was sustained by a person who was committing, at the time, a crime upon the premises occupied by the animal's owner or custodian; committing, at the time, a willful trespass or other tort upon the premises occupied by the animal's owner or custodian; or provoking, tormenting or physically abusing the animal, or can be shown to have repeatedly provoked, tormented, abused or assaulted the animal at other times. No police dog engaged in the performance of its duties as such at the time of the acts complained of shall be found to be a dangerous dog or a vicious dog. No animal which, at the time of the acts complained of, was responding to pain or injury, or was protecting itself, its kennel, its offspring, or its owner or owner's property, shall be found to be a dangerous dog or a vicious dog. 
(d)  The owner of any animal found by a court to be a dangerous dog shall, within ten days of such finding, obtain a dangerous dog registration certificate from the animal warden for a fee, the amount of which is on file in the town clerk's office, in addition to other fees that may be authorized by law. The animal warden shall also provide the owner with a uniformly designed tag identifying the animal as a dangerous dog. The owner shall affix the tag to the animal's collar and ensure that the animal wears the collar and tag at all times. All certificates obtained pursuant to this section shall be renewed annually for the same fee and in the same manner as the initial certificate was obtained. 
(e)  All certificates or renewals thereof required to be obtained under this section shall only be issued to persons 18 years of age or older who present satisfactory evidence of the animal's current rabies vaccination, if applicable, and that the animal is and will be confined in a proper enclosure or is and will be confined inside the owner's residence or is and will be muzzled and confined in the owner's fenced-in yard until the proper enclosure is constructed. In addition, owners who apply for certificates or renewals thereof under this section shall not be issued a certificate or renewal thereof unless they present satisfactory evidence that their residence is and will continue to be posted with clearly visible signs warning both minors and adults of the presence of a dangerous dog on the property and the animal has been permanently identified by means of a tattoo on the inside thigh or by electronic implantation. 
(f)  While on the property of its owner, an animal found by a court to be a dangerous dog shall be confined indoors or in a securely enclosed and locked structure of sufficient height and design to prevent its escape or direct contact with or entry by minors, adults, or other animals. The structure shall be designed to provide the animal with shelter from the elements of nature. When off its owner's property, an animal found by a court to be a dangerous dog shall be kept on a leash and muzzled in such a manner as not to cause injury to the animal or interfere with the animal's vision or respiration, but so as to prevent it from frightening, attacking or biting a person or another domestic animal. 
(g)  If the owner of an animal found by a court to be a dangerous dog is a minor, the custodial parent or legal guardian shall be responsible for complying with all requirements of this section. 
(h)  After an animal has been found by a court to be a dangerous dog, the animal's owner shall immediately, upon learning of same, notify the local animal control authority if the animal is loose or unconfined; bites a person or attacks another domestic animal; is sold, given away or dies; or has been moved to a different address. 
(i)  The owner of any animal found by a court to be a dangerous dog who willfully fails to comply with the requirements of this section shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor, punishable as provided in section 1-15. 
(j)  All fees collected pursuant to this section, less the costs incurred by the animal control authority in producing and distributing the certificates and tags required by this section, shall be paid into a special dedicated fund in the town treasury for the purpose of paying the expenses of any training course required under Code of Virginia, § 3.1-796.105. 
(Code 1974, § 6-10; Ord. No. 2011-4, 8-8-11) 
State Law reference- Procedure for controlling dangerous or vicious dogs, Code of Virginia, § 3.1-796.93:1. 
Sec. 18-73. - Annoying behavior by dogs. 
(a)  No person shall keep within the town a dog that persistently barks, howls, or by other conduct disturbs the quiet of any person. 
(b)  If after reasonable notice from the police the owner or custodian of such dog shall fail or refuse to prevent such annoyance or disturbance or to remove such dog from the town when ordered by the police, the dog may be removed and impounded by law enforcement personnel and the owner shall be charged with a class 3 misdemeanor punishable as provided in section 1-15 and required to pay all costs of impoundment. 
(Code 1974, § 6-11; Ord. No. 2011-4, 8-8-11) 
Sec. 18-74. - Penning of dogs. 
    No dog shall be penned or confined within a fence or house unless the pen area or house shall be in a condition which conforms with the health standards as determined by the county health department. Violation of this section shall constitute a class 1 misdemeanor, punishable as provided in section 1-15. 
(Code 1974, § 6-15) 
State Law reference- Cruelty to animals, Code of Virginia, § 3.1-796.122. 
Sec. 18-75. - Leashing. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, have the meaning ascribed to them in this subsection: 
    Dog means every dog regardless of sex or age. 
    Owner means every person having right of property in a dog, or who keeps or harbors a dog, or has a dog in his care, or who acts as a custodian of a dog. 
    To run at large or running at large means to roam, loiter, walk, run, destroy property of others, or be off the premises of the owner without being caged, physically carried or held by leash, by a person thoroughly capable both physically and mentally of controlling the dog. 
(b)  Custody. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any owner, harborer or custodian of any dog to allow, cause or permit such dog to run at large, at any time, within the town limits even though the dog is both lawfully licensed and vaccinated. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful for the owner, harborer or custodian of any dog to allow, cause or permit such dog to enter any public building, office or store during the time such business establishments are open for public business unless the dog is on leash or otherwise under the immediate control of such owner. 
(3)  Any person violating this section in any portion thereof shall be charged with a class 3 misdemeanor punishable as provided in section 1-15. 
(Code 1974, §§ 6-13, 6-14; Ord. No. 2011-4, 8-8-11) 
State Law reference- Authority to prohibit dogs from running at large, penalty, Code of Virginia, §§ 3.1-796.93, 3.1-796.94.

Sec. 22-51. - Enforcing agencies. 
(a)  The code enforcement department is hereby designated to act as the enforcing agency for the enforcement of chapter 34, existing structures of the Virginia Uniform Statewide Building Code, duly adopted by the Virginia state board of housing and community development under authority of Code of Virginia, §§ 36-98 and 36-103. Enforcement shall be as provided in this section. 
(b)  The enforcement procedures as provided by chapter 34, existing structures, of the Virginia Uniform Statewide Building Code shall be instituted by the code official when a written complaint is filed with the code official. 
(c)  The board of building code appeals is hereby designated as the appeals board to hear appeals arising from the application of the provisions of chapter 34, existing buildings, of the Virginia Uniform Statewide Building Code. 
(d)  The code official shall establish such procedures or requirements as may be necessary for administration and enforcement of this section. The procedures are to be approved by the council.
