DIVISION 3. - PERMITS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Building permit required prior to connection of utilities, § 86-1. 

Sec. 22-71. - Requirements for issuance. 
    The building official shall issue a building permit for the erection of any building or structure only: 
(1)  After the applicable zoning approval has been obtained and the plans have been approved. 
(2)  After the applicable subdivision approval has been obtained. 
(3)  When the lot on which the building is to be erected abuts, on the side or on the front, a hard surfaced dedicated roadway suitable for all weather travel or a bond posted to assure same. 
(4)  When plumbing fixtures are to be installed where town sanitary sewer and water are available. 
(Code 1974, § 7-4; Ord. of 11-02-87, § 1-14; Ord. of 1-30-89, § 1-14) 
Sec. 22-72. - Building permit fees. 
    The fees for building permits required by the building code adopted in section 22-111 are on file in the town clerk's office. 
(Code 1974, § 7-5; Ord. of 11-02-87, § 1-7; Ord. of 1-30-89, § 1-7) 
Sec. 22-73. - Electrical permit fees. 
    The fees for electrical permits required by the building code adopted in section 22-111 are on file in the town clerk's office. 
(Code 1974, § 7-6; Ord. of 11-02-87, § 1-8; Ord. of 1-30-89, § 1-8) 
Sec. 22-74. - Plumbing permit fees. 
    The fee for a permit under the building code adopted in section 22-111 for the installation, repair or replacement of plumbing is on file in the town clerk's office. 
(Code 1974, § 7-6; Ord. of 11-02-87, § 1-9; Ord. of 1-30-89, § 1-9) 
Sec. 22-75. - Mechanical permit fees. 
    The fee for a permit under the building code adopted in section 22-111 for the installation, repair or replacement of mechanical equipment is on file in the town clerk's office. 
(Code 1974, § 7-6; Ord. of 11-02-87, § 1-10; Ord. of 1-30-89, § 1-10) 
Sec. 22-76. - Refund. 
    If work is not pursued under a permit issued pursuant to the building code adopted in section 22-111 and it is requested that the fee paid therefor be refunded, the fees for administrative service shall be as follows: 
(1)  Permit amendments, extensions, reinstatements and change of ownership/contract change, a fee as on file in the town clerk's office. 
(2)  If an application for a permit is cancelled by written request to the building official within six months of the application date or within 12 months of the issue date, a refund will be granted. The following fees will be deducted from the refund: 
a.  Residential, commercial and other related permits, 30 percent of the fee. 
b.  All other permits, 20 percent of the fee. 
c.  Duplication of permits and inspection slips, a fee as on file in the town clerk's office for each permit or slip. 
(Ord. of 1-30-89, § 1-14) 
Sec. 22-77. - Fee for reinspections. 
    The fee for the reinspection of work pursuant to the building code adopted in section 22-111 made necessary due to the work not being complete for inspection when the request for inspection was made or when corrections are not made before requesting a reinspection, or when the work is not accessible for inspection after inspection has been requested is on file in the town clerk's office. The reinspection fee shall be paid to the building official prior to the performance of the reinspection. 
(Code 1974, § 7-5; Ord. of 11-02-87, § 1-7; Ord. of 1-30-89, § 1-6) 
Secs. 22-78-22-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - BUILDING CODE 

Sec. 22-111. - Adopted. 
(a)  There is hereby adopted by reference in and for the town the Virginia Uniform Statewide Building Code, including the Virginia Construction Code, the Virginia Rehabilitation Code and the Virginia Maintenance Code, with all amendments and addends thereto. The provisions of such code shall control all matters concerning the construction, alteration, addition, repair, removal, demolition, use, location, occupancy and other functions pertaining to the installation of systems (plumbing, electrical, mechanical and the like) vital to all buildings and structures. 
(b)  The Virginia Uniform Statewide Building Code, the Virginia Construction Code, the Virginia Rehabilitation Code and the Virginia Maintenance Code, together with all amendments and addends thereto, shall be enforced by the code official. 
(c)  Wherever in this chapter or elsewhere in this Code the term "building code" is used, it shall mean the Virginia Uniform Statewide Building Code and all of its parts, amendments and addends thereto adopted by this section. 
(Code 1974, § 7-1; Ord. of 11-02-87, § 1-2; Ord. of 1-30-89, § 1-2; Ord. of 12-14-98; Ord. No. 2018-1, 1-8-18) 
State Law reference- Authority of town council to enact unsafe building regulations, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-11.2; authority of town to enforce building code, Code of Virginia, § 36-105; statutory provisions of Uniform Statewide Building Code, Code of Virginia, § 36-97 et seq. 
Sec. 22-112. - Awnings and canopies. 
    Awnings and canopies shall be according to the Virginia Uniform Statewide Building Code. 
(Code 1974, § 3-9; Ord. of 8-10-92, art. 3-9) 
Secs. 22-113-22-145. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - NUMBERING OF BUILDINGS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 70. 

Sec. 22-146. - Establishment of system. 
    There is hereby established a uniform system of numbering houses and buildings fronting on all streets, alleys, avenues and public ways in the town, as drawn by the planning commission; and all houses and buildings shall be numbered in accordance with the plan as drawn, which is hereby adopted, and with the other provisions of this article. 
(Code 1974, § 27-33) 
Sec. 22-147. - Designation of base lines. 
    Atlantic Street shall constitute the base line for numbering along all streets running north and south, and Mecklenburg Avenue shall constitute the base line for numbering along all streets running east and west. 
(Code 1974, § 27-34) 
Sec. 22-148. - Assignment, procurement and specifications for numbers. 
(a)  The code official shall cause the proper numbers to be assigned to each house and building located on any street, alley, avenue or highway in the town; and the owner, occupant or agent shall cause to be placed upon each house or building controlled by him the number or numbers assigned under the uniform system as established by the planning commission and adopted in this article. 
(b)  The numbers shall be placed within 30 days after the assigning of the proper numbers or upon completion of construction, whichever is earlier. The numbers shall be of specifications established by the planning commission. The numbers may be procured from any source desired by the purchaser. 
(c)  The numbers shall be conspicuously placed for each building so that the number can be seen plainly from the street. Whenever any building is situated more than 75 feet from the street line, the number of such building shall be conspicuously displayed at the street line, near the walk, driveway or common entrance to such building and upon a post or other appropriate place so as to be easily discernible from the street. 
(Code 1974, § 27-35) 
Sec. 22-149. - Records of numbers assigned. 
    For the purpose of facilitating a correct numbering, a plat of all streets, avenues and public highways within the town showing the proper numbers of all lots or houses fronting upon all streets, avenues or highways shall be kept on file in the town office. These plats shall be open to inspection of all persons during the office hours of the town office. 
(Code 1974, § 27-37) 
Sec. 22-150. - Code official to supply numbers. 
    It shall be the duty of the code official to inform any party applying therefor of the number or numbers belonging or embraced within the limits of a lot or property as provided in this article. In case of doubt as to the proper number to be assigned to any lot or building, the code official shall determine the number of such lot or building. 
(Code 1974, § 27-38) 
Sec. 22-151. - Numbers for new buildings. 
    Whenever any house, building or structure shall be erected or located in the town, it shall be the duty of the owner to procure the correct number or numbers as designated from the code official and to immediately fasten the number so assigned upon the building as provided in this article. No building permit shall be issued for any house, building or structure until the owner has procured from the code official the official number of the premises. 
(Code 1974, § 27-39) 
Sec. 22-152. - Penalties for failure to comply. 
    If the owner or occupant of any building required to be numbered by this article shall neglect for a period of 30 days to duly attach and maintain the proper number on such building, the code official shall serve upon him a notice requiring such owner or occupant to properly number the same; and if he neglects to do so for ten days after the service of such notice, he shall be deemed to have violated this article. Upon conviction thereof, he shall be guilty of a class 4 misdemeanor, punishable as provided in section 1-15. 
(Code 1974, § 27-40) 
Chapter 26 - BUSINESSES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Advertising, ch. 6; alcoholic beverages, ch. 10; amusements and entertainment, ch. 14; community development, ch. 38; larceny, § 50-141 et seq.; shoplifting, § 50-170 et seq.; crimes involving fraud, § 50-306 et seq.; taxation, ch. 78; utilities, ch. 86; vehicles for hire, ch. 90; commercial district C-1, § 94-461 et seq.; commercial district C-2, § 94-491 et seq.; commercial district C-3, § 94-521 et seq.; industrial district M-1, § 94-551 et seq.; industrial district M-2, § 94-581 et seq.; industrial park district I-P, § 94-611 et seq. 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate businesses, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-839. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 26-1. - Parking vehicles in business district regulated. 
    No person shall park a truck, wagon, cart or vehicle within the business district of the town for a period longer than 15 minutes or in any block for a longer period than one hour in any day to sell and deliver any article he might offer for sale from house to house. 
(Ord. of 7-1-93, § 17.63(e)) 
Cross reference- Traffic and vehicles, ch. 82. 
State Law reference- Licensing peddlers, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3717 et seq.; peddlers at wholesale, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3718. 
Secs. 26-2-26-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - AUCTIONS 

Sec. 26-31. - When allowed. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any retail merchant, wholesale merchant or manufacturer to sell, dispose of or offer for sale at public auction or cause or permit to be sold, disposed of or offered for sale at public auction any merchandise, product or commodity whatsoever, whether the same be their property or whether they sell the same as agents or employees for others. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to: 
(1)  Sales by trustees or receivers of a retailer, wholesaler or manufacturer who is actually going out of business or where the sale by such trustee or receiver is a bona fide sale to subject the property sold for the benefit of the creditors of the retailer, wholesaler or manufacturer. 
(2)  Sales in judicial proceedings or sales on behalf of licensed pawnbrokers or unredeemed pledges in the manner provided by law. 
(3)  Sales of household or kitchen furniture or other personal property that has been in use; except where any local or nonresident merchant shall purchase or take on consignment any used or secondhand articles for the purpose of reselling the same, the sale thereof at public auction in the town is expressly prohibited under the terms of this article. 
(4)  Sale of the stock on hand of any person who shall have held a merchant's license for a period of one year preceding the sale and shall have been continuously in business in the town as a retail or wholesale merchant or manufacturer and who is going out of business in the town. 
(Ord. of 7-1-93, § 17.54(a)) 
Sec. 26-32. - Method of sale. 
    The sale at public auction of the stock on hand of a merchant or manufacturer shall be held on successive days, Sundays and legal holidays excepted, and shall not continue for more than 30 days in all; provided that: 
(1)  The merchandise shall be sold at public auction for cash only. 
(2)  The merchant shall publicly and conspicuously advertise on the front of the storehouse or building in which the auction sale is held the fact that the merchant is going out of business. 
(3)  At the auction sale, no merchandise shall be offered except what has been a bona fide part of the stock of merchandise of the merchant for more than 60 days preceding the commencement of the auction sale. 
(4)  The merchant before the commencement of the auction sale shall file with the town treasurer an inventory of the merchandise to be offered at the auction sale, with the cost price to the merchant of each article shown thereon and with an affidavit thereto attached made by the merchant or his duly authorized representative to the effect that the inventory is true and correct, that the merchant is going out of business and that the merchandise to be offered at the auction sale is listed on the inventory and has been a bona fide part of the merchant's stock of merchandise for more than 60 days preceding the commencement of the auction. 
(5)  It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, dispose of or offer for sale at public auction or cause or permit to be sold, disposed of or offered for sale at public auction any merchandise whatsoever, whether the same be his property or whether he sells the same as agent or employee of others, between the hours of 6:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. or at any time, except in a well-lighted place so that each article offered for sale may be plainly seen by all parties bidding thereon; and all announcements made relating to the character, make or value of the article offered must be true and be made in a voice loud enough to be distinctly heard by all parties bidding thereon. 
(Ord. of 7-1-93, § 17.54(b)) 
Sec. 26-33. - Penalty for unauthorized sales. 
    Each article sold or offered for sale contrary to the provisions of this article shall constitute a separate offense under this article. 
(Code 1974, § 17-11; Ord. of 7-1-93, § 17.54(c)) 
Secs. 26-34-26-65. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - INSURANCE, BANKRUPTCY, LIQUIDATION, FIRE, AND SIMILAR SALES[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Going out of business and certain other sales, Code of Virginia, §§ 18.2-223, 18.2-224. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 26-66. - Applicability of article. 
(a)  The provisions of this article shall apply to any person who shall advertise, represent or hold out in the town that any sale at retail of goods, wares or merchandise (hereinafter referred to as "goods") is an insurance, bankruptcy, insolvent, liquidation, assignee's, receiver's, trustee's, adjuster's, wholesaler's, manufacturer's, going out of business or closing out sale or sale of goods damaged by fire, smoke or water or otherwise. 
(b)  The provisions of this article shall not apply to trustees selling under deeds of assignment or mortgages or to sheriffs, constables or other public or court officers or to any other persons acting under the license, direction or authority of any court, state or federal, selling goods in the course of their official duties. 
(Ord. of 7-1-93, § 17.142) 
Sec. 26-67. - Violations of article. 
    Any person who violates any provision of this article shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor, punishable as provided in section 1-15. 
(Ord. of 7-1-93, § 17.143) 
Secs. 26-68-26-90. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 26-91. - Required. 
    No person shall advertise, represent or hold out in the town that any sale of retail of goods, wares or merchandise is an insurance, bankruptcy, insolvent, liquidation, assignee's, receiver's, trustee's, adjuster's, wholesaler's, manufacturer's going out of business, closing out sale or a sale of goods damaged by fire, smoke, water or otherwise, nor shall any person conduct such a sale, unless he shall have first obtained a permit to conduct such sale from the town treasurer. 
(Ord. of 7-1-93, § 17.141) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-223. 
Sec. 26-92. - Fee. 
    The applicant for a permit required by this division shall pay a permit fee per 60-day period, and there shall be no abatement of such fee for any reason whatsoever. The amount of the fee is on file in the town clerk's office. 
(Ord. of 7-1-93, § 17.141) 
State Law reference- Permit required, maximum fee, Code of Virginia, §§ 18.2-223, 18.2-224. 
Sec. 26-93. - Inspection by town treasurer. 
    Upon the application for a permit required by this division by a merchant, the town treasurer shall inspect the advertisement and conducting of such sale to ensure that it is being advertised and conducted in conformity with the required permit. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-223. 
Sec. 26-94. - Permit not assignable. 
    A permit issued under this division shall not be assignable. 
(Ord. of 7-1-93, § 17.147) 
Sec. 26-95. - Inventory required. 
    All applications for special sale permits shall be accompanied by an inventory, including the kind and quantity of all goods to be offered for sale during the sale; and only the goods specified in the inventory list may be advertised or sold during the sale period. Goods not included on the inventory of special sale goods shall not be commingled with or added to the special sale goods. The town shall have the right to revoke a special sale permit upon proof that goods not appearing on the original inventory of special sale goods have been commingled with or added to the special sale goods. 
(Ord. of 7-1-93, §§ 17.145, 17.148) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-223. 
Sec. 26-96. - Time limitations. 
    Each special sale permit shall be valid for a period of no longer than 60 days, and any extension of that time shall constitute a new special sale and shall require an additional permit and inventory. A maximum of one permit beyond the initial 60-day permit may be granted solely for the purpose of liquidating only those goods contained in the initial inventory list that remain unsold. 
(Ord. of 7-1-93, § 17.141) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-223. 
Sec. 26-97. - Permit number. 
    Any person who advertises a special sale shall conspicuously include in the advertisement the permit number assigned for the sale by the town and the effective dates of the sale as authorized in the permit. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-223. 
Secs. 26-98-26-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - PAWNBROKERS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Pawnbrokers, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4000 et seq. 

Sec. 26-131. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Pawnbroker means any person who lends or advances money or other things for profit on the pledge and possession of personal property, or other valuable things, other than securities or written or printed evidences of indebtedness, or who deals in the purchasing of personal property or other valuable things on condition of selling the same back to the seller at a stipulated price. 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4000. 
Sec. 26-132. - License authorized by court; building designated in license; penalty. 
(a)  The circuit court may authorize the town to issue to any individual who produces satisfactory evidence of his good character a license to engage in the business of a pawnbroker in the town. No such license shall be issued by the town except with such authority. Prior to the issuance of the license, the applicant shall furnish his date of birth and such other information as may be required by the council. The license shall designate the building in which the licensee shall carry on such business. No person shall engage in the business of a pawnbroker without being licensed. 
(b)  No person shall engage in the business of a pawnbroker in any location other than the one designated in the license except with consent of the court that authorized the license. Any person who violates the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a class 4 misdemeanor, punishable as provided in section 1-15. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4001. 
Sec. 26-133. - Limitations as to number of pawnshops. 
(a)  In addition to all limitations and restrictions and notwithstanding any other relevant provisions of this article, the town council may limit by resolution or ordinance the number of pawnshops that may be operated at any one time within the town. 
(b)  The circuit court shall not authorize any license to any pawnbroker after the commissioner of the revenue or other tax assessing officer of the town over which it has jurisdiction for the issuance of such licenses has filed with the court a statement that the number of licensed pawnshops within the town has reached the maximum number of pawnshops authorized to be operated therein unless the number has been reduced below the maximum prescribed. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4002. 
Sec. 26-134. - Private action on bond. 
    Any person who recovers a judgment against a licensed pawnbroker for the pawnbroker's misconduct may maintain an action in his own name upon the bond of the pawnbroker if the execution issued upon such judgement is wholly or partially unsatisfied. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4003. 
Sec. 26-135. - Memorandum to be given pledgor. 
    Every pawnbroker shall at the time of each loan deliver to the person pawning or pledging anything, a memorandum or note, signed by him, containing the information required by section 26-140. A one-time $2.00 service fee may be charged for any such entry, memorandum or note. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4004. 
Sec. 26-136. - Sale of goods pawned. 
    No pawnbroker shall sell any pawn or pledge until it has been in his possession for four months, unless a shorter period of not less than 30 days is agreed to in writing by the pawner, and a statement of ownership is obtained from the pawner. All sales of items pursuant to this section shall be made at a public auction conducted by a licensed auctioneer. The council may determine the contents of the statement of ownership. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4005. 
Sec. 26-137. - Notice of sale. 
    Notice of every sale of a pawn or pledge shall be published for at least five days prior to the sale in one or more daily newspapers of general circulation in the town. The notice shall specify the time and place of the sale, the name of the auctioneer, the kinds of articles to be sold, and the number of the pawner's ticket. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4006. 
Sec. 26-138. - Disposition of surplus. 
    After deductions are made for the amount of the loan, interest due on the loan and the expenses of advertising and conducting the sale, the pawnbroker shall pay any money remaining from the proceeds of the sale to the person who would have been entitled to redeem the pledge if the sale had not taken place. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4007. 
Sec. 26-139. - Interest chargeable. 
    No pawnbroker shall ask, demand or receive a greater rate of interest than ten percent per month on a loan of $25.00 or less, or seven percent per month on a loan of more than $25.00 and less than $100.00, or five percent per month on a loan of $100.00 or more, secured by a pledge of tangible personal property. No loan shall be divided for the purpose of increasing the percentage to be paid the pawnbroker. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4008. 
Sec. 26-140. - Records to be kept; credentials of person pawning goods. 
(a)  Every pawnbroker shall keep at his place of business an accurate and legible record of each loan or transaction in the course of his business. The account shall be recorded at the time of the loan or transaction and shall include: 
(1)  A description, serial number, and a statement of ownership of the goods, article or thing pawned or pledged or received on account of money loaned thereon; 
(2)  The time, date and place of the transaction; 
(3)  The amount of money loaned thereon at the time of pledging the same; 
(4)  The rate of interest to be paid on such loan; 
(5)  The full name, residence address, work place, and home and work telephone numbers of the person pawning or pledging the goods, article or thing, together with a particular description, including the height, weight, date of birth, race, gender, hair and eye color, and any other identifying marks, of such person; 
(6)  Verification of the identification by the exhibition of a government-issued identification card such as a driver's license or military identification card, which record shall contain the type of identification exhibited, the issuing agency, and the number thereon; 
(7)  The terms and conditions of the loan, including the period for which any such loan may be made; and 
(8)  All other facts and circumstances respecting such loan. 
(b)  The regulations promulgated by the superintendent of state police specifying the nature of the particular description for the purposes of subsection (a)(5) above shall apply. The regulations promulgated by the superintendent of state police specifying the nature of identifying credentials of the person pawning or pledging the goods shall apply. Such credentials shall be examined by the pawnbroker, and an appropriate record retained thereof. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4009. 
Sec. 26-141. - Daily reports. 
(a)  Every pawnbroker shall prepare a daily report of all goods, articles or things pawned or pledged with him that day and file such report by noon of the following day with the chief of police and such other law enforcement officer designated by the local attorney for the commonwealth to receive it. The report shall include the name and residence of the pledgor and a description of the goods, article or thing pledged and shall be in writing and clearly legible to any person inspecting it. 
(b)  Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a class 4 misdemeanor, punishable as provided in section 1-15. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4010. 
Sec. 26-142. - Officers may examine records or property; warrantless search and seizure authorized. 
    Every pawnbroker and every employee of the pawnbroker shall admit to the pawnbroker's place of business, during regular business hours, the chief of police or his designee or any law enforcement official of the state or federal government. The pawnbroker or employee shall permit the officer to examine all records required by this article and any article listed in a record believed by the officer to be missing or stolen and search for and take into possession any article known to him to be missing, or known or believed by him to have been stolen. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4011. 
Sec. 26-143. - Property pawned not to be disfigured, changed or concealed. 
    No property received on deposit or pledge by any pawnbroker shall be disfigured or its identity destroyed or affected in any manner so long as it continues in pawn or in the possession of the pawnbroker, nor shall any property be concealed for 48 hours after the property is received by the pawnbroker. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4012. 
Sec. 26-144. - Care of blankets, clothing and similar articles. 
    Pawnbrokers shall store, or take care to protect from damage during disuse, all blankets, clothing, carpets, furs, rugs, dress goods, cloths, mirrors, oil paintings, glass and chinaware, pianos, organs, curtains, beddings and upholstered furniture pawned or pledged with them. Pawnbrokers shall be allowed to charge two percent per month in addition to the regular charges for the first three months, or part thereof, while such goods remain as pledge for money advanced. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4013. 
Sec. 26-145. - Penalty for violation by licensed pawnbroker. 
    Any licensed pawnbroker who violates any of the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a class 4 misdemeanor, punishable as provided in section 1-15. In addition, the court may revoke or suspend the pawnbroker's license for second and subsequent offenses. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4014. 
Secs. 26-146-26-175. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - PRECIOUS METALS DEALERS[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate precious metals dealers, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4111. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 26-176. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Coin means any piece of gold, silver or other metal fashioned into a prescribed shape, weight and degree of fineness, stamped by authority of a government with certain marks and devices, and having a certain fixed value as money. 
    Dealer means any person, firm, partnership or corporation engaged in the business of purchasing secondhand precious metals or gems; removing in any manner precious metals or gems from manufactured articles not then owned by the person, firm, partnership, or corporation; or buying, acquiring, or selling precious metals or gems removed from manufactured articles. "Dealer" includes all employers and principals on whose behalf a purchase is made, and any employee or agent who makes any purchase for or on behalf of his employer or principal. The definition of "dealer" shall not include persons engaged in the following: 
(1)  Purchases of precious metals or gems directly from other dealers, manufacturers or wholesalers for retail or wholesale inventories, provided that the selling dealer has complied with the provisions of this article. 
(2)  Purchases of precious metals or gems from a qualified fiduciary who is disposing of the assets of an estate being administered by the fiduciary. 
(3)  Acceptance by a retail merchant of trade-in merchandise previously sold by the retail merchant to the person presenting that merchandise for trade-in. 
(4)  Repairing, restoring or designing jewelry by a retail merchant if such activities are within his normal course of business. 
(5)  Purchases of precious metals or gems by industrial refiners and manufacturers, insofar as such purchases are made directly from retail merchants, wholesalers, dealers, or by mail originating outside the commonwealth. 
(6)  Persons regularly engaged in the business of purchasing and processing nonprecious scrap metals which incidentally may contain traces of precious metals recoverable as a by-product. 
    Gems means any item containing precious or semiprecious stones customarily used in jewelry. 
    Precious metals means any item except coins containing as part of its composition in any degree gold, silver, platinum, platinum alloys or pewter. 
(Ord. of 7-1-93, § 17.111) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4000. 
Sec. 26-177. - Exclusions. 
(a)  The provisions of this article dealing with the subject matter of this article shall not apply to the sale or purchase of coins. 
(b)  The provisions of this article dealing with the subject matter of this article shall not apply to any bank, branch thereof, trust company or bank holding company, or any wholly owned subsidiary thereof, engaged in buying and selling gold and silver bullion. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4109. 
Sec. 26-178. - Penalties; first and subsequent offenses. 
(a)  Any person convicted of violating any of the provisions of this article for the first offense shall be guilty of a class 2 misdemeanor. Upon conviction of any subsequent offense, he shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor punishable as provided in section 1-15. 
(b)  Upon the first conviction of a dealer for violation of any provision of this article, the chief of police may revoke the dealer's permit for one full year from the date the conviction becomes final. Such revocation shall be mandatory upon a second conviction. 
(Ord. of 7-1-93, § 17.122) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4110. 
Secs. 26-179-26-200. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Permit generally, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4108. 

Sec. 26-201. - Required. 
    No dealer shall purchase precious metals or gems, make loans for which precious metals or gems are received and held as security or otherwise engage in the activities of a dealer without first obtaining a permit from the chief of police and without complying with all other provisions of this article. Possession of a permit issued in another locality shall not relieve a dealer of the obligation to obtain a permit from the chief of police. 
(Ord. of 7-1-93, § 17.112) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4108A. 
Sec. 26-202. - Fee. 
    The permit required in this division shall be issued by the chief of police or his designee upon payment of an application fee and satisfaction of the requirements in this article. The amount of the fee is on file in the clerk's office. 
(Ord. of 7-1-93, § 17.113(a)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4108. 
Sec. 26-203. - Required information. 
    Information required on the application for a permit required by this division shall include the dealer's full name, any aliases, address, age, date of birth, sex and fingerprints, and the name, address and telephone number of the applicant's employer, if any, and the location of the place of business of the dealer. No permit shall be valid for more than one year from the date of issuance and may be renewed in the same manner as the initial permit is obtained with an annual permit fee. The amount of the fee is on file in the town clerk's office. 
(Ord. of 7-1-93, § 17.113(b)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4108B, D. 
Sec. 26-204. - Issuance. 
    The applicant for a permit required by this division shall be issued a permit if he satisfies the chief of police of his good character and he has not been convicted within the seven years prior to date of application of a felony or a crime of moral turpitude. The permit shall be denied if the applicant has been denied a permit or has had a permit revoked under this article or any ordinance similar in substance to Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4100 et seq. 
(Ord. of 7-1-93, § 17.113(b)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4108B. 
Sec. 26-205. - Inspection of weighing devices. 
    Before a permit required by this division may be issued, the dealer must have all weighing devices used in his business inspected and approved by the town or state weights and measures official and present written evidence of such approval to the chief of police. 
(Ord. of 7-1-93, § 17.113(c)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4108C. 
Sec. 26-206. - Location of business. 
    The business of a dealer shall be conducted only from the fixed and permanent location specified in his application for a permit. 
(Ord. of 7-1-93, § 17.113(e)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4108E. 
Sec. 26-207. - Permit nontransferable, display. 
(a)  The permit issued under this division shall be a personal privilege and shall not be transferable. There shall be no abatement of the fee for such permit by reason of the fact that the dealer shall have exercised the privilege for any period of time less than for which it was granted. 
(b)  The permit shall at all times be displayed prominently by the dealer on his business premises. 
(Ord. of 7-1-93, § 17.114) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4108D. 
Sec. 26-208. - False statements. 
    Any false statement made on the application form under this division voids the permit ab initio. 
(Ord. of 7-1-93, § 17.115) 
Secs. 26-209-26-230. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - REGULATIONS 

Sec. 26-231. - Closings, reopenings. 
    If the business of the dealer regulated by this article is not operated without interruption, with Saturdays, Sundays, and recognized holidays excepted, the dealer shall notify the chief of police of all closings and reopenings of such business. 
(Ord. of 7-1-93, § 17.113(d)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4108E. 
Sec. 26-232. - Records to be kept; copy furnished to local authorities. 
(a)  Every dealer shall keep at his place of business an accurate and legible record of each purchase of precious metals or gems. The record of each purchase shall be retained by the dealer for at least 24 months and shall set forth the following: 
(1)  A complete description of all precious metals or gems purchased from each seller, including all names, initials, serial numbers or other identifying marks or monograms on each item purchased, the true weight or carat of any gem, and the price paid for each item; 
(2)  The date, time and place of receiving the items purchased; 
(3)  The full name, residence address, work place, home and work telephone numbers, date of birth, sex, race, height, weight, hair and eye color, and other identifying marks; 
(4)  Verification of the identification by the exhibition of a government-issued identification card such as a driver's license or military identification card; the record shall contain the type of identification exhibited, the issuing agency, and the number thereon; and 
(5)  A statement of ownership from the seller. 
(b)  The information required by subsection (a)(2)-(4) above shall appear on each bill of sale for all precious metals and gems purchased by a dealer, and a copy shall be mailed or delivered within 24 hours of the time of purchase to the chief of police. 
(Ord. of 7-1-93, §§ 17.116, 17.117(a), (b)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4101. 
Sec. 26-233. - Right of entry of law enforcement officers. 
    Every dealer shall admit to his place of business during regular business hours the chief of police or his designee, or any law enforcement officer of the state or federal government. The dealer or his employee shall permit such officer to examine all records required by this article and any article listed in a record that is believed by the officer to be missing or stolen and search for and take into possession any article known to him to be missing, or known or believed by him to have been stolen. 
(Ord. of 7-1-93, § 17.117(c)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4101.1. 
Sec. 26-234. - Credentials and statement of ownership required from seller. 
(a)  No dealer shall purchase precious metals or gems without first ascertaining the identity of the seller by requiring an identification issued by a governmental agency with a photograph of the seller thereon, and at least one other corroborating means of identification, and obtaining a statement of ownership from the seller. 
(b)  The council shall determine the contents of the statement of ownership. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4102. 
Sec. 26-235. - Prohibited purchases. 
    No dealer shall purchase or make a loan of precious metals or gems from any seller who is under the age of 18 years. No dealer shall purchase or make a loan on precious metals or gems from anyone who the dealer believes or has reason to believe is not the owner of such precious metals or gems unless the seller has written and duly authenticated authorization from the owner permitting and directing such sale. 
(Ord. of 7-1-93, § 17.118) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4103. 
Sec. 26-236. - Dealer to retain purchases. 
(a)  A dealer shall retain all precious metals or gems purchased for a minimum of ten calendar days from the date on which a copy of the bill of sale is received by the chief of police. Until the expiration of this period, the dealer shall not sell, alter or dispose of a purchased item in whole or in part, or remove it from the town. 
(b)  If a dealer performs the service of removing precious metals or gems, he shall retain the metals or gems removed and the article from which the removal was made for a period of ten calendar days after receiving such article and precious metals or gems. 
(Ord. of 7-1-93, § 17.119) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4104. 
Sec. 26-237. - Bond or letter of credit required of dealers when permit obtained. 
(a)  Every dealer in precious metals or gems shall secure a permit as required by section 26-201, and each dealer at the time of obtaining such permit shall enter into a recognizance to the council secured by a corporate surety authorized to do business in this state, in the penal sum of $10,000.00, conditioned upon due observance of the terms of this article. In lieu of a bond, a dealer may cause to be issued by a bank authorized to do business in the commonwealth a letter of credit in favor of the council for $10,000.00. 
(b)  A single bond upon an employer or principal may be written or a single letter of credit issued to cover all employees and all transactions occurring at a single location. 
(Ord. of 7-1-93, § 17.120) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4106. 
Sec. 26-238. - Private action on bond or letter of credit. 
    Any person aggrieved by the misconduct of any dealer who violated the provisions of this article may maintain an action for recovery in any court of proper jurisdiction against the dealer and his surety. Recovery against the surety shall be only for that amount of the judgment unsatisfied by the dealer. 
(Ord. of 7-1-93, § 17.121) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4107. 
Chapter 30 - CEMETERIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Trespass at night upon any cemetery, § 50-204; injuries to cemeteries and burial grounds, § 50-205; prohibition against disposal of dead body, § 50-387; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 70. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 30-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Cemetery means Oakwood Cemetery and West View Cemetery of the Town of South Hill, Virginia. 
(Code 1974, § 9-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Secs. 30-2-30-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 30-31-30-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CEMETERY COMMITTEE OF THE COUNCIL[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Committees of town council, § 2-91 et seq. 

Sec. 30-51. - Established. 
    There is hereby established a cemetery committee of the council. 
Sec. 30-52. - Duties. 
    The cemetery committee of the council shall have control of the cemeteries of the town with full authority to enforce all provisions of this chapter and other ordinances with respect to the cemeteries of the town. 
(Code 1974, § 9-2) 
Sec. 30-53. - Rules and regulations. 
    The cemetery committee may make and enforce, subject to the approval of the council, such rules and regulations as it may deem necessary for the proper maintenance, supervision and care of the cemetery. It shall be unlawful for any person to fail, neglect or refuse to comply with such rules and regulations. 
(Code 1974, § 9-3) 
Secs. 30-54-30-85. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - REGULATIONS 

Sec. 30-86. - Stones to be set in concrete. 
    All stones that are installed in the cemeteries shall have four inches of concrete on ground level on all four sides of the stone. 
(Code 1974, § 9-4) 
Sec. 30-87. - Prices of graves and lots. 
    Prices for graves and lots shall be as provided by the council and are on file in the town clerk's office. 
(Code 1974, § 9-5) 
Sec. 30-88. - Trespass at night. 
    If any person, without the consent of the owner, proprietor or custodian, shall go or enter in the nighttime between the hours of one-half hour after sunset until one-half hour before sunrise upon the premises, property, driveways or walks of any cemetery, either public or private, for any purpose other than to visit the burial lot or grave of some member of his family, he shall be guilty of a trespass and shall, upon conviction, be guilty of a class 4 misdemeanor punishable as provided in section 1-15. 
(Code 1974, § 9-6) 
Chapter 34 - CIVIL EMERGENCIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; fire prevention and protection, ch. 46. 
State Law reference- Emergency services and disaster law, Code of Virginia, § 44-146.13 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 34-1-34-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - DISASTER PREPAREDNESS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Continuity of government, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-13.1; emergency services and disaster law, Code of Virginia, § 44-146.13 et seq. 

Sec. 34-31. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Civil emergency means: 
(1)  A riot or unlawful assembly characterized by the use of actual force or violence or any threat to use force if accompanied by immediate power to execute such force by three or more persons acting together without authority of law. 
(2)  Any natural disaster or manmade calamity, including flood, conflagration, cyclone, tornado, earthquake or explosion within the corporate limits of the town resulting in the death or injury of persons or the destruction of property to such an extent that extraordinary measures must be taken to protect the public health, safety and welfare. 
    Curfew means a prohibition against any person walking, running, loitering, standing or motoring upon any alley, street, highway, public property or vacant premises within the corporate limits of the town during the hours in which a curfew has been imposed, excepting persons officially designated to duty with reference to the civil emergency. 
(Code 1974, § 2-82) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 34-32. - Penalty. 
    The violation of any provision of this article shall be a class 4 misdemeanor, punishable as provided in section 1-15. 
(Code 1974, § 2-87) 
Sec. 34-33. - Director of emergency services. 
    The director of emergency services shall be the mayor or town manager, who shall have the authority to appoint a coordinator of emergency services activities with the consent of the council. 
(Code 1974, § 2-83) 
Cross reference- Departments, officers and employees, § 2-151 et seq. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 44-146.19. 
Sec. 34-34. - Declaration of local emergency. 
(a)  A local emergency may be declared by the director of emergency services with the consent of the council. If the council cannot convene due to the disaster or other exigent circumstances, the director or any member of the council in the absence of the director may declare the existence of a local emergency, subject to confirmation by the council at its next regularly scheduled meeting or at a special meeting within 14 days of the declaration, whichever occurs first. The council, when in its judgment all emergency actions have been taken, shall take appropriate action to end the declared emergency. 
(b)  A declaration of a local emergency as defined in Code of Virginia, § 44-146.16(6), shall activate the response and recovery programs of all applicable local and interjurisdictional emergency operations plans and authorize the furnishing of aid and assistance thereunder. 
(Code 1974, § 2-84) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 44-146.21(a), (b). 
Sec. 34-35. - Restriction of sales. 
(a)  Whenever a local emergency has been declared, the director of emergency services or any member of the council in the absence of the director, if so authorized by the council, may: 
(1)  Control, restrict, allocate or regulate the use, sale, production and distribution of food, fuel, clothing and other commodities, materials, goods, services and resource systems that fall only within the boundaries of that jurisdiction and that do not impact systems affecting adjoining or other political subdivisions; 
(2)  Enter into contracts and incur obligations necessary to combat such threatened or actual disaster; 
(3)  Protect the health and safety of persons and property; and 
(4)  Provide emergency assistance to the victims of such disaster. 
(b)  In exercising the powers vested under this section, under the supervision and control of the council, the director may proceed without regard to time-consuming procedures and formalities prescribed by law except mandatory constitutional requirements pertaining to the performance of public work, entering into contracts, incurring of obligations, employment of temporary workers, rental of equipment, purchase of supplies and materials, and other expenditures of public funds, provided such funds in excess of appropriations in the current approved budget, unobligated, are available. Whenever the governor has declared a state of emergency in the area encompassing the town, the council may, under the supervision and control of the governor or his designated representative: 
(1)  Enter into contracts and incur obligations necessary to combat such threatened or actual disaster beyond the capabilities of the council; 
(2)  Protect the health and safety of persons and property; and 
(3)  Provide emergency assistance to the victims of such disaster. 
(c)  In exercising the powers vested under this section, under the supervision and control of the governor, the council may proceed without regard to time-consuming procedures and formalities prescribed by law pertaining to public work, entering into contracts, incurring of obligations, employment of temporary workers, rental of equipment, purchase of supplies and materials, levying of taxes, and appropriation and expenditure of public funds. 
(d)  No interjurisdictional agency or official thereof may declare a local emergency. However, an interjurisdictional agency of emergency services shall provide aid and services to the affected political subdivision authorizing such assistance in accordance with the agreement as a result of a local or state declaration. 
(e)  None of the provisions of this article shall apply to emergency disaster relief provided by the American Red Cross or other relief agency solely concerned with the provision of service at no cost to the citizens of the commonwealth. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 44-146.21(c1), (d), (e).
