    It shall be unlawful for any person to permit a vehicle to remain parked in any space beyond the period of time prescribed for such parking space. 
(Ord. of 6-14-10(1)) 
Sec. 50-807. - Presumption where vehicle illegally parked. 
    The fact that an automobile which is illegally parked is registered in the name of a person shall be considered prima facie proof that such person was in control of the automobile at the time of such parking. 
(Ord. of 6-14-10(1)) 
Sec. 50-808. - Stopping vehicle for selling, advertising, displaying or offering goods, wares, merchandise, produce or other property. 
    No person shall stop a vehicle upon the street at any time within a two-hour parking zone for the purpose of advertising, displaying, selling or offering for sale therefrom any goods, wares, merchandise, produce or any other property. 
(Ord. of 6-14-10(1)) 
Sec. 50-809. - Penalties for violation of article. 
(a)  Any person accused of a violation of an ordinance prohibiting parking a vehicle in an area restricting the length of time a vehicle may be parked may settle and compromise the claim against him for such illegal parking by paying to the town the sum of $5.00 if paid within ten days of the date on which the alleged offense was committed. If not paid within ten days, the penalty shall be increased to $10.00, and shall be further increased by an additional $10.00 each calendar month thereafter until the penalty is paid. 
(b)  Any person accused of parking a vehicle in a parking space reserved for the handicapped or designated as a fire lane may settle and compromise the claim against him for such illegal parking by paying to the town the sum of $50.00 if paid within ten days of the date on which the alleged offense was committed. If not paid within ten days, the penalty shall be increased to $75.00, and shall be further increased by an additional $10.00 each calendar month thereafter until the penalty is paid. 
(c)  Except as provided in subsection 50-809(b), any person accused of a violation of an ordinance prohibiting parking a vehicle in specified places other than in an area restricting the length of time a vehicle may be parked may settle and compromise the claim against him for such illegal parking by paying to the town the sum of $5.00 if paid within ten days of the date on which the alleged offense was committed. If not paid within ten days, the penalty shall be increased to $10.00, and shall be further increased by an additional $10.00 each calendar month thereafter until the penalty is paid. 
(d)  Any person who has not settled or compromised the claim against him within the times specified in this section and is subsequently convicted of the alleged offense shall be punished pursuant to section 1-15. 
(Ord. of 6-14-10(1)) 
Secs. 50-810-50-830. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIII. - FALSE ALARMS[13] 

Footnotes: 
--- (13) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2016-5, adopted Nov. 14, 2016, added provisions to the Code but did not specify manner of inclusion. Therefore, at the discretion of the editor, said provisions have been included as Art. XIII herein. 

Sec. 50-831. - Purpose. 
    Malfunctioning alarm systems and the false alerts and alarms associated with them constitute a hazard to public safety personnel and to the public in general. The regulation of false alarms is critical to ensuring the health, safety and welfare of town citizens. False alerts of fire, intrusions, robberies and other safety related events increase the town's public safety costs, divert public safety resources from other critical areas of work, and burden the Mecklenburg Emergency Communications Center. In order to preserve the integrity and efficiency of the town's law enforcement and fire emergency services, those who utilize automatic alarm systems must be required to maintain those systems in good working order and to promptly repair defects which may cause those systems to trigger false alarms. 
(Ord. No. 2016-5, 11-14-16) 
Sec. 50-832. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, and unless otherwise required by the context, the following words and terms shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
    Alarm system means an assembly of equipment and devices arranged to signal the presence of a hazard requiring urgent attention and to which a law enforcement, fire or rescue response is expected. 
    Alarm system user means: 
(1)  Any person or entity owning or leasing an alarm system; or 
(2)  Any person or entity owning or leasing the premises on which such alarm system is maintained. An "alarm system user" shall not include the United States, the Commonwealth of Virginia, or their respective agencies or political subdivisions, nor the county or its school board. 
    Emergency communications center means the 911 center known as the Mecklenburg Emergency Communications Center. 
    False alarm means an alarm that causes a law enforcement or fire department response when there is no actual or threatened criminal activity, fire, or other emergency requiring immediate law enforcement and/or fire department response. False alarms shall include, but not be limited to, negligently or accidentally activated signals; signals resulting from faulty, malfunctioning or improperly installed or maintained equipment; signals which are purposefully activated to summon a law enforcement and/or fire department response in nonemergency situations; and alarms for which the actual cause is not determined. False alarms shall not include alarms caused by failure of the equipment at the emergency communications center, alarms determined by the responding law enforcement and/or fire department to have been triggered by criminal activity, or alarms caused by a weather-related event. "Weather-related event" shall mean an event caused by weather conditions that results in either: 
(1)  Disruption of electrical service to the building for four (4) consecutive hours or longer; or 
(2)  Damage to the building that would activate the alarm. 
(Ord. No. 2016-5, 11-14-16) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Va. Code § 15.2-911. 
Sec. 50-833. - False alarms prohibited; service fees. 
(a)  Prohibition. No alarm system user or other person shall send or activate a false alarm that causes a law enforcement and/or fire department response where there is no actual or threatened crime, fire, or other emergency requiring an immediate law enforcement and/or fire department response. Violations of this section shall result in the assessment of service fees as herein. Nothing contained in this section shall apply to the periodic testing of direct transmittal alarms when sufficient notice is given to the emergency communications center. 
(b)  Service fee amounts. Alarm system users shall pay a service fee for false alarms within 30 days of billing. The service fee shall be assessed for each false alarm during any calendar year as follows: 
(1)  First false alarm: No charge. 
(2)  Second false alarm: No charge. 
(3)  Third false alarm: No charge. 
(4)  Fourth false alarm: $100.00. 
(5)  Fifth false alarm: $250.00. 
(6)  Sixth and each subsequent false alarms: $500.00. 
(c)  Service fee assessments, interest on unpaid charges. The town shall bill alarm system users for false alarms in accordance with the above schedule of service fees. All fees shall be paid within 30 days of billing. Service fees that have not been paid within 30 days of billing shall be subject to interest at the legal rate provided by the Code of Virginia, commencing when the account is more than 30 days delinquent. 
(Ord. No. 2016-5, 11-14-16) 
State Law reference- Regulation of alarm company operators, Code of Virginia § 15.2-911; legal rate of interest, Code of Virginia, § 6.2-301; penalty and interest for failure to pay accounts when due, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-105. 
Sec. 50-834. - Deliberate false alarms a criminal offense. 
    It shall be a class 1 misdemeanor for any person to knowingly and without just cause to activate an alarm system to summon a law enforcement and/or fire department response where there is no actual or threatened criminal activity, fire, or other emergency that required an immediate law enforcement and/or fire department response. 
(Ord. No. 2016-5, 11-14-16) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Va. Code, §§ 18.2-212, 18.2-461. 
Chapter 58 - PLANNING[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; buildings and building regulations, ch. 22; signs, ch. 62; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 70; subdivisions, ch. 74; utilities, ch. 86; zoning, ch. 94. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 58-1-58-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PLANNING COMMISSION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Planning commission, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-437 et seq. 

Sec. 58-31. - Established; title. 
(a)  The planning commission is hereby established in accordance with the provisions of Code of Virginia, § 15.1-437 et seq. 
(b)  The official title of this commission shall be the "South Hill Planning Commission." 
(Code 1974, § 21-1) 
Sec. 58-32. - Membership. 
(a)  The planning commission shall consist of ten members. One shall be a representative of the council, and the remaining nine members shall be residents of the town appointed by the council. 
(b)  The members shall be qualified by knowledge and experience to make decisions on questions of community growth and development. At least half the members so appointed shall be owners of real property. 
(c)  The term of the representative from the council shall be for tenure of office. The other members shall be appointed for a term of four years or until their successors are appointed by the council. Any vacancy in membership shall be filled by appointment by the council and shall be for an unexpired term only. Any appointed member may be removed by the council for inefficiency, neglect of duty, or malfeasance in office. The council may provide for the payment of expenses incurred in the performance of their official duties. A term shall expire immediately prior to the beginning of the regular January meeting at which meeting a commissioner's successor's term of office shall begin. 
(Code 1974, § 21-2) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-437. 
Sec. 58-33. - Officers and their selection. 
(a)  The officers of the planning commission shall be a chairman, a vice-chairman, and a secretary. 
(b)  Nomination of officers shall be made from the floor at the regular January meeting of the commission each year. Election of officers shall follow immediately. 
(c)  A candidate receiving a majority vote of the entire membership of the planning commission shall be declared elected. He shall take office immediately and serve for one year or until his successor shall take office. 
(d)  Vacancies in office shall be filled immediately by regular election procedures. 
(Code 1974, § 21-3) 
Sec. 58-34. - Duties of officers. 
(a)  The chairman shall be a citizen member of the planning commission and shall: 
(1)  Preside at all meetings. 
(2)  Appoint committees, special and/or standing. 
(3)  Rule on all procedural questions, subject to a reversal by a two-thirds majority vote by the members present. 
(4)  Be informed immediately of any official communication and report same at the next regular meeting. 
(5)  Carry out other duties as assigned by the commission. 
(b)  The vice-chairman shall be a citizen member of the commission and shall: 
(1)  Act in the absence or inability of the chairman to act. 
(2)  Have the power to function in the same capacity as the chairman in cases of the chairman's inability to act. 
(c)  The secretary shall: 
(1)  Keep a written record of all business transacted by the commission. 
(2)  Notify all members of all meetings. 
(3)  Keep a file of all official records and reports of the commission. 
(4)  Certify all maps, records and reports of the commission. 
(5)  Give notice of all hearings and public meetings. 
(6)  Attend to the correspondence of the commission. 
(7)  Prepare and be responsible for the publishing of advertisements relating to public hearings. 
(Code 1974, § 21-4) 
Sec. 58-35. - Standing and special committees. 
(a)  The following standing committees may be appointed by the chairman to serve as needed: 
(1)  A comprehensive plan committee, which shall coordinate the work of the other committees as it progresses and relate it to the overall program and keep the comprehensive plan developing in a realistic and reasonable manner. 
(2)  A land use committee, which shall initially determine and continue to maintain an inventory of land uses. This committee shall also be responsible for the preparation of land use maps. 
(3)  A subdivision committee, which, initially, should draft subdivision regulations and any subsequent amendments. They shall examine all applications for subdivisions, receive the views of the staff pertaining to them, and make recommendations to the commission. 
(4)  A zoning committee, which, initially, should draft a zoning ordinance and/or any subsequent amendments. They shall review all applications for rezoning or for special use permits. When authorized by law, they shall hold public or private hearings, receive the views of the staff pertaining to the issue, and make recommendations to the commission. 
(5)  A capital improvements committee, which shall study the economics of capital improvements as it relates to the use of land to be made by the town. This may be done independently or in conjunction with affected governmental agencies. Such study shall include need, priority of need, cost financing, joint use and participation, location, and relative status either within or without the comprehensive plan of the town. To initiate or review applications, receive the views of the staff relative to the issues, and make any recommendations deemed pertinent to the commission are further duties of the committee. 
(b)  Special committees may be appointed by the chairman for purposes and terms approved by the commission. 
(c)  The chairman shall be an ex officio member of every committee. 
(Code 1974, § 21-5) 
Sec. 58-36. - Meetings. 
(a)  Regular meetings of the planning commission shall be held on the first Monday of each month at 7:30 p.m. When a meeting date falls on a legal holiday, the meeting shall be held on the day following unless otherwise designated by the commission. It shall meet at least every two months. 
(b)  Special meetings of the commission may be called by the chairman or by two members upon written request to the secretary. The secretary shall mail to all members, at least five days in advance of a special meeting, a written notice fixing the time and place of the meeting and the purpose thereof. Written notice of a special meeting is not required if the time of the special meeting has been fixed at a regular meeting, or if all members are present at the special meeting or file a written waiver of notice. 
(c)  All meetings, hearings, records and accounts shall be open to the public. 
(d)  A majority of the membership of the commission shall constitute a quorum. The number of votes necessary to transact business shall be a majority of those present and voting. Voting may be by roll call, in which case a record shall be kept as a part of the minutes. 
(Code 1974, § 21-6) 
State Law reference- Meetings, Code of Virginia, §§ 15.1-439, 15.1-440. 
Sec. 58-37. - Order of business. 
(a)  The order of business for a regular meeting of the planning commission shall be: 
(1)  Call to order by chairman. 
(2)  Roll call. 
(3)  Determination of a quorum. 
(4)  Reading of minutes. 
(5)  Report of secretary. 
(6)  Report of standing committees. 
(7)  Report of special committees. 
(8)  Unfinished business. 
(9)  New business. 
(10)  Adjournment. 
(b)  Parliamentary procedure in commission meetings shall be governed by Robert's Rules of Order, Newly Revised. 
(c)  The commission shall keep a set of minutes of all meetings, and these minutes shall become a public record. 
(d)  The secretary shall sign all minutes and at the end of the year shall certify that the minutes of the preceding year are a true and correct copy. 
(Code 1974, § 21-7) 
Sec. 58-38. - Hearings. 
(a)  In addition to those required by law, the planning commission at its discretion may hold public hearings when it decides that a hearing will be in the public interest. 
(b)  Notice of a hearing shall be published in a newspaper having general circulation in the area once a week for two successive weeks specifying the time and place of hearing at which persons affected may appear and present their views, not less than five days nor more than 21 days after final publication. 
(c)  The case before the commission shall be summarized by the chairman or other members delegated by the chairman. Interested parties shall have the privilege of the floor. Records or statements shall be recorded or sworn to, as evidence for any court of law, only after notice is given to the interested parties. 
(d)  A record shall be kept of those speaking before the hearing. 
(Code 1974, § 21-8) 
Sec. 58-39. - Correspondence. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the secretary to draft and sign all correspondence necessary for the execution of the duties and functions of the planning commission. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the secretary to communicate by telephone or telegraph when necessary to make communications that cannot be carried out as rapidly as required through direct correspondence. 
(c)  All official papers and plans involving the authority of the commission shall bear the signature of the chairman and vice-chairman, together with the certification signed by the secretary and chairman. 
(Code 1974, § 21-9) 
Sec. 58-40. - Amendments. 
    The rules of the planning commission may be changed by a recorded two-thirds vote of the entire membership after 30 days' prior notice. 
(Code 1974, § 21-10) 
Chapter 66 - SOLID WASTE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Disposition of dead animals and fowl, § 18-5; buildings and building regulations, ch. 22; environment, ch. 42; accumulation of trash, garbage and other unsightly conditions, § 42-186 et seq.; utilities, ch. 86; disposal of human or animal excrement, garbage or other objectionable waste, § 86-147. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 66-1-66-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - COLLECTION 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 66-31. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Building and construction materials means any material such as lumber, wire, pilings, sheetrock, shingles, brick, plaster, gutter, pipes, concrete, asphalt, stones, topsoil, dirt dredge spoil, or other substances accumulated as the result of the construction repair, alteration, or demolition of infrastructure, including but not limited to, buildings, highways, utilities, streets, sidewalks, or similar structures, dredging or land-clearing activities. 
    Bulk container or dumpster means a metal container of not less than four cubic yards nor larger than eight cubic yards, made of watertight construction with doors opening on two sides and/or top, and constructed so that it can be emptied mechanically by specially equipped trucks. 
    Bulky waste means large items weighing over 50 pounds or exceeding one cubic yard in size, which include, but are not limited to, mattresses, furniture, white goods and appliances such as refrigerators, freezers, hot water heaters, televisions and similar items. 
    Combustible refuse means refuse accumulations of paper, excelsior, rags or wooden or paper boxes or containers, sweepings, and all other accumulations of a nature other than garbage, which are usual to housekeeping and to the operation of stores, offices and other business places. 
    Commercial establishment means any retail, restaurant, manufacturing, wholesale, institutional, religious, governmental, or other non-residential establishment at which garbage or trash may be generated. 
    Garbage means the by-product of animal or vegetable foodstuffs resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and consumption of food or other matter which is subject to decomposition, decay, petrification or the generation of noxious or offensive gases or odors, or which, during or after decay, may serve as breeding or feeding material for insects or animals. 
    Hazardous waste means any substance, material, solid waste, or combination of solid waste which, because of its quantity, concentration or physical, chemical or infectious characteristics may: 
(1)  Cause or significantly contribute to an increase in mortality or an increase in serious irreversible or incapacitating illness; or 
(2)  Pose a substantial present or potential hazard [to] health or the environment when improperly treated, stored, transported, disposed of, or otherwise managed. 
For the purpose of this chapter, the term "hazardous waste" shall include, but not be limited to, materials such as poisons, acids, caustics, chemicals, infectious materials, offal, fecal matter, biological materials, petroleum, petroleum products, flammable materials, compressed gases, radioactive materials and explosives. 
    Household trash means every kind of waste, accumulation of paper, sweepings, dust, rags, bottles, cans of matter of any kind, other than garbage, which is usually attendant to housekeeping. 
    Industrial waste means all waste, including solids, semi-solids, sludges and liquids, created by factories, processing plants, or other manufacturing enterprises. 
    Litter means garbage, refuse, waste materials, including waste tires, or any discarded, used or unconsumed substance which is not handled as specified in this chapter. 
    Person means any individual, firm, company, corporation, partnership, association, governmental body, municipal corporation, or any other legal entity. 
    Recyclable materials means aluminum cans, metal cans, glass bottles and jars (clear, green, brown), plastic beverage containers, newspaper, magazines, office paper and junk mail. 
    Refuse means solid waste accumulations consisting of garbage, household trash, vegetative waste, yard trash, and business trash as herein defined. 
    Vegetative waste means waste accumulation of tree branches, tree limbs, parts of trees, bark, roots, stumps, bushes, or shrubbery generated by yard and lawn care of land-clearing activities. 
    Yard waste/yard trash means waste accumulation of lawn, grass, or shrubbery cuttings or clippings and dry leaf rakings, free of dirt, rocks, large branches and bulky of noncombustible material. 
(Code 1974, § 14-1; Ord. of 8-10-98(1); Ord. No. 2012-1, 1-9-12) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 66-32. - Fees and authority of town manager generally. 
    All residents and businesses in the town shall pay a fee approved by town council for collection and disposal services. The town manager shall have full authority over and supervision of the collection and disposal of all garbage, trash, recyclable materials, and refuse in the town. 
(Code 1974, § 14-2; Ord. No. 2012-1, 1-9-12) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2012-1, adopted Jan. 9, 2012, changed the title of § 66-32 from "Authority of town manager generally" to "Fees and authority of town manager generally". This historical notation has been preserved for reference purposes. 
Sec. 66-33. - Rules and regulations as to collection of garbage. 
    The town manager shall have authority to make rules and regulations relative to the collection, removal and disposition of garbage, combustible refuse, noncombustible refuse, recyclable materials, rubbish and trash not in conflict with the provisions of this article, subject to approval by the council. It shall be unlawful for any person to fail, neglect or refuse to comply with such rules and regulations. Any violation of this article shall constitute a class IV misdemeanor. 
(Code 1974, § 14-3; Ord. of 8-10-98(1); Ord. No. 2012-1, 1-9-12) 
Sec. 66-34. - Purpose and prohibited use of public trash containers. 
    Trash containers placed upon the streets or sidewalks of the town by the town or by any organization, under the direction and approval of the council, shall be for the use of the general public and shall not be loaded by householders or places of business. 
(Code 1974, § 14-4) 
Sec. 66-35. - Trash or garbage originating outside corporate limits. 
    Except as provided in this section, no person may dump or place garbage within receptacles or containers for municipal pickup when the trash or garbage originates outside the corporate limits. 
    The town at its sole discretion may, under rules and regulations set forth by the town manager and approved by the town council, collect and dispose of garbage, refuse, rubbish and trash that originates outside of the corporate limits. 
(Code 1974, § 14-4.1; Ord. of 9-8-03) 
Secs. 66-36-66-55. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - COLLECTION AND REMOVAL 

Sec. 66-56. - Containers for curbside garbage set out for collection. 
    All garbage, refuse and recyclable materials set out for curbside collection in the town shall be placed in containers of sizes and composition prescribed by the town or its designated agent, having secure lids, protecting the contents from flies, dogs, and other creatures and preventing the emission of disagreeable odors. The containers shall be provided to customers by the town or its designated agent. The containers shall be owned by the town or its designated agent and shall be used only by the customers to whom they have been provided. Plastic bags, boxes and similar items placed curbside and not in containers will not be collected. 
(Code 1974, § 14-7; Ord. of 8-10-98(1); Ord. of 8-13-01; Ord. No. 2012-1, 1-9-12) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2012-1, adopted Jan. 9, 2012, changed the title of § 66-56 from "Containers for residential garbage set out for collection" to "Containers for curside garbage set out for collection". This historical notation has been preserved for reference purposes. 
Sec. 66-57. - Containers for commercial trash and refuse set out for collection. 
(a)  All commercial trash and refuse set out for collection in the town shall be placed in bulk containers where a business generates more than four 45-gallon containers of refuse per week. The containers shall be owned by the town and rented to commercial establishments in accordance with a monthly service fee. 
(b)  For the purposes of this article, all businesses located in multi-use buildings or shopping centers may be considered as a whole unit in determining whether or not a bulk container will be required. 
(c)  All commercial solid waste containers are provided for the sole use of commercial establishments for which the container is assigned by the town. Any use of the containers for solid waste by persons not authorized to do so by the commercial establishment is prohibited. 
(Code 1974, § 14-8; Ord. of 8-10-98(1); Ord. of 8-13-01) 
Sec. 66-58. - Bundles for vegetative wastes set out for collection. 
    Vegetative waste set out for collection in the town shall be not over four feet in height, width and length. No vegetative waste shall be larger than four inches in diameter. All vegetative waste shall be placed perpendicular to the edge of the road. 
(Code 1974, § 14-9; Ord. of 8-10-98(1)) 
Sec. 66-59. - Bulky waste collection. 
(a)  Bulky waste will be collected by the town and may be subject to a charge approved by the town council for amounts weighing more than 200 pounds or exceeding six cubic yards in size. 
(b)  For collection of bulky waste citizens must call in the request and the collection will be scheduled by the public works department. Bulky waste must not be placed curbside sooner than 5:00 p.m. on the day prior to its scheduled collection. 
(Code 1974, § 14-10; Ord. of 8-10-98(1); Ord. No. 2012-1, 1-9-12) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2012-1, adopted Jan. 9, 2012, changed the title of § 66-59 from "Containers or bundles for paper boxes, newspapers set out for collection" to "Bulky waste collection". This historical notation has been preserved for reference purposes. 
Sec. 66-60. - Setting out containers for collection. 
    All containers for garbage, trash, recyclables, refuse and other similar matter and all material to be collected by the town or its designated agent shall be set out by the alley adjoining the property or set out next to the street, where it will be conveniently and easily reached by town personnel or its agents making the collection, and shall be so set out for collection by 6:00 a.m. on the day of collection but no earlier than the night preceding the day of collection. 
(Code 1974, § 14-12; Ord. of 8-10-98(1); Ord. No. 2012-1, 1-9-12) 
Sec. 66-61. - Keeping containers covered. 
    All containers for garbage, trash, recyclables, refuse and other similar matter shall be kept covered at all times. 
(Code 1974, § 14-13; Ord. No. 2012-1, 1-9-12) 
Sec. 66-62. - Removal of containers after collection. 
    After being emptied, each container for garbage, trash, recyclables, refuse and other similar matter shall be removed from the sidewalk, curb, street or alley by the customer, not later than 9:00 a.m. of the day following the date of collection. 
(Code 1974, § 14-14; Ord. No. 2012-1, 1-9-12) 
Sec. 66-63. - Schedule for collection. 
(a)  Collection of garbage and refuse will be provided weekly to curbside customers. Recyclables collection will be provided bi-weekly to curbside customers. Commercial bulk customers shall have their garbage collected in accordance with the schedule established by the town manager. 
(b)  Unscheduled collections for commercial bulk containers shall be subject to a fee set and approved by the town council and/or the town manager. 
(Code 1974, § 14-15; Ord. of 8-10-98(1); Ord. of 9-12-05(1); Ord. No. 2012-1, 1-9-12) 
Sec. 66-64. - Entrance upon private property by town employees. 
    No employee of the town or its designated agent shall enter upon any private property while engaged in the collection of garbage, trash, recyclables or refuse without prior written authorization of the property owner or occupant. 
(Code 1974, § 14-16; Ord. No. 2012-1, 1-9-12) 
Sec. 66-65. - Removal of waste materials resulting from construction of buildings. 
    All waste materials resulting from construction, repairs, or demolition of buildings, such as lumber, stone, brick, cement, sand, glass, roofing, plaster and foundation stone or gravel, shall be removed, within 30 days, by the owners of such buildings or their agents. Waste materials shall not be placed in the bulk container supplied by the town. 
(Code 1974, § 14-17; Ord of 8-10-98(1)) 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 22. 
Sec. 66-66. - Hot ashes, burning materials. 
    Hot ashes or any material burning in any container will not be collected by town employees. 
(Code 1974, § 14-18) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, ch. 46. 
Sec. 66-67. - Site requirements. 
    Each new or modified commercial establishment must provide adequate space on their property for a bulk container. All bulk containers are to be screened from public view on all sides. The screening shall include fencing of such height and constructed of such material so as to screen the dumpsters to the satisfaction of the town manager. Fencing shall have a gate of at least sufficient width to accommodate the collection of the waste by mechanized machinery. Any enclosure used for screening shall be approved by the town manager. All existing commercial establishments shall be encouraged to install fencing at the discretion of the town manager. 
(Ord. of 8-10-98(1)) 
Sec. 66-68. - Responsibilities of bulk container customer. 
(a)  Areas around bulk containers shall be free from debris, litter, garbage, etc. All trash is to be placed in bags inside the bulk container. Containers will be emptied in a timely manner and in accordance with a schedule established by the town manager. 
(b)  The town manager shall have authority to require a higher level of service at a bulk container location should that be required in order to maintain sanitary conditions around a bulk container location. The minimum level of service for any bulk container will be one collection per week. 
(Ord. of 8-10-98(1)) 
Sec. 66-69. - Brush collection. 
    Brush will be collected by town forces if placed in bundles not to exceed four feet in length, four feet in height, and four feet in width. All brush must be set by the curb for collection. A charge approved by the town council will be assessed for collecting amounts of brush over six cubic yards in total volume. Stumps, logs,or entire trees will not be picked up by town personnel. Trees, shrubbery, or brush cut by a contractor will be removed by the contractor. 
(Ord. of 8-10-98(1)) 
Sec. 66-70. - Collection of grass clippings. 
    Grass clippings are to be placed in clear plastic bags, 32-gallon containers or left loose at the edge of the road. Grass clippings placed in 32-gallon containers are not to be intermingled with any household trash or garbage. A charge approved by the town council will be assessed for grass clippings placed by the curb for collection in amounts greater than six cubic yards. 
(Ord. of 8-10-98(1)) 
Sec. 66-71. - Collection of leaves and pine needles. 
    Leaves and pine needles placed in piles will be collected at the edge of the road from October 15 to December 31 of each year by town personnel as established by a published schedule. Leaves and pine needles will be collected on the normal collection day. Leaf piles must be free of twigs, branches, rocks, etc. 
(Ord. of 8-10-98(1)) 
Secs. 66-72-66-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CONDITIONS OF PREMISES 

Sec. 66-91. - Maintenance of litter free properties. 
    All owners or occupants of property within the town limits shall maintain such property in a clean and litter-free condition. This shall include, but not limited to, sidewalks, alleys, driveways, yards and grounds, fences, walls, and property lines, drainages, and vacant lots. 
(Ord. of 8-10-98(1)) 
Sec. 66-92. - Maintenance of public right-of-way. 
    Property owners whose property abuts the public right-of-way shall keep that portion of right-of-way free of litter and it shall be unlawful to sweep litter onto said right-of-way. 
(Ord. of 8-10-98(1)) 
Sec. 66-93. - Removal of debris from properties. 
    Property owners who do not keep their property free of trash, debris, refuse, litter, and such will be in violation of this article. 
(Ord. of 8-10-98(1)) 
Sec. 66-94. - Notification to remove debris from property. 
    Upon verification of the violation of this article, the town manager or his designee shall notify the property owner by certified mail to remove trash, debris, refuse, litter, and such from any property in town. 
(Ord. of 8-10-98(1)) 
Sec. 66-95. - Failure to comply. 
    Failure to comply with a notice to remove trash debris, refuse, litter, and such from a property within seven days of notification will constitute a violation of this article. The town manager will be authorized to remove such material from a property and bill the property owner for the expense of such. Failure to pay for the removal of above material within 15 days of notification will constitute a lien on the property for the amount so billed. 
(Ord. of 8-10-98(1)) 
Sec. 66-96. - Cutting of grass, weeds, and other foreign growth. 
    All properties shall be kept free of tall grass, weeds, and other foreign growth. Growth in excess of 12 inches shall constitute a violation of this article and will require the town manager to notify the property owner of such violation. Should the property owner fail to cut the grass, weeds, or foreign growth within ten days of notification by the town manager, the property will be cut and the owner billed for the expenses. Failure of the property owner to pay for such expenses within 15 days shall constitute a lien on the property equal to the cost of cutting. 
(Ord. of 8-10-98(1)) 
Chapter 70 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes:
