(4)  After receiving the required approvals of the site development and engineering plans, the subdivider will provide acceptable sureties to the town that guarantee the successful completion of the subdivision according to the approved plans and plats. 
(5)  The subdivider will then be authorized to record the final plat in the office of the clerk of circuit court in the county with a certified copy to be placed on file with the agent of the town. 
(Ord. of 6-9-03(2)) 
Sec. 74.1-31. - Other plat requirements. 
(a)  Platting required. Any owner or developer of any tract of land situated within the South Hill town limits or within two miles of the corporate limits in Mecklenburg County as defined in the Code of Virginia and as depicted on a map on file in the agent's office who subdivides the land shall cause a plat of such subdivision, with reference to known or permanent monuments, to be made and recorded in the office of the clerk of the circuit court. No such plat of subdivision shall be recorded unless it shall have been submitted, approved and certified by the agent in accordance with the regulations set forth in this chapter. No lot shall be sold in any such subdivision before the plat shall have been recorded. 
(b)  Certification. Every subdivision plat which is intended for recording shall be prepared by a certified professional engineer or land surveyor, who shall endorse upon each plat a certificate signed by him or her setting forth the source of title of the owner of the land subdivided and the place of record of the last instrument in the chain of title. When the plat is of land acquired from more than one source of title, the outlines of the several tracts shall be indicated upon the plat. Nothing herein, however, shall be deemed to prohibit the preparation of preliminary studies, plans or plats of a proposed subdivision by the owner of the land, city planners, land planners architects, landscape architects or others having training or experience in subdivision planning and design (Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2262). 
_____
(c)  Owners statement. Every such plat, or the deed of dedication to which plat is attached, shall contain in addition to the surveyor's or engineers's certificate a statement to the following effect: 
"the above and foregoing subdivision of 
____________ 
(here insert correct description of the land subdivided) 
as appears in the plat 
is with the free consent and in accordance with the desire 
of the undersigned owners, proprietors, and trustees, if any, 
____________  
    Such plat and certificate shall be duly acknowledged before some officer authorized to take acknowledgments of deeds, and when thus executed and approved as herein specified shall be filed and recorded in the office of the clerk of the circuit court, and indexed under the names of the landowners signing such statement and under the name of the subdivision. 
_____
(d)  No one exempt. No person shall subdivide any tract of land that is located within the town or within two miles of the corporate limits in the county except in conformity with the provisions of this chapter. 
(e)  Private contract. This chapter bears no relation to any private easement, covenant, agreement or restriction; nor is the responsibility of enforcing such private easement, covenant, agreement or restriction implied in this chapter to any public official. When this chapter calls for more restrictive standards than are required by private contracts, the provisions of this chapter shall control. 
(f)  Changes on plat prohibited. No change, erasure or revision shall be made on any preliminary or final plat, nor on accompanying data sheets after approval of the agent has been endorsed in writing on the plat or sheets, unless authorization for such changes has been granted in writing by the agent. 
(g)  Fees. There shall be a charge for the examination and approval or disapproval of every plat reviewed by the agent. At the time of filing the preliminary plat, the subdivider shall deposit with the agent checks payable to the town treasurer in the amount on file in the town clerk's office. At the time of filing the final plat, the subdivider shall deposit with the agent checks payable to the town treasurer in the amount on file in the town clerk's office. Revised, vacated or amended plats must be accompanied by the fee on file in the town clerk's office. Plats reviewed and located within two miles of the town's corporate limits shall pay a fee on file as adopted by council in the town clerk's office. 
(h)  Approval required before sale. Whenever any subdivision of land is proposed, and before any permit for the erection of a structure shall be granted, no lot shall be sold until a final plat for the subdivision shall have been approved and recorded as prescribed in this chapter. 
(Ord. of 6-9-03(2)) 
Sec. 74.1-32. - Preliminary sketch plan. 
    The subdivider may, if he so chooses, submit to the agent a preliminary sketch of the proposed subdivision prior to his preparation of engineered preliminary and final plats. The purpose of such preliminary sketch is to permit the agent to advise the subdivider whether his plans in general are in accordance with the requirements of this chapter. The agent, and in appropriate cases, the planning commission, upon submission of any preliminary sketch, shall study it and advise the subdivider wherein it appears that changes would be necessary. The agent may mark the preliminary sketch indicating necessary changes, and any such marked sketch shall be returned with the preliminary plat. The preliminary sketch shall be as follows: 
(1)  How drawn? It shall be drawn on white paper or on a print of a topographic map of the property. It shall be drawn to a minimum scale of 100 feet to the inch. It shall show the name, location and dimensions of all streets entering the property, adjacent to the property, or terminating at the boundary of the property to be subdivided. It shall show the location of all proposed streets, lots, parks, playgrounds and other proposed uses of the land to be subdivided and shall include the approximate dimensions. 
(2)  Part of tract. Whenever part of a tract is proposed for platting and it is intended to subdivide additional parts in the future, a sketch plan for the entire tract shall be submitted prior to or with the preliminary plat. This sketch is merely for informational purposes and is not binding on the subdivider or the council. 
(Ord. of 6-9-03(2)) 
Sec. 74.1-33. - Procedure for preliminary plat. 
(a)  General procedure. The agent or his appointed representative and, in appropriate cases, the planning commission shall discuss the preliminary plat with the subdivider in order to determine whether or not the preliminary plat generally conforms to the requirements of this chapter and of the zoning ordinance (chapter 94.1 of this revised Code). If the proposed subdivision is outside the corporate limits of the town, but within the two-mile limit as depicted on the map that is a part of this chapter, the subdivider shall at the time present to the agent and planning commission one copy of preliminary plat that has been approved by the county's subdivision agent. The subdivider shall then be advised in writing within 45 days, which may be by formal letter or by legible markings on his copy of the preliminary plat, concerning: 
(1)  Any additional data that may be required; 
(2)  The character and extent of public improvements, if any, that will have to be made according to this chapter; 
(3)  An estimate of the cost of construction of any proposed improvements; 
(4)  The amount of the performance bond which will be required as a prerequisite to approval of the final subdivision plat. In determining the cost of required improvements and the amount of the performance bond, the agent may require a bona fide estimate of the cost of improvements to be furnished by the subdivider. 
(b)  Procedure for filing where land is within corporate limits. When the preliminary plat is of land within the corporate limits of the town: 
(1)  The subdivider shall submit to the agent three prints of a preliminary layout at a minimum scale of 100 feet to the inch, one of which shall be retained by the agent until the final plat is approved. 
(2)  The agent shall then arrange for a meeting with the commission and the subdivider to discuss the plat and note any changes on all three copies. 
(3)  The agent and, in cases where the planning commission is required to review the preliminary subdivision plat, the commission chairman shall sign approval of all three copies and return two copies to the subdivider. 
(4)  The subdivider shall submit the plat to the county health department if town water and sewer are not to be provided. 
(5)  The subdivider shall submit the plat to the state department of transportation, South Hill district office, if directed to do so by the agent. 
(6)  The subdivider shall upon submission of a preliminary plat deposit payment of the amount on file in the town clerk's office with the town treasurer as the fee charged for preliminary plat review. An additional fee will be due with final plat submission. 
(c)  Procedure for filing when land is outside corporate limits. When the preliminary plat is of land situated outside the corporate limits of the town but within two miles of the corporate limits and within the boundaries depicted on the map that is part of this chapter: 
(1)  The subdivider shall submit to the agent three prints of a preliminary layout at a minimum scale of 100 feet to the inch, one of which shall be retained by the agent until final plat is approved. 
(2)  The agent shall then arrange a meeting with the planning commission and the subdivider to discuss the plat and note any changes on all copies. 
(3)  The agent and the commission chairman shall sign approval on all copies and return two copies to the subdivider. 
(4)  The subdivider shall submit the plat to the county health department. 
(5)  The subdivider shall submit the plat to the state department of transportation, South Hill district office. 
(6)  The subdivider shall upon submission of a preliminary plat deposit payment of the amount on file in the town clerk's office with the town treasurer as the fee charged. No additional per lot fee is charged for outside corporate limits subdivisions. 
(7)  The subdivider shall submit back to the agent the preliminary plat as approved by and signed by the county administrator. 
(d)  No guarantee. Approval of a preliminary plat does not constitute a guarantee of approval of a final plat. 
(e)  Time frame to pursue final plat. Once a preliminary subdivision plat is approved, it shall be valid for a period of five years, provided that the subdivider (i) submits a final subdivision plat for all or a portion of the property within one year of such approval, and (ii) thereafter diligently pursues approval of the final subdivision plat. Diligent pursuit of approval means that the subdivider has incurred extensive obligations or substantial expenses relating to the submitted final subdivision plat or modifications thereto. However, no sooner than three years following such preliminary plat approval, and upon ninety days written notice by certified mail to the subdivider, the commission or other agent may revoke such approval upon a specific finding of facts that the subdivider has not diligently pursued approval of the final subdivision plat. 
(Ord. of 6-9-03(2)) 
State Law reference- Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2260 F. 
Sec. 74.1-34. - Contents and submission requirements of preliminary plats. 
    The subdivider shall present to the agent three prints of a preliminary layout at a scale of 100 feet to the inch as a preliminary plat. The preliminary plat shall include the following information: 
(1)  Name. Name of subdivision, owner, subdivider, surveyor or engineer, date of drawing, number of sheets, north point and scale. If true north is used, method of determination must be shown. 
(2)  Location. Location of proposed subdivision by an inset map at a scale of not smaller than one inch equals 2,000 feet showing adjoining roads, their names and numbers, subdivisions and other landmarks. 
(3)  Survey. The boundary survey or existing survey of record provided such survey shows a closure with an accuracy of not less than 1 in 2,500; total acreage, acreage of subdivided area, number and approximate area and frontage of all building sites, existing buildings within the boundaries of the tract, names of owners and their property lines within the boundaries of the tract and adjoining such boundaries. 
(4)  Data. All existing, platted and proposed streets, their names, numbers, and widths; existing utility or other easements, public areas and parking spaces; culverts, drains and watercourses, their names and other pertinent data. 
(5)  Drainage. The complete drainage layout, including all pipe sizes, types, drainage easements and means of transporting the drainage to a well-defined open stream that is considered natural drainage. 
(6)  Streets. A cross section showing the proposed street construction, depth and type of base, type of surface, etc. 
(7)  Map. A profile or contour map showing the proposed grades for the streets and drainage facilities, including elevations of existing and proposed ground surface at all street intersections and at points of major grade change along the centerline of streets, together with proposed grade lines connecting therewith. 
(8)  Zoning. Requirements of the zoning ordinance of the town (chapter 94.1 of this Code) apply only within the corporate limits of the town. 
(9)  Water/sewer. Proposed connections with existing sanitary sewers and existing water supply or alternate means of sewage disposal and water supply. 
(10)  Dedication. All parcels of land to be dedicated for all use and the condition of such dedication. 
(11)  Lighting. The location of streetlights and their illumination pattern shall be shown. 
(Ord. of 6-9-03(2)) 
Sec. 74.1-35. - Contents and submission requirements of final plats. 
(a)  Requirements. The final plat submitted to the agent and the commission shall have been approved and signed by the chairman of the planning commission. The subdivision plats submitted to the commission and agent for final approval by the council and subsequent recording shall be clearly and legibly drawn in black or blue ink at a minimum scale of 100 feet to the inch on sheets having a maximum size of 24 × 36 inches. In addition to the requirements of the preliminary plat, the final plat shall include the information included in this section. All plat details shall meet the standard for plats as adopted under Section 42.1-82 of the Virginia Public Records Act (Code of Virginia, § 42.1-76 et seq.). 
(b)  Reserved space. A blank oblong space three inches by five inches shall be reserved for the use of the council. 
(c)  Certificates. Certificates signed by the surveyor or engineer setting forth the source of title of the owners of the land subdivided and the place of record of the last instrument in the chain of title shall be included. 
(d)  Statement. A statement to the effect that the subdivision as it appears on this plat is with the free consent and in accordance with the desires of the owners, proprietors and trustees, if any, which shall be signed by the owners, proprietors and trustees, if any, shall be included and shall be duly acknowledged before some officer authorized to take acknowledgments of deeds. (Also see section 74.1-31 for sample form.) 
(e)  Outlines. When the subdivision consists of land acquired from more than one source of title, the outlines of the various tracts shall be indicated by dashed lines, and identification of the respective tracts shall be placed on the plat. 
(f)  Locations and dimensions. The accurate location and dimensions by bearings and distances with all curve data on all lots and street lines and centerlines of streets, boundaries of all proposed or existing easements, parks, school sites, all existing public and private streets, their names, numbers and widths, existing utilities, and those to be provided such as sanitary sewers, storm drains, water mains, manholes and underground conduits, including their size and type, watercourses and their names, names of owners and their property lines, both within the boundary of the subdivision and adjoining those boundaries, shall be shown. 
(g)  Accuracy. Distances and bearings must balance and close with an accuracy of not less than one in 10,000. 
(h)  Data. The data of all curves along the street frontage shall be shown in detail in the curve data table containing the delta angle, radius, arc, tangent, chord and chord bearings. 
(i)  Conditions. The plat shall not be approved until the subdivider has complied with the general requirements and minimum standards of design in accordance with this chapter, and has made satisfactory arrangements for performance bond, cash or other sureties satisfactory to the town to cover the cost of necessary improvements to the satisfaction of the agent. Approval of the final plat shall be written on the face of the plat by the agent. The subdivider shall record the plat within 60 days after final approval; otherwise the agent shall mark the plat "void" and return it to the subdivider. 
(j)  Erosion and sediment control plan required. An approved erosion and sediment control plan pursuant to chapter 10.1 with a state professional seal shall be submitted with the final subdivision plat. 
(k)  Plans and specifications. Two blue or black line prints of the plans and specifications for all required physical improvements to be installed shall be prepared by an engineer and shall be submitted to the agent for approval or disapproval within 60 days. If approved, one copy bearing certification of such approval shall be returned to the subdivider. If disapproved, all papers shall be returned to the subdivider with the reason for disapproval in writing. If there is no approval or disapproval within 60 days after it has been officially submitted for approval, the subdivider, after ten days written notice to the agent, may petition the circuit court to decide whether the plat should or should not be approved. The court shall hear the matter and make and enter an order with respect thereto as it deems proper, which may include directing approval of the plat. 
(l)  Performance assurances and bond. 
(1)  Before any subdivision plat will be finally approved by the agent and accepted by the council for dedication for public use any right-of-way located within the subdivision or section thereof, which has constructed or proposed to be constructed any street, curb, gutter, sidewalk, bicycle trail, drainage or sewerage system, waterline, storm water management facility or other facility intended as part of the public system of improvements to be dedicated for public use, and maintained by the town, the commonwealth, or other public agency, the subdivider shall, in lieu of construction, furnish either: 
a.  A certification to the agent that the construction costs have been paid to the person or firm constructing the facilities; 
b.  A certified check, cash escrow, in the amount of the estimated cost of construction; 
c.  A personal, corporate or property bond with surety satisfactory to the agent in an amount sufficient for and conditioned upon the construction of such facilities; 
d.  A contract for the construction of such facilities and a contractor's bond with like surety, in like amount and so conditioned; or 
e.  A letter of credit from a bank or savings institution on certain designated funds satisfactory to the town as to the bank or savings institution, the amount and form. 
(2)  Partial release of surety. The town may release part of any bond, escrow, letter of credit or other performance guarantee required by this section within 30 days after receipt of written notice by the subdivider of the completion of part or all of any facilities required to be constructed by this chapter provided the agent certifies that the facilities for which the release is requested shall have been constructed in accordance with plans and specifications previously approved by the agent. The amount of each release shall be based on the percentage of facilities completed and approved by the agent or state agency having jurisdiction. No release shall be made before completion of 30 percent of the facilities covered by the performance guarantee, nor shall more than three such releases be approved during any calendar year (from Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2245). 
(Ord. of 6-9-03(2)) 
Secs. 74.1-36-74.1-59. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - DESIGN STANDARDS 

Sec. 74.1-60. - Residential lots. 
(a)  Compliance with zoning. The minimum lot size in any area shall be in accordance with the zoning ordinance for those subdivisions within the corporate limits. For those subdivisions lying outside the corporate limits, the minimum lot size shall be in conformance with the requirements of the county's subdivision ordinance. 
(b)  Exceptions. Greater lot areas may be required where individual septic tank or individual wells are used if the health official determines that there are factors of drainage, soil condition or other conditions to cause potential health problems. The agent shall require that data from percolation tests be submitted as a basis for passing upon subdivisions dependent upon septic tanks as a means of sewage disposal. 
(c)  Shape of lots. The lot arrangement, design and shape shall be such that lots will provide satisfactory and desirable sites for buildings, be properly related to topography, and conform to requirements of this chapter. Lots shall not contain peculiarly shaped elongations solely to provide necessary square footage of area that would be unusable for normal purposes. Lots shall not contain peculiarly shaped elongations solely to provide access to a street that is publicly dedicated or will become publicly dedicated through the construction of the subdivision. 
(d)  Location of lots on a street. Each lot shall abut on a street dedicated by the subdivision plat, or on an existing publicly dedicated street, or on a street that has become public by right of use. If the existing streets are not 50 feet in width, the subdivider shall make provisions in the deeds to lots for all buildings to be so constructed as to permit the widening by dedication of such roads or streets to a width of 50 feet. 
(e)  Corner lots. Corner lots shall have extra width sufficient for maintenance of any required building lines on both streets as determined by the zoning ordinance (chapter 94.1 of this Code). 
(f)  Side lines of lots. Side lines of lots shall be approximately at right angles or radial to the street line. At the dead-end of a street that terminates in a turn-around, the lot lines shall generally be radial to the center of the turn-around at the end of such street except in cases where temporary turn-arounds are provided to allow for the future extension of the street. 
(g)  Remnants of lots. All remnants of lots below the minimum size left over after subdividing of a tract must be added to adjacent lots, or otherwise disposed of rather than allowed to remain an unusable parcels. 
(h)  Separate ownership of lots. Where the land covered by a subdivision includes two or more parcels in separate ownership, and lot arrangement is such that a property ownership divides one or more lots, the land in each lot so divided shall be transferred by deed to single ownership, simultaneously with the recording the final plat. This deed is to be deposited with the clerk of the court and held with the final plat until the subdivider is ready to record the plat, and they both shall then be recorded together. 
(i)  Location of lot corners. All lot corners other than at street corners shall be marked with concrete monuments not less than four inches square and not less than 15 inches in depth or iron pins not less than one-half inch in diameter and 24 inches long and driven so as to be flush with the finished grade. When rock is encountered, a hole shall be drilled four inches deep in the rock, into which shall be cemented a steel rod one-half inch in diameter, the top of which shall be flush with the finished grade line. 
(j)  Unusable land area. Not more than 20 percent of the minimum lot area required by the zoning ordinance shall be unusable by reason of location at an elevation below the 100-year flood level, in wetlands or other protected natural resource areas. 
(Ord. of 6-9-03(2)) 
Sec. 74.1-61. - Business or industrial lots. 
Lots  that are intended for development for business or industrial use shall be designed specifically for such purposes and shall provide adequate space for parking and loading in accordance with the zoning ordinance. 
(Ord. of 6-9-03(2)) 
Sec. 74.1-62. - Blocks. 
(a)  Generally. Where created by the subdivision of land, all new blocks shall be of modern design and shall comply with the requirements of this section. 
(b)  Length. Generally the maximum length of blocks upon which lots have frontage shall be 1,200 feet and the minimum length of blocks upon which lots have frontage shall be 500 feet. 
(c)  Width. Blocks shall be wide enough to allow two tiers of lots of minimum depth, except where fronting on major streets, unless prevented by topographical conditions or size of the property, in which case the agent may approve a single tier of lots of minimum depth. 
(d)  Orientation. Where a proposed subdivision will adjoin a major road, the agent may require that the greater dimension of the block shall front or back upon such major thoroughfare to avoid unnecessary ingress and egress. 
(e)  Access through block. In long blocks the agent may require the reservation of easements to facilitate utilities, drainage or pedestrian traffic. 
(Ord. of 6-9-03(2)) 
Secs. 74.1-63-74.1-99. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - IMPROVEMENTS 

Sec. 74.1-100. - General requirements. 
(a)  Stormwater facilities. The subdivider shall provide all necessary information needed to determine what improvements are necessary to properly develop the subject property, including contour intervals, drainage plans, stormwater management and flood control devices. The subdivider shall provide plans for all such improvements, together with a properly qualified certified engineer's or surveyor's statement that such improvements, when properly installed, will be adequate for proper development. The town's agent shall then approve or disapprove the plans. The subdivider shall also provide any other information required by the agent. 
(b)  Easements. The agent may require that easements for drainage through adjoining property be provided by the subdivider. Easements shall be provided for water, sewer, power lines and other utilities in the subdivision as follows: 
(1)  Ten-foot width at the rear of the lot or 20-foot where lots abut other property not being subdivided. 
(2)  Ten-foot width on each side of side lot line. 
(3)  Ten-foot width on front of lot. 
All easements, including utility, storm sewer, or drainage easements, are required to be shown on the preliminary plan and approved. 
(c)  Shared easements. The subdivider may also be required to designate and convey, in appropriate cases, common or shared easements to franchised cable television operators furnishing cable television and public service corporations furnishing cable television, gas, telephone and electric service to the proposed subdivision. Such easements, the location of which shall be adequate for use by public service corporations and franchised cable television operators which may be expected to occupy them, may be conveyed by reference on the final plat to a declaration of the terms and conditions of such common easements and recorded in the land records of the county. 
(Ord. of 6-9-03(2)) 
Sec. 74.1-101. - Monuments. 
    As required by this chapter, all monuments must be installed by the subdivider and shall meet the minimum specifications. Upon completion of subdivision streets, sewers and other improvements, the subdivider shall make certain that all monuments required by the agent are clearly visible for inspection and use. Such monuments shall be inspected and approved by the agent before any improvements are accepted by the council. 
(Ord. of 6-9-03(2)) 
Sec. 74.1-102. - Fire protection. 
    The installation of adequate fire hydrants in a subdivision at locations approved by the agent shall be required provided necessary public water is available. The agent shall consult with the proper authority before approving such location. 
(Ord. of 6-9-03(2)) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, ch. 46. 
Sec. 74.1-103. - Utilities. 
(a)  Material specification. Where the construction and/or extension of water and sewer lines are required by this chapter, all water lines must be either six-inch ductile iron, class 50 or PVC-C900, class 200 with tracter wire. All sewer lines must be either eight-inch ductile iron pipe or eight-inch PVC pipe, SDR-35, unless prior to installation a written variance shall be given by the agent for good cause shown. All materials and construction shall comply with the utility construction standards of the town. 
(b)  Water facilities. Where public water is available, the service shall be extended by the subdivider to all lots within a subdivision including fire hydrants in accordance with the design standards and specifications for water, construction and improvements in the town and meeting the approval of the agent. Every subdivision to which public water cannot or will not be provided shall be supplied by the subdivider with a complete central water supply and distribution system in conformance with the town's requirements, provided that subdivisions with fewer than 25 lots with each lot being 20,000 square feet or more in size may be provided with private wells, with the approval of the county health department. 
(c)  Sewerage facilities. Where public sewerage facilities are available, the service shall be extended to all lots within a subdivision and septic tanks will not be permitted. Every subdivision shall be provided by the subdivider with a satisfactory and sanitary means of sewage collection and disposal in accordance with the current design standards and specifications for sewerage construction and improvements in the town and meeting the approval of the agent. For lots in subdivisions beyond the town limits but within the extra territorial jurisdiction of the town, an individual sewage disposal system for each lot may be provided by the subdivider subject to the approval by the health official. 
(Ord. of 6-9-03(2)) 
Secs. 74.1-104-74.1-220. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - STREETS AND OTHER RIGHTS-OF-WAY 

Sec. 74.1-221. - Street design generally. 
(a)  All streets in the proposed subdivision shall be designed and constructed in accordance with the minimum requirements of this article and other construction standards adopted by the town by the subdivider at no cost to the town. 
(b)  The arrangement of streets in new subdivisions shall make provision for the continuation of existing streets in adjoining areas. The street arrangement must be such as to cause no unnecessary hardship to owners of adjoining property when they plat their own land and seek to provide for convenient access to it. Where in the opinion of the agent it is desirable to provide for street access to adjoining property, proposed streets shall be extended by dedication to the boundary line of such property. Half streets along the boundary of land proposed for subdivision are not permitted. 
(Ord. of 6-9-03(2)) 
Sec. 74.1-222. - Approach angle of major streets. 
    Wherever possible, streets should intersect at right angles. In all hillside areas, streets running with contours shall be required to intersect at angles of not less than 60 degrees unless approved by the agent. Major streets shall approach major or minor streets at an angle of not less than 80 degrees unless the agent, upon recommendation of the highway engineer, shall approve a lesser angle of approach for reasons of contour, terrain or matching of existing patterns. 
(Ord. of 6-9-03(2)) 
Sec. 74.1-223. - Minimum right-of-way widths, minimum pavement widths and other street design standards. 
    Minimum right-of-way widths, minimum pavement widths and other street design standards shall be provided in accordance with current standards of the state department of transportation, relating to geometric design guides for subdivision roads and streets, which are not printed in this chapter, but are on file in the town clerk's office. All streets within and outside the corporate limits shall have a minimum of a 50-foot right-of-way, and a 30-foot minimum pavement width where two lanes of traffic are involved. The 30-foot minimum pavement width can include the hard surface gutter, in accordance with state specifications. The minimum pavement design for all streets shall include eight inches in depth of aggregate base material, and two inches of base course asphalt and 11/2 inches of asphalt surface mix. 
(Ord. of 6-9-03(2)) 
Sec. 74.1-224. - Grades. 
    The grades of streets submitted on subdivision plats shall be approved by the agent according to current state department of transportation standards. 
(Ord. of 6-9-03(2)) 
Sec. 74.1-225. - Construction requirements generally. 
(a)  Conflicts with state, county specifications. In cases where state department of highways and transportation or county specifications are lacking or are less restrictive than the requirements of this chapter, this chapter shall prevail. 
(b)  Drainage. Drainage facilities and drainage structures, including off-site facilities when necessary to provide adequate drainage, shall be provided in accordance with the state department of highways and transportation's current location and design division drainage manual and current road designs and standards. 
(c)  Easements. Drainage easements shall be provided from all drainage outfalls to extend to a watercourse, defined as one where water has been accustomed to gather and flow along a well-defined channel, which by frequent running has worn or cut into the soil. In instances where developments divert more intensified runoff into existing town facilities to the extent that the facilities must be adjusted, such adjustments shall be at the developer's expense; and the developer will be required to furnish any additional easements thus required. In the event curb and gutter is required by the agent, then widths between faces of curbs shall be in accordance with current state department of transportation standards. 
(d)  Curb cut ramps. Curb cut ramps shall be required in accordance with state law. Curb-cut designs approved by the town shall be required for the use of this type of curb and gutter in each instance. 
(e)  Curb and gutter. Curb and gutter shall be installed by the subdivider when erosion damage is such that the agent and street committee of the town council find it necessary. 
(Ord. of 6-9-03(2)) 
Sec. 74.1-226. - Bridges and culverts. 
(a)  Capacity. All bridges and culverts shall be of HS-20-44 loading and military loading in accordance with the current bridge design specifications established by AASHTO. Design calculations utilized in the design shall be submitted with each bridge plan in order to expedite town review. 
(b)  Width. Clear widths shall be provided on all structures in accordance with the state department of transportation's geometric criteria. 
(Ord. of 6-9-03(2)) 
Sec. 74.1-227. - Hydraulic and hydrologic design. 
(a)  Hydraulic and drainage design, and the criteria to be used, shall be in accordance with the state department of transportation's drainage manual. All design criteria and methods of analysis shall be subject to approval by the town. A copy of the hydrologic and hydraulic design data and computations shall be submitted to the town at the same time as the plans are submitted for review. 
(b)  Documentation. All design data shall be properly recorded and shall include all pertinent data (survey, hydrology, hydraulic, floodplain studies) necessary to verify the design. 
(c)  Hydrology. Peak discharges shall be determined by methods appropriate for the size, location and character of the watersheds involved. Where floodplain reports have been prepared for the area, they shall be considered in the design. If these floodplains are affected by tides, tidal action reports shall be included. Appropriate design storm frequencies shall be utilized depending upon the risk of damage to both adjacent property and the roadway. Minimum design criteria applicable to the roadway may not be acceptable relative to adjacent property damage potential, thus requiring higher design criteria. 
(d)  Hydraulic design. No exact criteria for flood frequency or allowable headwater/backwater values can be set that will apply generally to various locations. In the hydraulic design of drainage structures, the following risk evaluations should be considered: 
(1)  Damage to adjacent property. 
(2)  Damage to the roadway and/or structure. 
(3)  Traffic interruption. 
(4)  Hazard to human life. 
(5)  Damage to stream and floodplain environment. 
    Hydraulic design and analysis techniques shall be appropriate for the type of structure or system of structures involved and may require flood profiles and water surface profile analysis. In areas involving floodplains, the federal flood insurance requirements relative to zoning and hydraulic design to accommodate the 100-year flood shall be considered. 
(Ord. of 6-9-03(2)) 
Sec. 74.1-228. - Dams. 
    Whenever dams are to be utilized as roadways, an alternate way of ingress and egress open to the public must be provided. Plans for dams designated for such use shall be reviewed and approved by the town prior to construction. A formal agreement must be executed between the developer and the town regarding the relative responsibility of the maintenance of various elements prior to acceptance. 
(Ord. of 6-9-03(2)) 
Sec. 74.1-229. - Guardrail. 
    A guardrail is a safety element that can serve as protection to the traveling public as well as protection to adjacent properties. When evaluating the need for guardrails within subdivisions, the total effect from the standpoint of safety should be the predominant consideration. However, guardrail types in common usage tend to be objectionable within residential subdivisions from an aesthetic point of view. 
(Ord. of 6-9-03(2)) 
Sec. 74.1-230. - Sidewalks. 
(a)  Sidewalks are not a requirement of the town, but town policy provides for the acceptance of their maintenance whenever they are proposed, whether voluntarily or required by local ordinance, if they are located within dedicated right-of-way and constructed to the state department of transportation's standards on satisfactorily prepared subgrade. 
(b)  Any sidewalk that is constructed contiguous to a curb and gutter typical section shall be constructed of the state department of transportation's specification class P concrete at least four feet wide and four inches deep at appropriate grade so as to tie in compatibly with the curb and gutter. 
(c)  On rural-type typical sections, asphalt plant mix sidewalk will be acceptable when located back of a ditch line on cut sections and back of the guardrail on fill sections. Asphalt sidewalks shall be at least four feet wide and four inches deep at appropriate grade to tie in to the appropriate roadway element. Concrete sidewalks on rural typical sections will be acceptable only when constructed on the ultimate alignment and grade that would tie in to the eventual conversion to a curb and gutter section. Temporary sidewalks that meander horizontally and/or vertically relative to the roadway element may be permitted if they do not conflict with the roadway elements, but the town will not accept the maintenance of these. Therefore, any temporary sidewalks that do not qualify for state maintenance will have to be covered by permit to the extent that they encroach upon the right-of-way. The permit must clearly delineate the maintenance responsibility of the applicant, thus saving the town harmless from any possible liability. The applicant should be a county, corporate town or agency that has perpetual maintenance capability. These temporary sidewalks maintained by others may be asphalt plant mix, gravel or other stabilizer convenient to the applicant. 
(Ord. of 6-9-03(2)) 
Sec. 74.1-231. - Intersections-Landings. 
    At all intersecting streets, a relatively flat landing should be provided on the side streets that have stop or yield situations. It should be of sufficient length to accommodate at least one vehicle, with additional length depending upon the projected traffic volume of the side street. 
(Ord. of 6-9-03(2)) 
Sec. 74.1-232. - Same-Site distances. 
    The site distances shown below are stopping sight distances; they are applicable along the alignment of all streets and are based on a three-foot, nine-inch height of eye to a six-inch height of object. Concurrently, site distances at intersecting streets shall be in accordance with the following tabulation for the operating speed of the predominant street. These shall be based on a three-foot, nine-inch eye to a two-foot object. 
Operating Speed 
(miles per hour) Required 
Sight Distance 
(feet) 25 250 35 350 45 450 55 550  
(Ord. of 6-9-03(2)) 
Sec. 74.1-233. - Same-Turning lanes. 
    Where the turning movement at intersections is of such magnitude as to warrant left or right turn lanes, sufficient additional pavement and right-of-way widths shall be required as necessary. It shall be the town's prerogative to determine when turning lanes are required. 
(Ord. of 6-9-03(2)) 
Sec. 74.1-234. - Traffic projection. 
    For the purpose of these regulations, the town will assume that traffic will be generated in accordance with the traffic projection model currently in use by the state department of transportation. The town will consider any bona fide traffic study that shows otherwise; however, such study shall be subject to the review and approval of the town. 
(Ord. of 6-9-03(2)) 
Sec. 74.1-235. - Townhouses or condominiums. 
    Townhouse and condominium developments are unique and pose additional problems due to the density of units. Foremost among these problems are parking and frequency of individual entrances. Therefore the following shall apply: 
(1)  Spaces for parking. At least two parking spaces per unit shall be provided. In computing the required number of spaces, a combination of off-street parking spaces being provided plus available on-street parking may be considered (see zoning ordinance also). 
(2)  Parking bays. Parking bays shall have well-channelized entrances for ingress and egress that will prevent vehicles from backing into traffic along the street. 
(3)  Entrances. Private entrances and/or entrances to parking bays or lots shall be at least 50 feet apart and shall be arranged in such a manner as to assure the safe channelization of traffic. 
(Ord. of 6-9-03(2)) 
Sec. 74.1-236. - Parking. 
    Perpendicular and angular parking are prohibited, and parallel parking will be approved only where circumstances permit. 
(Ord. of 6-9-03(2)) 
Sec. 74.1-237. - Private entrances. 
    All private entrances are to be constructed in accordance with the state department of transportation's (VDOT) standard PE-1 or applicable VDOT standards for curb and gutter sections, whether installed prior to or subsequent to town acceptance. 
(Ord. of 6-9-03(2)) 
Sec. 74.1-238. - Encroachments. 
    Structures such as ornamental posts, walls, and signs, which serve no functional value from a structural or traffic capacity standpoint, shall not be allowed within the right-of-way limits except those which have received approval by the town in accordance with town rules and regulations. 
(Ord. of 6-9-03(2)) 
Sec. 74.1-239. - Cul-de-sac. 
    Generally, minor terminal streets (cul-de-sac), designed to have one end permanently closed shall be no longer than 800 feet and no less than 100 feet to the beginning of the turnaround. Each cul-de-sac must terminate by a turn-around not less than 100 feet in diameter and a pavement radius of 40 feet. No cul-de-sac shall be established that does not have at least one lot fronting on in between its beginning and where the turnaround begins. 
(Ord. of 6-9-03(2)) 
Sec. 74.1-240. - Alleys. 
    Alleys should be avoided wherever possible. Dead-end alleys, if unavoidable shall be provided with adequate turnaround facilities as determined by the agent. 
(Ord. of 6-9-03(2)) 
Sec. 74.1-241. - Private streets and reserved strips. 
(a)  No private streets shall be platted in any residential single-family detached home subdivision. Every subdivided property for residential single-family detached home subdivision shall be served from a publicly dedicated street, and there shall be no reserve strip controlling access to streets. All streets upon completion and acceptance must be conveyed to the appropriate authority, be it the town or the state department of transportation, for public maintenance. Private maintenance of streets by individual groups, associations or others is expressly prohibited by this chapter, with the exceptions of streets located in areas of the county subject to the provisions of this chapter that the state department of transportation refuses to accept because it does not meet their level of service requirements. Such streets will be dedicated for public use but shall be maintained by the developer or by a property owner's association until such time as it may be conveyed to the state department of transportation for maintenance. The address and by-laws of the property owner's association will be filed with the county administrator and the agent for the town. The town will not approve plans that include the use of streets by adjacent properties, whether within or outside the development proper. Driveways shared with access easements by three or more lots, either within or outside of a subdivision, are considered private streets and shall not be permitted unless they are platted, dedicated as public right-of-way, and constructed as streets in accordance with this chapter. 
(b)  Requirements for private streets in planned residential developments are included in the town's zoning ordinance, chapter 94.1 of this Code. 
(Ord. of 6-9-03(2)) 
Sec. 74.1-242. - Names of streets. 
    Proposed streets obviously in alignment with other already existing and named streets shall bear the name of the existing streets. In no case shall the names of proposed streets duplicated existing street names irrespective of the use of the suffix street, avenue, boulevard, drive, way, place, lane or court. Street names shall be indicated on the preliminary and final plats and shall be approved by the agent. Names of existing streets shall not be changed except by approval of the council. 
(Ord. of 6-9-03(2)) 
Sec. 74.1-243. - Street identification signs. 
    Street identification signs of a design approved by the agent shall be installed at all intersections. 
(Ord. of 6-9-03(2)) 
Sec. 74.1-244. - Location of streets: concrete monuments and iron pins. 
    Concrete monuments or iron pins shall be set at all street corners; at all points where the street line intersects the exterior boundaries of the subdivision; and at right angle points, and points of curve in each street. The top of the monument shall have an appropriate mark to identify properly the location and shall be set flush with the finished grade. 
(Ord. of 6-9-03(2)) 
Sec. 74.1-245. - Landscaping. 
    All disturbed areas within the dedicated rights-of-way and easements shall be restored with acceptable vegetation compatible with the surrounding area. No street shall be accepted by the town where there is visual evidence of siltation unless appropriate protective measures in accordance with the town's construction practices have been taken. Any planting of trees and/or shrubs shall be in accordance with the state department of transportation, Environmental quality division's "Guide for Tree and Shrub Planting on Virginia's Streets and Highways." 
(Ord. of 6-9-03(2)) 
Sec. 74.1-246. - Utility easements. 
(a)  It is the policy of the town to require a clear and unencumbered dedication of rights-of-way on all additions to the system. Therefore, any easements or other interests within the platted right-of-way must be quitclaimed of any prior rights therein in exchange for a permit to occupy the space. All longitudinal underground utilities shall be located under the shoulder of the road insofar as practical. Town policy prohibits the open cutting of paved or surface-treated roads. Therefore, all lateral underground utilities to be installed prior to the acceptance of the street should be installed before the final surface application. 
(b)  The developer shall have underground service and it is the responsibility of the developer to assure that poles and street lights are installed, placed per the specifications of the town, coordinated with the electric utility company, and placed in compliance with all applicable safety standards regarding the distance of fixed objects from the edge of pavement. 
(Ord. of 6-9-03(2)) 
Secs. 74.1-247-74.1-299. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - SITE DEVELOPMENT PLANS 

Sec. 74.1-300. - Submission and approval of site development plan. 
    Three sets of blue or black line prints of plans and specifications for all required physical improvements to be installed shall be prepared by an engineer and shall be submitted to the agent who shall approve or disapprove such plans within 90 days. If approved, one copy bearing certification of such approval shall be returned to the subdivider. If disapproved, all papers shall be returned to the subdivider with the reason for disapproval in writing. 
(Ord. of 6-9-03(2)) 
Sec. 74.1-301. - Requirements of the site development plans. 
    Each site development plan shall contain the following information; provided, however, that in the case of a subdivision that involves no new construction of streets, sewer or water facilities, the agent may exempt a subdivider from such of these requirements as in his opinion serves the public interest. 
(1)  Plans and specifications generally. Site development plans for subdivisions shall consist of plans and specification of all proposed utilities, drainage, sanitary sewage disposal facilities, and streets. All drainage lines, sewer lines, and road plans shall be shown on standard plan and profile sheets with an overall dimension of 24 inches wide by 36 inches long. The site development plans shall contain sufficient details and data to enable the improvements to be constructed therefrom. In addition the site development plans shall show the following: 
a.  Name of subdivision. 
b.  Name of the applicant, owner, developer or subdivider. 
c.  Name of the person or firm who prepared the plan, date of drawing, north arrow, and scale. 
d.  Adjacent site data showing the present use of all contiguous or abutting properties, the location and width of existing or planned streets or roads around the perimeter of the subdivision, the size and location of existing or planned utilities at the perimeter, and similar development features at the perimeter. 
e.  Drainage and grading plan showing: 
1.  The proposed finish grade plan, supplemented by spot elevations; 
2.  Identification of drainage structures by type, size, and location, connections to existing drainage systems, and the contributing drainage area in acres for each subbasin; 
3.  Existing and proposed drainage easements, the direction of flow, dredging or relocation of drainage ways, storm sewers or drainage ways related to street construction; 
4.  Typical drainage section, proper driveway entrance; 
5.  Computed culvert size; and limits of flood plain, provision and schedule for the adequate control of erosion and sedimentation. 
f.  Grading plans. For each lot in the subdivision may be required prior to or at the time that application is made for a building permit. Grading plans will be required if there is a significant variation from the overall drainage plan which may impact neighboring properties or utilities. The grading plan for each site shall show the location of the proposed building, the existing and proposed elevations at building corners, lot corners, and the finished floor elevations of ground floors, and the proposed direction of flow of drainage swales indicated with arrows and spot elevations as needed on each lot. 
g.  Street profiles. Profiles along the centerline of each street, with established grades indicated thereon shall be prepared in accordance with standards of the state department of transportation for the class of road to be constructed. 
h.  Sewer profiles, when applicable. When a subdivision is to be served by sanitary sewers and/or storm sewers, the plans shall include profiles along the line of every sanitary or storm sewer line showing the percent of slope, invert elevations at all manholes, cleanouts, catch basins, inlets or other changes in line or grade. Such profiles shall show the proposed sewer grades, proposed street grades and the original ground profiles. 
i.  Erosion and sediment control. All subdivision plans shall include adequate provisions for control of temporary flooding or erosion and sediment control, both during construction and after completion of construction, in compliance with applicable ordinances. 
j.  Cover sheet. Where the site development plans require two or more sheets, a cover sheet shall be provided showing the entire subdivision with the names of the subdivision, the owner or developer, the professional engineer or certified land surveyor who prepared the plan and a location map. 
(2)  The site development plans shall be prepared by a professional civil engineer or certified land surveyor. 
(Ord. of 6-9-03(2)) 
Sec. 74.1-302. - Site plans prepared pursuant to zoning regulations. 
    Whenever a site plan for a planned residential development or other of development prepared pursuant to the zoning ordinance requires the establishment of features and/or facilities that are also covered by this chapter, applications requesting approval of such projects may be submitted and reviewed concurrently. Accordingly when such plans are approved as meeting the requirements of both zoning and subdivision regulations, in applicable cases, they may be considered as approved preliminary plats for purposes of meeting the regulations of this chapter. 
(Ord. of 6-9-03(2)) 
Secs. 74.1-303-74.1-349. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - ADMINISTRATION[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

Sec. 74.1-350. - Agent established. 
    The agent appointed by the council is delegated to administer this chapter. In so doing the agent shall be considered the agent of the council, and approval or disapproval by the agent shall constitute approval or disapproval as though it were given by the council. The agent shall also consult with the commission on matters contained in this chapter. 
(Ord. of 6-9-03(2)) 
Sec. 74.1-351. - Duties and authority of agent. 
    The agent shall perform his duties as regards subdivisions and subdividing in accordance with this chapter and the state land subdivision and development act. In the performance of his duties, the agent may call for opinions or decisions, either verbal or written, from other departments in considering details of any submitted plant. This authority by the agent shall have particular reference to the resident highway engineer and the health official, or other outside consultant. In addition to the regulations contained in this chapter for the platting of subdivisions, the agent may, from time to time, establish any reasonable additional administrative procedures deemed necessary for the proper administration of this chapter. 
(Ord. of 6-9-03(2)) 
Sec. 74.1-352. - Right of appeal. 
    If the agent fails to approve or disapprove the proposed plat within 60 days after it has been officially submitted for approval, the subdivider may, after ten days' written notice to the agent, petition the circuit court of the county to decide whether the plat should or should not be approved. The court shall hear the matter and enter such order with respect thereto as it deems proper. 
(Ord. of 6-9-03(2)) 
Sec. 74.1-353. - Penalties. 
    After the adoption of this chapter, the following provisions shall be effective within the territory to which this chapter applies: 
(1)  No person shall subdivide land without making and recording a plat of the subdivision and without fully complying with the provisions of this chapter. 
(2)  No plat of any subdivision shall be recorded unless and until it has been submitted to and approved by the duly authorized agent of the town council. 
(3)  No person shall sell or transfer any land of a subdivision, before a plat has been duly approved and recorded as provided herein, unless the subdivision was lawfully created prior to the adoption of a subdivision ordinance by the town, however, nothing herein contained shall be construed as preventing the recordation of the instruments by which such land is transferred or the passage of title as between the parties to the instrument. 
(4)  No clerk of any court shall file or record a plat of a subdivision required by this chapter to be recorded until the plat has been approved as required herein. The penalties provided by Code of Virginia, § 17-59, shall apply to any failure to comply with the provisions of this subsection. 
(5)  Any person who violates the foregoing provisions of this section shall be subject to a fine of not more than $500.00 for each lot or parcel of land so subdivided, transferred or sold. The description of the lot or parcel by metes and bounds in the instrument of transfer or other document used in the process of transferring shall not exempt the transaction from the penalties or remedies herein provided. 
(Ord. of 6-9-03(2)) 
Secs. 74.1-354-74.1-399. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - VACATION OF PLAT 

Sec. 74.1-400. - Vacation before the sale of a lot. 
    At any time prior to the sale of a lot within a subdivision, with the consent of the governing body the owners, proprietors and trustees, if any, who signed the statement of consent to the subdivision pursuant to Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2264 (see owners statement at subsection 74.1-31(c) of this chapter) may file a written instrument declaring the plat to be vacated, duly executed, acknowledged or proved and recorded in the same clerk's office wherein the plat to be vacated is recorded and the execution of the recordation of such writing shall operate to destroy the force and effect of the recording of the plat so vacated and to divest all public rights in, and to reinvest the owners, proprietors and trustees, if any, with the title to the streets, alleys, easements for public passage and other public areas laid out or described in the plat. 
(Ord. of 6-9-03(2)) 
Sec. 74.1-401. - Vacation of plat after sale of lot. 
    In cases where any lot has been sold, the plat or part thereof may be vacated by an instrument in writing agreeing to the vacation signed by all the owners of lots shown on the plat and also signed on behalf of the governing body of the locality in which the land shown on the plat or part thereof to be vacated lies for the purpose of showing the approval of the vacation by the governing body. In cases involving drainage easements or street rights-of-way where the vacation does not impede or alter drainage or access for any lot owners other than those lot owners immediately adjoining or contiguous to the vacated area, the governing body shall only be required to obtain the signatures of the lot owners immediately adjoining or contiguous to the vacated area. The word "owners" shall not include lien creditors except those whose debts are secured by a recorded deed of trust or mortgage and shall not include any consort of an owner. The instrument of vacation shall be acknowledged in the manner of a deed and filed for record in the clerk's office of the court in which the plat is recorded. 
(Ord. of 6-9-03(2)) 
Chapter 78 - TAXATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Ordinances providing for the levy of taxes saved from repeal, § 1-8(7); finance, § 2-311 et seq.; annual license taxes for alcoholic beverages, § 10-36 et seq.; license tax for coin-operated machines, § 14-61; businesses, ch. 26. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 78-1. - When and where taxes and levies due and payable; penalty for delinquent payment. 
    All town taxes and levies shall be due and payable annually at the town treasurer's office on January 5 of each year. On and after January 6 of each year, there shall be added to the taxes or levies due from each taxpayer a penalty of ten percent. 
(Code 1974, §§ 11-16, 11-17) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3515. 
Sec. 78-2. - Collection of delinquent town taxes. 
    Town taxes declared delinquent by the council shall be turned over to an attorney for collection. 
(Code 1974, § 11-19) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3919.1. 
Sec. 78-3. - Tax year and assessment date. 
    The town tax year shall begin on July 1 of each year and end on the following June 30 to correspond with the fiscal year. All taxable real estate, personal property, machinery and tools and other taxable property will be assessed as of July 1 of each year. 
(Ord. of 8-9-04) 
Secs. 78-4-78-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BANK FRANCHISE TAX[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Bank franchise tax, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-1210. 

Sec. 78-36. - Tax on stock when bank is located in town. 
    A tax of 80 percent of the state rate of taxation is hereby imposed on each $100.00 of the net capital as defined in Code of Virginia, § 58.1-1205, of any bank located within the corporate limits of the town. If any such bank has any offices located outside the corporate limits of the town, the tax imposed by this section shall be as provided in Code of Virginia, § 58.1-1211. 
(Code 1974, §§ 11-20, 11-21) 
Sec. 78-37. - Franchise tax levied. 
    Upon bank franchises there shall be a tax levy of $0.80 for every $100.00 of deposits. 
(Ord. of 6-21-04, § 1D; Ord. of 6-27-05, § 1D) 
Secs. 78-38-78-65. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - TAXATION OF UTILITY SERVICES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- An ordinance adopted Oct. 9, 2000, amended Art. III in its entirety, in effect repealing and reenacting said article to read as herein set out. The former Art. III, §§ 78-66-78-72, pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Code 1974, § 11-22. 
Cross reference- Utilities generally, ch. 86. 
State Law reference- Consumer utility tax, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3800 et seq. 

Sec. 78-66. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    CCF means the volume of gas at standard pressure and temperature in units of 100 cubic feet. 
    Consumer means every person who, individually or through agents, employees, officers, representatives, or permittees, makes a taxable purchase of local exchange telephone, electricity, or natural gas services within the corporate limits of the town. 
    Gas utility means a public utility authorized to furnish natural gas in Virginia. 
    Kilowatt hours (kWh) delivered means 1,000 watts of electricity delivered in a one-hour period by an electric provider to an actual consumer, except that in the case of eligible customer-generators (sometimes called co-generators) as defined in Code of Virginia, § 56-594, it means kWh supplied from the electric grid to such customer-generators, minus the kWh generated and fed back to the electric grid by such customer-generators. 
    Person means any individual, corporation, company, or other entity. 
    Pipeline distribution company means a person, other than a pipeline transmission company which transmits, by means of a pipeline, natural gas, manufactured gas or crude petroleum and the products or byproducts thereof to a purchaser for purposes of furnishing heat or light. 
    Purchaser means every person who purchases a utility service. 
    Residential customer means the owner or tenant of property used primarily for residential purposes, including but not limited to, separately metered apartment houses and other multiple-family dwellings. 
    Seller means every person, whether a public service corporation or not, who sells or furnishes a utility service, other than the municipal water service of the town. 
    Service provider means a person who delivers electricity to a consumer or a gas utility or pipeline distribution company which delivers natural gas to a consumer. 
    Used primarily relates to the larger portion of the use for which electric or natural gas utility service is furnished. 
(Ord. of 10-9-00) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 78-67. - Electric utility consumer tax. 
(a)  In accordance with Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3814, effective January 1, 2001, there is hereby imposed and levied a monthly tax on each purchase of electricity delivered to consumers by a service provider, classified as determined by such provider, as follows: 
(1)  Residential consumers: Such tax shall be $1.05 plus the rate of $0.011429 on each kWh delivered monthly to residential consumers by a service provider not to exceed $2.25 monthly. 
(2)  Nonresidential consumers: Such tax on nonresidential consumers shall be at the rates per month for the classes of nonresidential consumers as set forth below: 
a.  Commercial consumers: Such tax shall be $1.72 plus the rate of $0.010708 on each kWh delivered monthly to commercial consumers, not to exceed $15.00 monthly. 
b.  Industrial consumers: Such tax shall be $1.72 plus the rate of $0.010708 on each kWh delivered monthly to industrial consumers, not to exceed $15.00 monthly. 
(3)  The conversion of tax pursuant to this article to monthly kWh delivered shall not be effective before the first meter reading after December 31, 2000, prior to which time the tax previously imposed by this jurisdiction shall be in effect. 
(4)  There shall be no tax computed on bills submitted for electric service for heating water and space heating where a separate meter is used solely for water heating and space heating service or on bills submitted for unmetered electric service. 
(b)  Exemptions. The United States, the state, and the political subdivisions, boards, commissions and authorities thereof are exempted from the payment of the tax imposed and levied by this article with respect to the purchase of utility services used by such governmental agencies. 
(c)  Billing, collection, and remittance of tax. The service provider shall bill the electricity consumer tax to all users who are subject to the tax and to whom it delivers electricity and shall remit the same to this jurisdiction on a monthly basis. Such taxes shall be paid by the service provider to this jurisdiction in accordance with Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3814, paragraphs F. and G., and Code of Virginia, § 58.1-2901. If any consumer receives and pays for electricity but refuses to pay the tax imposed by this section, the service provider shall notify this jurisdiction of the name and address of such consumer. If any consumer fails to pay a bill issued by a service provider, including the tax imposed by this section, the service provider must follow its normal collection procedures and upon collection of the bill or any part thereof must apportion the net amount collected between the charge for electric service and the tax and remit the tax portion to the town. Any tax paid by the consumer to the service provider shall be deemed to be held in trust by such provider until remitted to the town. 
(d)  Computation of bills not on a monthly basis. Bills shall be considered as monthly bills for the purposes of this article if submitted 12 times per year of approximately one month each. 
Accordingly, the tax for a bimonthly bill (approximately 60 days) shall be determined as follows: (i) the kWh will be divided by two; (ii) a monthly tax will be calculated using the rates set forth above; (iii) the tax determined by (ii) shall be multiplied by two; (iv) the tax in (iii) may not exceed twice the monthly "maximum tax." 
(Ord. of 10-9-00) 
Sec. 78-68. - Natural gas utility consumer tax. 
(a)  In accordance with Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3814, there is hereby imposed and levied a monthly tax on each purchase of natural gas delivered to consumers by pipeline distribution companies and gas utilities classified by "class of consumers" as such term is defined in Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3814 J., as follows: 
(1)  Residential consumers: Such tax on residential consumers of natural gas shall be at the rate of $1.50 per month. 
(2)  Nonresidential consumers: Such tax on nonresidential consumers shall be at the rates per month shown for each CCF delivered by a pipeline distribution company or a gas utility for the classes as set forth below: 
a.  Commercial consumers: Such tax shall be $3.49 plus $0.065 on each CCF delivered monthly to commercial consumers, not to exceed $15.00 monthly. 
b.  Industrial consumers: Such tax shall be $3.49 plus $0.065 on each CCF delivered monthly to industrial consumers, not to exceed $15.00 monthly. 
(3)  The conversion of tax pursuant to this article to monthly CCF delivered shall not be effective before the first meter reading after December 31, 2000, prior to which time the tax previously imposed by this jurisdiction shall be in effect. 
(b)  Exemptions. The United States, the state, and the political subdivisions, boards, commissions and authorities thereof are exempted from the payment of the tax imposed and levied by this article with respect to the purchase of utility services used by such governmental agencies. 
(c)  Billing, collection, and remittance of tax. The service provider shall bill the electricity consumer tax to all users who are subject to the tax and to whom it delivers electricity and shall remit the same to this jurisdiction on a monthly basis. Such taxes shall be paid by the service provider to this jurisdiction in accordance with Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3814, paragraphs H. and I., and Code of Virginia, § 58.1-2901. If any consumer receives and pays for natural gas billed but refuses to pay the tax imposed by this section, the service provider shall notify this jurisdiction of the name and address of such consumer. If any consumer fails to pay a bill issued by a service provider, including the tax imposed by this section, the service provider must follow its normal collection procedures and upon collection of the bill or any part thereof must apportion the net amount collected between the charge for natural gas service and the tax and remit the tax portion to the town. Any tax paid by the consumer to the service provider shall be deemed to be held in trust by such provider until remitted to the town. 
(d)  Computation of bills not on a monthly basis. Bills shall be considered as monthly bills for the purposes of this article if submitted 12 times per year of approximately one month each. Accordingly, the tax for a bimonthly bill (approximately 60 days) shall be determined as follows: (i) the CCF will be divided by two; (ii) a monthly tax will be calculated using the rates set forth above; (iii) the tax determined by (ii) shall be multiplied by two; (iv) the tax in (iii) may not exceed twice the monthly "maximum tax." 
(Ord. of 10-9-00) 
Sec. 78-69. - Records. 
    Each seller shall keep complete records showing all purchases in the town, which records shall show the price charged against each purchaser with respect to each purchase, the date thereof, and the date of payment thereof, and the amount of tax imposed under this article; and such record shall be kept open for inspection by the duly authorized agents of the town at reasonable times, and the duly authorized agents of the town shall have the right, power, and authority to make such transcripts thereof during such times as they may desire. 
(Ord. of 10-9-00) 
Sec. 78-70. - Telephone service utility consumer tax. 
(a)  There is imposed and levied by the town upon each purchaser of local exchange telephone service a tax in the amount of 15 percent of the charge, exclusive of any federal tax thereon, made by the seller against the purchaser with respect to local exchange telephone service, which tax in every case shall be collected by the seller from the purchaser and shall be paid by the purchaser unto the seller for the use of the town at the time the purchase price or such charge shall become due and payable under the agreement between the purchaser and the seller. 
(b)  The tax imposed and levied by this article on purchasers with respect to local exchange telephone service shall apply to all charges made for local exchange telephone service, except local messages which are paid for by inserting coins in coin-operated telephones. 
(c)  If any monthly bill submitted exceeds $100.00 per month, there shall be no tax computed on so much of the bill as shall exceed $100.00. 
(d)  Under the provisions and definitions of Code of Virginia, 58.1-3812, there is also imposed and levied on each purchaser of mobile local telecommunications service, a tax of ten percent of the taxable monthly charge for such services, provided, however, that the tax shall not be applicable to any amount in excess of $30.00. The service provider of local telecommunications services shall collect the tax monthly from consumers by adding the tax to the monthly gross charge for such services. The tax shall be stated as a distinct item separate and apart from the monthly gross charge. Each service provider shall remit monthly to the town the amount of tax billed during the preceding month to consumers with a service address within town limits. 
(Ord. of 10-9-00; Ord. of 6-18-01) 
Sec. 78-71. - Penalty for failure to pay. 
    Any consumer of telephone, electricity or natural gas failing, refusing, or neglecting to pay the tax imposed and levied under this article, and any officer, agent, or employee of any service provider violating the provisions of this article shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished by a fine of not more than $100.00, or by imprisonment in jail for not more than 30 days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. Each such failure, refusal, neglect or violation shall constitute a separate offense. Such conviction shall not relieve any person from the payment, collection and remittance of the tax as provided in this article. 
(Ord. of 10-9-00) 
Sec. 78-72. - Local telecom consumer utility tax. 
    There shall be levied upon every local telecom consumer a utility tax of ten percent up to $3.00 maximum per month. 
(Ord. of 6-16-03, § 1D; Ord. of 6-21-04, § 1E; Ord. of 6-27-05, § 1E) 
Secs. 78-73-78-105. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - BUSINESS, PROFESSIONAL, OCCUPATIONAL LICENSE 

Sec. 78-106. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Affiliated group means: 
(1)  One or more chains of includable corporations connected through stock ownership with a common parent corporation that is an includable corporation if: 
a.  Stock possessing at least 80 percent of the voting power of all classes of stock and at least 80 percent of each class of the nonvoting stock of each of the includable corporations, except the common parent corporation, is owned directly by one or more of the other includable corporations; and 
b.  The common parent corporation directly owns stock possessing at least 80 percent of the voting power of all classes of stock and at least 80 percent of each class of the nonvoting stock of at least one of the other includable corporations. 
As used in this subsection, the term "stock" does not include nonvoting stock that is limited and preferred as to dividends. The term "includable corporation" means any corporation within the affiliated group irrespective of the state or country of its incorporation; and the term "receipts" includes gross receipts and gross income. 
(2)  Two or more corporations if five or fewer persons who are individuals, estates or trusts own stock possessing: 
a.  At least 80 percent of the total combined voting power of all classes of stock entitled to vote or at least 80 percent of the total value of shares of all classes of the stock of each corporation; and 
b.  More than 50 percent of the total combined voting power of all classes of stock entitled to vote or more than 50 percent of the total value of shares of all classes of stock of each corporation, taking into account the stock ownership of each such person only to the extent such stock ownership, is identical with respect to each such corporation. 
When one or more of the includable corporations, including the common parent corporation, is a nonstock corporation, the term "stock" as used in this subsection shall refer to the nonstock corporation membership or membership voting rights, as is appropriate to the context. 
    Assessment means a determination as to the proper rate of tax, the measure to which the tax rate is applied, and ultimately the amount of tax, including additional or omitted tax, that is due. An assessment shall include a written assessment made pursuant to notice by the assessing official or a self-assessment made by a taxpayer upon the filing of a return or otherwise not pursuant to notice. Assessments shall be deemed made by an assessing official when a written notice of assessment is delivered to the taxpayer by the assessing official or an employee of the assessing official, or mailed to the taxpayer at his last known address. Self-assessments shall be deemed made when a return is filed, or if no return is required, when the tax is paid. A return filed or tax paid before the last day prescribed by ordinance for the filing or payment thereof shall be deemed to be filed or paid on the last day specified for the filing of a return or the payment of tax, as the case may be. 
    Assessor or assessing official means the town treasurer. 
    Base year means the calendar year preceding the license year, except for contractors subject to the provisions of Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3715. 
    Business means a course of dealing that requires the time, attention and labor of the person so engaged for the purpose of earning a livelihood or profit. It implies a continuous and regular course of dealing, rather than an irregular or isolated transaction. A person may be engaged in more than one business. The following acts shall create a rebuttable presumption that a person is engaged in a business:
