If the town agents or employees remove any such motor vehicles, trailers or semitrailers, after having given such reasonable notice, the town may dispose of such motor vehicles, trailers or semitrailers after giving additional notice to the owner of the vehicle. The cost of any such removal and disposal shall be chargeable to the owner of the vehicle or premises and may be collected by the town as taxes and levies are collected. Every cost authorized by this section with which the owner of the premises has been assessed shall constitute a lien against the property from which the vehicle was removed, the lien to continue until actual payment of such costs has been made to the town. 
(Mo. of 10-8-90; Ord. No. 2018-8, 9-10-18) 
Cross reference- Environment, ch. 42. 
State Law reference- Authority to restrict keeping of inoperative motor vehicles, etc., on residential, or commercial property; removal of such vehicles; penalty, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-904. 
Chapter 86 - UTILITIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; buildings and building regulations, ch. 22; businesses, ch. 26; environment, ch. 42; offenses relating to utilities, § 50-266 et seq.; obtaining or attempting to obtain oil, electric, gas, water, telephone, telegraph or cable television services without payment, § 50-310; planning, ch. 58; solid waste, ch. 66; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 70; digging in street incident to water supply or sewer system, § 70-34; subdivisions, ch. 74.1; taxation of utility services, § 78-66 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 86-1. - Building permit required prior to connection. 
    Every applicant for water and sewer connection shall purchase a building permit if this has not been done previously in the treasurer's office. 
(Code 1974, § 31-1) 
Cross reference- Building permits, § 22-71 et seq. 
Secs. 86-2-86-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - WATER 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 86-31. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Cross connection means any physical connection of any other water system with the town water supply system in such a manner that a flow of water directly into the town supply is possible therefrom through the manipulation of valves, or because of ineffective check or back pressure valves or otherwise. 
    Improved street means any street having a wearing surface of concrete, asphalt, brick, stone, block, tar treatment or similar hard material. 
    Service connection means the pipe from the water main to the property line of the consumer and including the cutoff device at the main, the connecting pipe and the complete meter setting, with provision for the consumer to connect thereto. 
    Superintendent means the director of public works of the town, or his duly authorized deputy, agent or representative. 
    Unimproved street means any street having dirt or crushed stone surface. 
    Water consumer means any person contracting with the town for the use of water. 
    Water main means the pipe laid in the street, alley or other public place or in any easement, through which the supply of water is conducted, including all valves and appurtenances. 
    Waterworks system means all facilities for the production, treatment and distribution of water for all purposes. 
(Code 1974, § 31-2) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 86-32. - Powers and duties of superintendent. 
    The superintendent shall, subject to the direction of the council, have active charge and control of the operation, maintenance and construction of the entire town water supply system, including the sale and distribution of water. In addition to the aforesaid general powers and duties, the superintendent shall have the following specific powers and duties: 
(1)  The superintendent shall at all times preserve and be responsible for all equipment, machinery, tools and materials belonging to the town and used in the water department. It shall be his duty at all times to keep himself and the council informed as to the conditions of such machinery, equipment and property. 
(2)  The superintendent shall submit to the water and sewer committee of the council by March 1 of each year a budget of estimated receipts and expenditures of the water department for the next fiscal year. 
(3)  The superintendent shall immediately report in writing to the town treasurer any changes in regard to the installation, removal or reading of water meters or any other information necessary to keep proper and accurate records of a water consumer's account. 
(4)  The superintendent shall have right of access to all premises for the purpose of enforcement of this article. 
(5)  The superintendent shall do and perform such other duties pertaining to the water system as may be assigned to him from time to time by the council. 
(Code 1974, § 31-3) 
Sec. 86-33. - Prerequisites for water service. 
    No water shall be turned on or furnished to premises unless an application for such service is made to the town. A tenant shall be required to make, in addition, the required deposit as set forth in this article. 
(Code 1974, § 31-4) 
Sec. 86-34. - Separate connections required. 
    Every house or building abutting any water main and requiring a water connection shall be separately and independently connected. 
(Code 1974, § 31-5) 
Sec. 86-35. - Unauthorized connections. 
    No unauthorized person shall uncover, make any connections with, or disturb in any way any portion of the waterworks system or appurtenances thereto without first obtaining written permission from the superintendent. 
(Code 1974, § 31-6) 
Sec. 86-36. - Unauthorized use. 
    If any person not acting under the authority of the water department shall turn the water on to any premises, or if any person shall take, receive or use water before first having made proper application for the same and having been granted such service by the water department, he shall, upon conviction, be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor subject to the penalties prescribed by section 1-15. Water shall not be turned on to any premises except by an authorized agent of the water department. 
(Code 1974, § 31-7) 
Sec. 86-37. - Water main extensions generally. 
(a)  Water main extensions from existing water mains within the town shall be made by the town on the availability of funds. The town will at its cost extend water mains a maximum of 75 feet. Extensions in excess of 75 feet, the excess above 75 feet, shall be borne by the applicant. The applicant shall reimburse the town for the costs incurred by the town for excess footage over 75 feet. The size of line installed shall be subject to the recommendation of the superintendent and approval by the council. The applicant agrees in making the extension that he will connect to the water line and use the service within six months of completion, and on failure to so do the applicant agrees to reimburse the town for the entire cost of making the water line extension. 
(b)  On proper application and payment of service connection fees prescribed in this article, the town shall install the service pipe and meter as set forth in section 86-83. 
(c)  All water mains laid shall revert to the town on completion. 
(Code 1974, § 31-9) 
Sec. 86-38. - Repair and renewal of water connections. 
(a)  For the purposes of this section, the word "connection" shall be construed to be that portion of water pipe between the main and the property line. 
(b)  Water connections shall be kept in repair by the town and at the expense of the town. Necessary renewals of water connections shall be made by the town. 
(Code 1974, § 31-17) 
Sec. 86-39. - Repair of meters generally. 
    Except as otherwise provided by section 86-40, all meters shall be kept in good repair and working order by the town and at the expense of the town. 
(Code 1974, § 31-18) 
Sec. 86-40. - Meter damage caused by hot water. 
(a)  If, on the removing of any meter for repairs, it is found that such meter has, in the judgment of the superintendent, been damaged by the passage of hot water through it, the cost of the necessary repairs to such meter shall be added to the water bill of the consumer and shall be treated as part of the water bill. 
(b)  If in any particular case it is evident to the superintendent that such damage will frequently recur, the consumer shall be required to install a check valve or other suitable means of protecting the meter as the superintendent may direct within ten days after receiving written notice from the superintendent to do so. On failure to comply with such notice the water shall be cut off from such premises. 
(Code 1974, § 31-19) 
Sec. 86-41. - Use of stopcocks; injuring meter generally. 
(a)  Stopcocks placed within meter boxes or cutoff boxes shall be for the exclusive use of the town. No person, except an official or duly authorized employee of the town, shall cause any such stopcock to be turned on or off. 
(b)  No person shall injure or tamper with any water meter, nor shall any person construct or have constructed any bypass around any water meter, except such as may be installed, approved and sealed by the water department. 
(Code 1974, § 31-20) 
Sec. 86-42. - Wasting water-Generally. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner or occupant of any premises having thereon hose bibbs or other fixtures for supplying water to permit water to run carelessly or in a wasteful manner. Service may be discontinued for violation of this section. 
(Code 1974, § 31-21) 
Sec. 86-43. - Same-Failure to repair leak. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner or occupant of any premises whereon is located a hose bibb, spigot or other water fixture in a leaking condition to fail, neglect or refuse to cause the same to be repaired immediately upon discovery; and if such fixture is not repaired, service may be discontinued. 
(Code 1974, § 31-22) 
Sec. 86-44. - Temporary service. 
    Temporary water service may be supplied by the town, upon proper application to the superintendent. Such water shall be supplied through a meter at the regular rates, and the applicant shall pay for the installation and removal of the meter. Before such temporary installation is made the applicant shall make a deposit, the amount of which is on file in the town clerk's office, out of which any unpaid balance due the town shall be taken. 
(Code 1974, § 31-23) 
Sec. 86-45. - Water for automatic fire suppression sprinkler systems. 
    Water will be furnished for automatic fire suppression sprinkler systems free; provided that in any case where there is a diversion of water furnished free for any such system, such free service shall be immediately discontinued and thereafter water shall be supplied for such system only through a meter and at the rates prescribed by council, on file in the town clerk's office. Application for any such water supply shall be made in writing, in which application shall be set out all such information as may be necessary for the purpose of determining the location, size and character of the sprinkler system. 
(Code 1974, § 31-24) 
Sec. 86-46. - Pollution of water supply. 
    No person shall contaminate any portion of the town's water supply, whether the same is in reservoir, tank or pipes. No person shall wade, bathe or fish in any water reservoir belonging to the town. 
(Code 1974, § 31-25) 
Cross reference- Environment, ch. 42. 
Sec. 86-47. - Liability of town. 
    The town does not guarantee the quality, quantity or pressure of its water supply. It is hereby made a portion of the terms on which the town furnishes water to consumers that the town shall in no case be liable to any consumer for any defect in quality or any deficiency in quantity or pressure; that the town shall not be liable to any consumer for damages resulting from the complete or partial cutting off of water; and that no deduction shall be made from any water bill by reason of any defect or deficiency. In every case where practicable, ample notice, by the best available means, shall be given when the water is to be cut off from any portion of the town. 
(Code 1974, § 31-26) 
Sec. 86-48. - Subdivision water extension policy. 
(a)  Where any tract of land is subdivided so that there will be two or more lots, it shall be regarded as a subdivision, whether newly created or existing. 
(b)  Water lines may be extended; provided, that the subdivider or developer will bear the full cost of such water lines. The town shall have the right to prescribe the size of the mains and appurtenances. All materials used shall be approved by the town. A six-inch main shall be considered standard and will be used as a basis for computing the estimated cost. The town also has the right to prescribe where such lines shall be installed and where connections to existing mains shall be made. The subdivider or developer will be required to install such mains the full distance of the subdivision unless the subdivider or developer obtains permission to do otherwise. The subdivider or developer must provide standard fire hydrants at points designated by the town manager. 
(c)  Persons desiring water extensions shall apply for such at the town office on forms furnished by the town. The subdivider or developer shall also furnish a plat of such property and give any easements needed. 
(d)  The policy set forth in this section in no way binds the council with respect to such water extensions as it may determine to be in the best interest of the town. 
(Code 1974, § 31-27) 
Cross reference- Subdivisions generally, ch. 74.1. 
Sec. 86-49. - Effect of article. 
    All pertinent provisions of this article are hereby made a part of the terms and conditions whereby the town furnishes water service to any person, or whereby the town makes any water connection or performs any work of any kind in connection with the furnishing of water service. 
(Code 1974, § 31-28) 
Sec. 86-50. - Rates to be uniform; exceptions. 
    The rates for water service to all consumers within the town shall be equal and uniform, the community swimming pools excepted. The council may through contractual arrangements supply water to consumers outside of the town under terms and conditions prescribed by the council. 
(Code 1974, § 31-29) 
Sec. 86-51. - Metered rates. 
    Water shall be furnished to consumers at metered rates only. 
(Code 1974, § 31-30) 
Sec. 86-52. - When meters to be read. 
    Meters shall be read monthly, and as far as practical shall be read on the same day of each month. 
(Code 1974, § 31-31) 
Sec. 86-53. - Schedule of rates. 
    Monthly consumption of water shall be paid for at rates on file in the town clerk's office. 
(Code 1974, § 31-32) 
Sec. 86-54. - Deposits; cut-on fee. 
(a)  When any tenant of any premises makes application for water to be furnished such premises, he shall be required to make a deposit to guarantee the payment of his water bill and pay a cut-on fee before water service will be initiated. If at the expiration of the time limited by this article for the payment of any such bill for any month, the tenant has failed to pay his water bill due for such month, such portion of such deposit as may be necessary shall be applied to the payment of such water bill. Thereupon, water service shall be scheduled for termination at such premises and shall not be continued or restored until the balance of such deposit is increased to the original amount thereof, and all penalties for delinquent payment are paid. When such tenant has the water finally cut off, he shall, upon payment of all water bills due, be entitled to the return of his deposit, or any balance thereof; provided, that if such tenant vacates the premises without notifying the water department and having the water cut off, he shall forfeit any balance therefrom. 
(b)  The amount of such required deposits and the cut-on fee shall be as follows: 
(1)  Residential customers: 
a.  In town ..... $100.00 
b.  Out of town ..... 150.00 
(2)  Commercial and industrial customers: 
a.  Consumption in excess of 20,000 gallons ..... $150.00 
b.  Consumption in excess of 40,000 gallons ..... 300.00 
c.  Consumption in excess of 100,000 gallons ..... 400.00 
(3)  Cut-on fee for all customers is $40.00 
(Code 1974, § 31-35; Ord. of 8-8-05(2); Ord. No. 2010-10, 11-8-10) 
Sec. 86-55. - Water bills generally; procedure when meter defective. 
    Bills for water shall be based on the actual reading of amounts of water used; except that when the amount of water used is not registered because of a defective meter, the bill thus rendered shall be for the average amount theretofore used by the premises served by such meter during the preceding six months, or if water was not consumed by such premises through such meter during such preceding six-month period, the bill rendered shall be for the average amount for other services of same class in the town during the period covered by the bill. Bills shall be rendered separately for each meter or connection. All bills shall be made out and mailed as early as practicable after the close of the month covered by such bills. 
(Code 1974, § 31-36) 
Sec. 86-56. - Date of bills; penalties for delinquent payment; effect of nonpayment of bill or penalties. 
(a)  Water service shall be billed as of the last day of each monthly billing period with a penalty as on file in the town clerk's office to be added on the 22 nd day of the month in which the billing is made. If any such bill is not paid by the tenth day of the following month by 5:00 p.m., an additional penalty as on file in the town clerk's office shall be added and water service shall be scheduled for termination on the following work day. 
(b)  If any payment is made via the U.S. Postal Service and postmarked after the 21 st , the penalty shall be included on the next bill. 
(c)  After water service has been scheduled for termination as provided in subsection (a) above, it shall not be continued or restored until all past due water bills for the premises are paid together with all penalties due. 
(d)  Should the 22 nd or tenth day of a month fall on a weekend or legal holiday, the effective date of penalties shall be the first business day thereafter. 
(Code 1974, § 31-37; Ord. of 8-8-05(2); Ord. of 6-11-07) 
Sec. 86-57. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- An ordinance adopted Aug. 8, 2005(2), repealed § 86-57 in its entirety. Former § 86-57 pertained to the cut-on fee and derived from Code 1974, § 31-38. 
Sec. 86-58. - Correction and adjustment of bills. 
    The superintendent shall investigate all claims of disputed amounts or over charges and shall have full authority to make such corrections and adjustments of incorrect bills as the facts may warrant; provided, that no deductions shall be made in water bills on account of waste caused by defective plumbing fixtures or pipes on the consumer's premises. 
(Code 1974, § 31-39) 
Sec. 86-59. - Permitted margin of error for meters. 
    Since the most accurate water meters suitable for general use require a margin of approximately 21/2 percent for error, any meter which shows upon test an error not greater than 21/2 percent shall not be considered defective. 
(Code 1974, § 31-40) 
Sec. 86-60. - Liability for payment for unauthorized use of water. 
    The fact that water is cut on to any premises by any tenant thereof without the prior knowledge of either the town or the owner shall not have the effect of relieving the owner of such premises of liability for payment of such unauthorized use of water. 
(Code 1974, § 31-41) 
Secs. 86-61-86-80. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - SERVICE CONNECTIONS 

Sec. 86-81. - Required; exception. 
    Within 30 days after the time when any water main on any street is completed and ready for use, the owner of every abutting lot, whereon water is supplied for any human use, shall cause such lot to be connected with such water main. 
(Code 1974, § 31-10) 
Sec. 86-82. - Application generally. 
    Each person desiring water service shall make application on a form furnished by the town. Such application shall be accompanied by a fee on file in the town clerk's office and when properly executed by the applicant and the town shall constitute the contract under which water shall be secured. 
(Code 1974, § 31-11) 
Sec. 86-83. - Contents of application. 
    Every application for a water service connection shall state the name of the owner of the lot; the name of the street on which such lot is situated; the number of the house, if there is one on the lot, or if not, a description of the location of the lot; the number and size of connections desired; the purpose for which the water will be used; and the character of the surface of the abutting street. Every such application shall be signed by the person making the application. 
(Code 1974, § 31-12) 
Sec. 86-84. - Work to be done by town. 
(a)  Upon approval of any application for water service connection, the town shall do the excavating, lay the pipe, install a meter and box, make the connection to the main, fill the excavation and replace the surface of the street. 
(b)  The town will install the service line from the main to the property line, including meter and control devices, with proper fitting for the water consumer to make his connection. 
(Code 1974, § 31-13) 
Sec. 86-85. - Work to be done by consumer. 
    The water consumer shall construct at his own cost and expense the water service line from the point as stated in section 86-84 to the actual point of usage. 
(Code 1974, § 31-14) 
Sec. 86-86. - Fees. 
(a)  Fees for service connections to the town's water supply system shall be on file in the town clerk's office. 
(b)  In any case, where there is desired a larger connection than any for which a fee is required, the same will be made, if the application therefor is approved, at cost, in which cost shall be included in addition to the cost of labor and materials, the cost of the necessary meter and box. 
(Code 1974, § 31-15) 
Sec. 86-87. - Meters to be property of town. 
    All meters, meter boxes, pipes and other equipment furnished and used by the town in installing any water connection shall be and remain the property of the town. 
(Code 1974, § 31-16) 
Secs. 86-88-86-110. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - CONSERVATION OF WATER DURING EMERGENCIES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Water supply emergencies, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-37.3:4. 

Sec. 86-111. - Use during emergencies. 
    If the council at any time declares there is an emergency existing in the town arising, either wholly or substantially, out of a shortage of water supply, the town manager or the director of public works is hereby authorized to order the restriction or prohibition of any or all of the following uses of public water supply: 
(1)  Watering of shrubbery, trees, lawns, grass, plants or other vegetation. 
(2)  Washing of automobiles, trucks, trailers or any other type of mobile equipment, except in facilities operating with a water recycling system approved by the town; provided, further, that any facility operating with an approved water recycling system must prominently display, in public view, a sign stating that such a recycling system is in operation. 
(3)  Washing of sidewalks, streets, driveways, parking areas, service station aprons, exteriors of homes, apartments, commercial or industrial or any other outdoor surface. 
(4)  The operation of any ornamental fountain or other structure making a similar use of water. 
(5)  The filling of swimming or wading pools or the refilling of swimming or wading pools which were drained after the effective date of the order. 
(6)  The use of water from hydrants for any purpose other than necessary governmental operations. 
(7)  The serving of drinking water in restaurants, cafeterias or any other establishment, unless requested to do so by the individual being served. 
(Ord. of 12-1-86) 
Sec. 86-112. - Restriction to industrial, commercial activities. 
    If the measures taken pursuant to section 86-111 prove insufficient to preserve sufficient supplies of water for the citizens of the town, the town manager or director of public works is hereby further authorized to restrict or discontinue the supply of water to any industrial or commercial activity that uses water beyond the sanitary and drinking needs of its employees and invitees. 
(Ord. of 12-1-86) 
Sec. 86-113. - Violation, penalty. 
    Any person violating any provision of this division or any order of the town manager or director of public works issued pursuant to the authority granted hereunder shall be guilty of a class 3 misdemeanor, punishable as provided in section 1-15. In addition, the town manager or director of public works is hereby authorized to terminate the water services, for the duration of the emergency, to any person convicted of such violation. 
(Ord. of 12-1-86) 
DIVISION 4. - IRRIGATION SYSTEMS 

Sec. 86-114. - Construction. 
    No irrigation systems shall be constructed or reconstructed within the town limits without first obtaining approval from the building official. Any proposed irrigation systems will be shown on a detailed drawing and submitted to the building official for approval prior to beginning construction or reconstruction. 
(Ord. of 3-11-02) 
Sec. 86-115. - Construction on public right-of-way forbidden. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person or persons to construct an irrigation system on any public right-of-way. 
(Ord. of 3-11-02) 
Sec. 86-116. - Conflict with existing utilities. 
    Any irrigation systems constructed within the public right-of-way prior to the adoption of this division will be the responsibility of the property owner. Any damage to such irrigation system due to construction, installation, or maintenance of any adjacent utility or street or roadway of any kind within the public right-of-way will not be the responsibility of the town. 
(Ord. of 3-11-02) 
Sec. 86-117. - Persons constructing irrigation systems contrary to law. 
    Any person constructing an irrigation system within a public right-of-way in a manner not permitted to the general public, and without having obtained the consent of the town, shall be guilty of a Class 4 misdemeanor. Each day's continuance shall be a separate offense, and shall be deemed a nuisance. The court trying the case may cause the nuisance to be abated and may assess such fines and penalties as it may deem appropriate. 
(Ord. of 3-11-02) 
DIVISION 5. - DROUGHT RESPONSE 

Sec. 86-118. - Short title. 
    This division shall be known and may be cited as the Lake Country Regional Drought Response Ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 2011-2, 6-13-11) 
Sec. 86-119. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this division is to provide for the voluntary and mandatory restriction of use of the Roanoke River Service Authority public water supply system during declared water shortages or water emergencies. 
(Ord. No. 2011-2, 6-13-11) 
Sec. 86-120. - Scope. 
    This division shall apply to all Town of South Hill residents and businesses, which are served by the public water system. 
(Ord. No. 2011-2, 6-13-11) 
Sec. 86-121. - Drought response plan. 
    The town council shall adopt by resolution the Lake Country Regional Water Supply Plan, which includes the Lake Country Regional Drought Response and Contingency Plan. 
(Ord. No. 2011-2, 6-13-11) 
Sec. 86-122. - Drought indicators. 
    Upon determination that drought indicator(s) exceed the threshold of a drought stage, as set forth in Lake Country Regional Drought Response and Contingency Plan as outlined in Chapter 7 and Section B and Section C of the Lake Country Regional Water Supply Plan, the council may declare a specific drought stage. 
(Ord. No. 2011-2, 6-13-11) 
Sec. 86-123. - Drought stages. 
    The drought stages shall be drought watch, drought warning, and drought emergency, as determined by the council, pursuant to the Lake Country Regional Drought Response and Contingency Plan and state water control board regulation 9 VAC 25-120. 
(Ord. No. 2011-2, 6-13-11) 
Sec. 86-124. - Declaration. 
    Upon notification to the council that a drought stage exists, the council may issue a declaration of a drought stage. The town may declare a drought stage in the absence of a declaration by the Commonwealth of Virginia. 
(Ord. No. 2011-2, 6-13-11) 
Sec. 86-125. - Drought stage responses. 
    Upon declaration by the council of a drought watch or drought warning, voluntary conservation measurers will be requested of residents and businesses as set forth in the Lake Country Regional Drought Response and Contingency Plan. Upon declaration of a drought emergency, mandatory restrictions shall apply as set forth in the plan. 
(Ord. No. 2011-2, 6-13-11) 
Sec. 86-126. - Waiver of restrictions. 
    Upon prior written request by an individual, business, or other water user, the council, or its designee, may permit less than full compliance with any drought restrictions if good cause can be shown, including evidence that the applicant is affected in a substantial manner not common to other businesses or persons generally. No waiver shall be granted by the council or its designee unless the council or its designee determines that the public health, safety, and welfare will not be adversely affected by the waiver. All waivers granted by the council of its designee shall be reported at the council's next regular or special meeting. 
(Ord. No. 2011-2, 6-13-11) 
Sec. 86-127. - Penalties. 
    Any violation of this division shall constitute a misdemeanor, punishable by a fine of not less than $100.00 and not more than $500.00. Each act or each day's continuation of the violation shall be considered a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 2011-2, 6-13-11) 
Secs. 86-128-86-145. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SEWERS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 86-146. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    BOD (denoting biochemical oxygen demand) means the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure in five days of 20 degrees Celsius, expressed in parts per million by weight. 
    Garbage means solid wastes from the preparation, cooking and dispensing of food, and from the handling, storage and sale of produce. 
    House drain means that part of the lowest horizontal piping of a drainage system that receives the discharge from soil, waste and other drainage pipes inside the walls of the building and conveys it to the house sewer, beginning five feet outside the inner face of the building wall. 
    House sewer means the extension from the house drain to the public sewer or other place of disposal. 
    Industrial wastes means the liquid wastes from industrial processes as distinct from sanitary sewage. 
    Natural outlet means any outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake or other body of surface water or groundwater. 
    Normal domestic sewage means sewage for the town in which concentration of suspended materials and five day 20 degrees Celsius BOD is established at 240 parts per million each, by weight, on the basis of the normal daily contribution of 0.20 pound per capita, per 100 gallons. 
    pH means the logarithm of the reciprocal of the weight of hydrogen ions in grams per liter of solution. 
    Properly shredded garbage means the wastes from the preparation, cooking, and dispensing of food that has been shredded to such a degree that all particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public sewers, with no particle greater than one-half inch in any dimension. 
    Public sewer means a sewer receiving sewage. 
    Sanitary sewer means a sewer which carries sewage and to which stormwaters, surface waters and groundwaters are not intentionally admitted. 
    Sewage means water-carried wastes from residences, business buildings, institutions, and industrial establishments. 
    Sewage treatment works means any arrangement of devices and structures used for treating sewage. 
    Sewage works means all facilities for collecting, pumping, treating and disposing of sewage. 
    Sewer means a pipe or conduit for carrying sewage. 
    Storm sewer or storm drain means a sewer which carries stormwaters and surface waters and drainage, but excludes sewage and polluted industrial waters. 
    Superintendent means the town manager or his authorized deputy, agent or representative. 
    Surcharge means the charge in addition to the published water and sewer rates. The basis for surcharges on industrial wastes is a capital and operating cost for suspended solids, BOD and chlorine demand exceeding normal domestic sewage. 
    Suspended solids means solids that either float on the surface of or are in suspension in water, sewage or other liquids; and which are removable by laboratory filtering. 
    Watercourse means a channel in which a flow of water occurs, either continuously or intermittently. 
(Code 1974, § 26-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 86-147. - Disposal of human or animal excrement, garbage or other objectionable waste. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place, deposit or permit to be deposited in any insanitary manner upon public or private property within the town or in any area under the jurisdiction of the town, any human or animal excrement, garbage or other objectionable waste. 
(Code 1974, § 26-2) 
Cross reference- Animals generally, ch. 18; solid waste generally, ch. 66. 
Sec. 86-148. - Discharge of sanitary sewage, industrial wastes or polluted waters. 
    It shall be unlawful to discharge to any natural outlet within the town or in any area under the jurisdiction of the town any sanitary sewage, industrial wastes or other polluted waters except where suitable treatment has been provided in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1974, § 26-3) 
Sec. 86-149. - Duty of owner to connect to town sewer. 
    The owner of all houses, buildings or properties used for human occupancy, employment, recreation or other purpose, situated within the town and abutting on any street, alley or right-of-way in which there is located a public sanitary or combined sewer of the town is hereby required at his expense to install suitable toilet facilities therein, and to connect such facilities directly with the proper public sewer in accordance with the provisions of this article, within 90 days after date of official notice to do so, provided the public sewer is within 200 feet of the property line. 
(Code 1974, § 26-5) 
Secs. 86-150-86-170. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ENFORCEMENT 

Sec. 86-171. - Right of entry. 
    The superintendent and other duly authorized employees of the town bearing proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter upon all properties for the purposes of inspection, observation, measurement, sampling and testing, in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1974, § 26-39) 
Sec. 86-172. - Notice of violations and corrections thereof. 
    Any person found to be violating any provision of this article shall be served by the town with written notice stating the nature of the violation and providing a reasonable time limit for the satisfactory correction thereof. The offender shall, within the period of time stated in such notice, permanently cease all violations. 
(Code 1974, § 26-40) 
Sec. 86-173. - Surcharge for discharge of substandard industrial waste. 
    Any person who discharges industrial wastes requiring pretreatment under the terms of this article, without pretreating to conform to standards established in this article, shall be charged a surcharge over and above the published water and sewer rates. The basis for surcharge on industrial wastes is a capital and operating cost of $.14 per pound for the BOD and a capital and operating cost of $.14 per pound for the suspended solids exceeding normal domestic sewage. For purposes of this section, the level of BOD for normal domestic sewage is 240 mg/l and the normal level of suspended solids for domestic sewage is 240 mg/l. These rates shall continue until changed by action of the council. The surcharge in dollars shall be calculated for billing purposes with the following formula: 
    Surcharge for BOD = V X (B-C) X 8.34 X .14 
    Surcharge for SS = V X (B-C) X 8.34 X .14 
    Surcharge = Surcharge for BOD + Surcharge for SS. 
    B = Total contribution from user in mg/l. 
    C = Normal domestic sewage strength of 240 mg/l. 
    8.34 = pounds per gallon (conversion) 
    V = Volume per million gallons based on metered process water, as determined by the town. 
    BOD = BOD, five-day at 20° Celsius, of industrial waste (ppm). 
    SS = Suspended solids (ppm) 
(Code 1974, § 26-40.1; Ord. of 5-8-06(1); Ord. of 10-10-06) 
Sec. 86-174. - Discontinuance of service upon noncompliance. 
    Any person who refuses to comply with or who resists or willfully discharges wastes prohibited from discharge into public sewers or who refuses to comply with the provisions of this section shall be served by the superintendent with a written notice stating the nature of the violation and providing a reasonable time limit for satisfactory correction thereof. Any person who shall continue any violation beyond the time limit shall be guilty of violation of his industrial sewer connection application and shall be summarily disconnected from the sanitary and/or water service, such disconnection and reconnection to be of total expense to the customer. Where acids or chemicals damaging to sewer lines or treatment process are related to the sewer and cause rapid deterioration of these structures or interfere with the proper treatment of sewage, the superintendent is authorized to immediately terminate service by such measures as are necessary to protect the facilities. 
(Code 1974, § 26-40.2) 
Sec. 86-175. - Penalty for violation of article. 
    Any person who violates any of the provisions of this article or who fails to comply with any proper order of the superintendent, health officer or their duly authorized inspectors, or any person who in any way obstructs the superintendent, health officer or their duly authorized inspectors in the proper discharge of the duties prescribed in this article shall, upon conviction, be fined in a sum of not less than $5.00 nor more than $100.00 and may also be sentenced to jail for a period of time not exceeding six months. Each day such violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1974, § 26-41) 
Sec. 86-176. - Liability for violation of article. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall become liable to the town for any expense, loss or damage occasioned by the town by reason of such violation. 
(Code 1974, § 26-42) 
Secs. 86-177-86-200. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PRIVATE SEWAGE DISPOSAL 

Sec. 86-201. - Privies, privy vaults, septic tanks and cesspools prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful to construct or maintain any privy or privy vault. Septic tanks, cesspools or other facilities intended or used for the disposal of sewage shall be permitted only as provided in this division. 
(Code 1974, § 26-4) 
Sec. 86-202. - Where town sewer is not available. 
    Where a public sanitary sewer is not available under the provisions of section 86-149, the house sewer shall be connected to a private sewage disposal system complying with the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1974, § 26-6) 
Sec. 86-203. - Use of septic tanks or sanitary privies. 
    In cases where it is not practicable or possible to make connections with the town sewer system, the use of septic tanks or sanitary privies will be allowed, the same to be maintained as provided in this division. 
(Code 1974, § 26-7) 
Sec. 86-204. - Septic tanks and sanitary privies in areas where no town sewer exists. 
    Persons desiring to have sewer connections in their homes where no town sewer exists with which to connect may be allowed to construct a septic tank, provided the same complies with the regulations of the state board of health and is approved by the health officer and his permit issued therefor. In areas where no town sewer exists, the property owner may erect a sanitary privy for use on such premises in accordance with the regulations and specifications of this division. 
(Code 1974, § 26-8) 
Sec. 86-205. - Sewered water closet or sanitary privy required. 
    All buildings or other places in the town where human beings live, are employed, or congregate shall be provided with a sewered water closet or a sanitary privy for the catchment or receiving of human discharge, which will be properly disposed of, and safeguard such matter. 
(Code 1974, § 26-9) 
Sec. 86-206. - Sewers discharging into septic tanks. 
    All houses having a sewer that discharges into a septic tank shall be provided with an ample and approved subsurface distributing system to care for the effluent from such tank. 
(Code 1974, § 26-10) 
Sec. 86-207. - Connection to town sewer when available. 
    At such time as a public sewer becomes available to a property served by a private sewage disposal system, a direct connection shall be made to the public sewer in compliance with this article, when any septic tanks, cesspools, and similar private sewage disposal facilities shall become inadequate or inoperative. 
(Code 1974, § 26-11) 
Sec. 86-208. - Operation and maintenance of private sewage disposal facilities. 
    The owner shall operate and maintain the private sewage disposal facilities in a sanitary manner at all times, at no expense to the town. 
(Code 1974, § 26-12) 
Sec. 86-209. - Additional requirements of the health officer. 
    No statement contained in this division shall be construed to interfere with any additional requirements that may be imposed by the health officer. 
(Code 1974, § 26-13) 
Secs. 86-210-86-230. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - PUBLIC SEWERS AND CONNECTIONS 

Sec. 86-231. - Sewer construction. 
(a)  When technically feasible, the town will furnish sewers to the persons whose building lot abuts on a public thoroughfare, noted on the town map of 1934, or accepted into the town street system prior to June 18, 1968, or dedicated prior to June 18, 1968; but in no instance will the town be obligated to expend more than $375.00 for each customer in this category. Any excesses above this amount shall be furnished by the customer in addition to the normal connection fee. 
(b)  Where public sewage facilities are available to persons whose building lot abuts on public thoroughfares accepted into the town system subsequent to June 18, 1968, the service shall be extended to all lots by the subdivider within a subdivision and septic tanks will not be permitted. Every subdivision shall be provided by the subdivider with a satisfactory and sanitary manner of sewage collection and disposal, in accordance with the design standards and specifications for sewage construction and improvements in the town. 
(1)  Location of sewer pipe, size and quality of sewer pipe, grade level, backfill material, and method of compacting shall be approved by the town manager. 
(2)  Manholes shall be provided by the subdivider and locations determined by the town manager. 
(Code 1974, § 26-14) 
Sec. 86-232. - Cost of connection to town sewer. 
    The connection fee for connection to the public sewer system for persons within the corporate limits of the town and for persons with connections located outside the corporate limits is on file in the town clerk's office. 
(Code 1974, § 26-15) 
Sec. 86-233. - Each building to be separately connected with sewer. 
    A separate and independent house sewer shall be provided for every building; except where one building stands at the rear of another on an interior lot and no private sewer is available or can be constructed to the rear building through an adjoining alley, court, yard or driveway, the house sewer from the front building may be extended to the rear building and the whole considered as one house sewer. 
(Code 1974, § 26-16) 
Sec. 86-234. - Connection of old house sewers. 
    Old house sewers may be used in connection with new buildings only when they are found, on examination and test by the superintendent, to meet all requirements of this article. 
(Code 1974, § 26-17) 
Sec. 86-235. - Types of house sewers permitted. 
(a)  House sewers shall be eight-inch ABS truss pipe or eight-inch PVC truss pipe, STR 35. 
(b)  Joints shall be tight and waterproof. Any part of the house sewer located within five feet of a water service pipe shall be constructed of approved pipe with approved joints. The approved pipe with approved joints may be required by the superintendent where the house sewer is exposed to damage by tree roots. If installed in filled or unstable ground, the house sewer shall be accepted if laid on a suitable concrete bed or cradle as approved by the superintendent. 
(Code 1974, § 26-18) 
Sec. 86-236. - Size and slope of house sewer. 
    The size and slope of the house sewer shall be subject to the approval of the superintendent, but in no event shall the diameter be less than four inches. The slope of such four-inch pipe shall be not less than one-eighth inch per foot. 
(Code 1974, § 26-19) 
Sec. 86-237. - Location of house sewer. 
    Whenever possible the house sewer shall be brought to the building at an elevation below the basement floor. No house sewer shall be laid parallel to or within three feet of any bearing wall, which might thereby be weakened. The depth shall be sufficient to afford protection from frost. The house sewer shall be laid at uniform grade and in straight alignment insofar as possible. Changes in direction shall be made only with properly curved pipe and fittings. 
(Code 1974, § 26-20) 
Sec. 86-238. - Installation of house drains lower than house sewer. 
    In all buildings in which any house drain is too low to permit gravity flow to the public sewer, sanitary sewage carried by such drain shall be lifted by approved artificial means and discharged to the house sewer. 
(Code 1974, § 26-21) 
Sec. 86-239. - Excavations for the installation of house sewers. 
    All excavations required for the installation of a house sewer shall be open trench work unless otherwise approved by the superintendent. Pipe laying and backfill shall be performed in accordance with ASTM specifications. 
(Code 1974, § 26-22) 
Sec. 86-240. - Joints and connections. 
(a)  All joints and connections shall be made gastight and watertight. 
(b)  Joints shall be made with approved type. No paint, varnish or other coatings shall be permitted on the jointing material until after the joint has been tested and approved. 
(c)  All joints and jointing material shall be pursuant to ASTM specifications. 
(Code 1974, § 26-23) 
Sec. 86-241. - Connection of house sewer to public sewer. 
    The connection of the house sewer into the public sewer shall be made at the public sewer. The invert of the house sewer at that point of connection shall be at the same or at a higher elevation than the invert of the public sewer. In addition, a cleanout acceptable to the superintendent shall be installed either at the property line or some other point acceptable to the superintendent at the time the connection, or any substantial reconstruction of the connection, is made. A smooth, neat joint shall be made and the connection made secure and watertight by encasement in concrete. Special fittings may be used for the connection only when approved by the superintendent. Approved pipe shall be utilized within the street lines. 
(Code 1974, § 26-24; Ord. of 1-14-02) 
Sec. 86-242. - Inspection and connection of house sewer. 
    The applicant for the house sewer permit shall notify the superintendent when the house sewer is ready for inspection and connection to the public sewer. The connection shall be made under the supervision of the superintendent or his representative, and no sewer connection shall be started after 12:00 noon. 
(Code 1974, § 26-25) 
Sec. 86-243. - Removal of obstructions from sewer. 
    In the case of any stoppage in the main or lateral sewers, the town shall remove the obstruction. The town will also be responsible for the removal of obstructions in house sewers up to the property line of the property owner whose property it connects. If the stoppage occurs in the house sewer or drain on the property, the property owner whose property it connects with the main sewer shall remove the obstruction. If he fails to remove the obstruction within 48 hours after notice from the town manager, the obstruction may be removed by the town and the cost thereof together with 20 percent shall be paid by the owner or occupant. 
(Code 1974, § 26-26; Ord. of 1-14-02) 
Sec. 86-244. - Injuring sewage works. 
    No person while engaged in the construction of house sewers or otherwise shall injure, trim, break or remove any portion of any main or lateral sewer, or "Y" or manhole, lamphole or flush tank, or do any injury to any gas or water pipe or house sewer previously laid; and no penalty fixed in this article shall prevent the town or any property owners from recovering any damages sustained by reason of such injury, by appropriate civil action or otherwise. 
(Code 1974, § 26-27) 
Sec. 86-245. - Protection of excavations and installations of house sewers. 
    All excavations for house sewer installation shall be adequately guarded with barricades and lights so as to protect the public from hazard. Streets, sidewalks, parkways and other public property disturbed in the course of the work shall be restored in a manner satisfactory to the town. 
(Code 1974, § 26-28) 
Secs. 86-246-86-265. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - USE OF THE PUBLIC SEWERS 

Sec. 86-266. - Discharge of stormwaters and unpolluted drainage. 
    No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any stormwater, surface water, groundwater, roof runoff, subsurface drainage, cooling water or unpolluted industrial process waters to any sanitary sewer. 
(Code 1974, § 26-29) 
Sec. 86-267. - Connection to storm sewers. 
    Stormwater and all other unpolluted drainage shall be discharged to such sewers as are specifically designated as storm sewers, or to a natural outlet approved by the superintendent. Industrial cooling water or unpolluted process waters may be discharged, upon approval of the superintendent, to a storm sewer. 
(Code 1974, § 26-30) 
Sec. 86-268. - Limits for the discharge of waters and wastes. 
    Except as hereinafter provided, no person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any of the following described waters or wastes to any public sewer in excess of the limits specified: 
(1)  Excluded: 
Mineral oils and combustibles 
Sand, ashes, cinders, etc. 
Hair, rags, feathers, etc. 
Toxic, corrosive, explosive and malodorous gases 
Unshredded garbage 
Metal, broken glass, etc. 
Any liquid or vapor having a higher temperature than 150° F. 
(2)  Removed to maximum practicable extent soluble oils. 
(3)  Toxic and deleterious wastes in sufficient quantities to exceed the following limitations as regards the combined sewage reaching the sewage treatment works: 
Zinc 3 ppm Iron 5 ppm Chromium 3 ppm Copper 1 ppm Cyanide 2 ppm Phenol 2 ppm pH 6.5 to 7.5  
(4)  Toxic pollutants. No toxic waste or incompatible waste shall be discharged into treatment works. Any user who discharges such waste that causes an increase in the cost of managing the effluent or the sludge from the treatment works shall pay for such increased cost. 
(5)  Any waters or wastes containing suspended solids of such character and quantity and/or waters or wastes having five-day BOD sufficient in the opinion of the superintendent to require pretreatment. Generally, maximum acceptable limits shall be five-day BOD of 240 ppm by weight and 240 ppm by weight of suspended solids. 
(Code 1974, § 26-31; Ord. of 5-8-06(1)) 
Sec. 86-269. - Grease, oil and sand interceptors. 
(a)  Grease, oil and sand interceptors shall be provided when, in the opinion of the superintendent, they are necessary for the proper handling of liquid wastes containing grease in excessive amounts, or any flammable wastes, sand and other harmful ingredients; except that such interceptors shall not be required for private living quarters or dwelling units. All interceptors shall be of a type and capacity approved by the superintendent and shall be located as to be readily and easily accessible for cleaning and inspection. 
(b)  Grease and oil interceptors shall be constructed of impervious materials capable of withstanding abrupt and extreme changes in temperature. They shall be of substantial construction, watertight, and equipped with easily removable covers, which when bolted in place shall be gastight and watertight. 
(Code 1974, § 26-32) 
Sec. 86-270. - Maintenance of grease, oil and sand interceptors. 
    Where installed, all grease, oil and sand interceptors shall be maintained by the owner, at his expense, in continuously efficient operation at all times. 
(Code 1974, § 26-33) 
Sec. 86-271. - When preliminary treatment is required. 
    The admission into the public sewers of any waters or wastes exceeding the limitations set forth in section 86-268 shall be subject to the review and approval of the superintendent; and where deemed necessary by the superintendent, the owner shall provide at his expense such preliminary treatment as may be necessary to reduce the objectionable characteristics of constituents to within the limits provided for in section 86-268 and to control the quantities and rates of discharge of such waters or wastes. Plans, specifications and any other pertinent information relating to proposed preliminary treatment facilities shall be submitted for the approval of the superintendent and of the state department of health; and no construction of such facilities shall be commenced until approvals are obtained in writing. 
(Code 1974, § 26-34) 
Sec. 86-272. - Maintenance of preliminary treatment facilities. 
    Where preliminary treatment facilities are provided for any waters or wastes, they shall be maintained continuously in satisfactory and effective operation by the owner at his expense. 
(Code 1974, § 26-35) 
Sec. 86-273. - Location and installation of control manholes. 
    When required by the superintendent, the owner of any property served by a house sewer carrying industrial wastes shall install a suitable control manhole in the house sewer to facilitate observation, sampling and measurement of the wastes. Such manhole, when required, shall be accessibly and safely located and shall be constructed in accordance with plans approved by the superintendent. The manhole shall be installed by the owner at his expense and shall be maintained by him so as to be safe and accessible at all times. 
(Code 1974, § 26-36) 
Sec. 86-274. - Measurements, tests and analyses. 
(a)  Measurements, tests and analyses of the characteristics of waters and wastes to which reference is made in section 86-268 shall be determined in accordance with "Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Sewage," and shall be determined at the control manhole provided for in section 86-273, or upon suitable samples taken at the manhole. If no special manhole has been required, the control manhole shall be considered to be the nearest downstream manhole in the public sewer to the point at which the house sewer is connected. 
(b)  The cost of tests and analysis to determine the content of industrial waste being discharged into the sewage works shall be paid to the town by the owner. 
(Code 1974, § 26-37) 
Sec. 86-275. - Special agreements by town. 
    No statement contained in this article shall be construed as preventing any special agreement or arrangement between the town and any industrial concern whereby an industrial waste of unusual strength or character may be accepted by the town for treatment, subject to payment therefor by the industrial concern. 
(Code 1974, § 26-38) 
Secs. 86-276-86-295. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - FEES, RATES, ETC. 

Sec. 86-296. - Fees. 
    Sewage connection fees within the corporate limits and without the corporate limits are on file in the town clerk's office. 
(Code 1974, § 26-43) 
Sec. 86-297. - Bills, when paid. 
    All water and sewer bills shall be paid in advance for the minimum charges of the billing period and the minimum charges plus the excess already consumed shall be billed on the first of each billing period in which bills shall be due and payable on or before the 15th day of the current month following date of bill, and the town manager or his duly appointed agent is hereby vested with authority to discontinue service to anyone in default after that date. 
(Code 1974, § 26-44) 
Sec. 86-298. - Connection charges to be paid before installation started. 
    All water and sewage connection charges shall be paid for before installation is started, and the monthly rates for water and sewage services shall commence immediately upon completion of the installation of the connection. 
(Code 1974, § 26-45) 
Sec. 86-299. - Deposits. 
    All deposits shall be construed to be advance payments. 
(Code 1974, § 26-46) 
Sec. 86-300. - Biennial review. 
    The council will review the user charge system no less than every two years and revise it as necessary to ensure revenue requirements for the wastewater treatment works. 
Chapter 90 - VEHICLES FOR HIRE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 26; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 70; traffic and vehicles, ch. 82. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 90-1-90-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - TAXICABS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 90-31. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Certificate means the certificate of public convenience and necessity granted by the taxicab commission to persons in the business of operating taxicabs, as provided in this article. 
    Driver means any person driving a taxicab. 
    Owner means any person having control of the operation or maintenance of a taxicab or of the collection of revenue derived from its operation. 
    Taxicab means any motor vehicle used for the transportation for hire or reward of passengers and baggage upon the streets of the town, other than buses being operated under franchise and over fixed routes between fixed termini. 
    Taxicab driver's permit means a taxicab driver's permit granted to a driver, as provided in this article. 
(Code 1974, § 29-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 90-32. - Creation and composition of taxicab commission. 
    There is created a taxicab commission, which commission shall be composed of the mayor, the town manager and the chief of police. 
(Code 1974, § 29-2) 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 
Sec. 90-33. - Condition of vehicles. 
    Taxicabs operated pursuant to this article shall at all times be kept clean and sanitary and in a safe physical condition to the satisfaction of the chief of police. 
(Code 1974, § 29-3) 
Sec. 90-34. - Display on vehicle of name of owner. 
    Every taxicab for which a certificate of public convenience and necessity is issued pursuant to this article shall have the name of the owner thereof or firm name painted on the outside of the vehicle on both sides thereof in letters not less than four inches high. Signs attached to the vehicle and bearing the requisite information, whether removable or not, shall not be deemed compliance with this section. 
(Code 1974, § 29-4) 
Sec. 90-35. - Public liability or property damage insurance policy or bond required. 
    No taxicab shall operate on the streets of the town under this article and no certificate of public convenience and necessity shall be delivered therefor under this article unless the owner thereof shall deposit with the town manager for each such vehicle a public liability and property damage insurance policy or bond as described in Code of Virginia, §§ 46.2-2028 and 46.2-2030. 
(Code 1974, § 29-5) 
Sec. 90-36. - Report of accidents. 
    Every accident in which any taxicab operated pursuant to this article is involved shall be immediately reported to the chief of police. 
(Code 1974, § 29-6) 
Sec. 90-37. - Shades and curtains. 
    No taxicab operated pursuant to this article shall be equipped with shades or curtains that can shield any occupant from observation. 
(Code 1974, § 29-7) 
Sec. 90-38. - Owners to have listed telephones. 
    The owners of any taxicab operated pursuant to this article shall provide and maintain at all times a listed telephone by which calls for service can be made. 
(Code 1974, § 29-8) 
Sec. 90-39. - Designation and assignment of stands; use of metered parking space as stand. 
    The town manager may designate and assign stands for taxicabs or may require owners of taxicabs to furnish their own stands not on the town streets. No metered parking space shall be used as a stand by any taxicab. 
(Code 1974, § 29-10) 
Sec. 90-40. - Nonpaying passengers. 
    No nonpaying passenger shall be transported in a taxicab operated pursuant to this article with a paying passenger, except bona fide officers or employees of the owner or a police officer engaged in the performance of his duty. 
(Code 1974, § 29-11) 
Sec. 90-41. - Limitation on number of passengers. 
    No driver of any taxicab operated pursuant to this article shall carry in such taxicab at any one time more passengers than the number which the vehicle was built to carry normally. 
(Code 1974, § 29-12) 
Sec. 90-42. - Council approval required for rates for transportation of passengers and baggage. 
    The rates charged for transportation of passengers and baggage in taxicabs shall be subject to the approval of the council. 
(Code 1974, § 29-13) 
Sec. 90-43. - Posting of rates for transportation of passengers and baggage; compliance with posted rates. 
    The rates for transportation of passengers and baggage in taxicabs shall be posted in each taxicab in full view of passengers. It shall be unlawful to charge any rates other than those posted and such rates approved by the council. 
(Code 1974, § 29-14) 
Sec. 90-44. - Drivers to complete accepted calls. 
    It shall be unlawful for the driver of a taxicab operated pursuant to this article to fail or refuse to complete an accepted call in the absence of a satisfactory reason. 
(Code 1974, § 29-15) 
Sec. 90-45. - Compliance with article. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or permit or cause to be operated any taxicab within the town except in compliance with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1974, § 29-16) 
Sec. 90-46. - Tax. 
    Except as provided in Code of Virginia, § 46.2-2018, every person operating a taxicab for hire on the streets of the town shall pay a license tax as follows: 
(1)  Vehicle of five-passenger capacity or less ..... $75.00 
(2)  Vehicle of six- or seven-passenger capacity ..... 80.00 
(3)  Vehicle of eight-, nine- or ten-passenger capacity ..... 85.00 
(4)  Vehicle of more than ten-passenger capacity ..... 90.00 
(Ord. of 7-1-93, § 17-72(a)) 
Secs. 90-47-90-65. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CERTIFICATES OF PUBLIC CONVENIENCE AND NECESSITY 

Sec. 90-66. - Required. 
    No person shall use any vehicle under his control as a taxicab, or allow any vehicle under his control to be used as a taxicab, upon the streets of the town unless he shall have obtained a certificate of public convenience and necessity in accordance with the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1974, § 29-17) 
Sec. 90-67. - Form and contents of application. 
    Application for a certificate of public convenience and necessity shall be made by the owner or proposed owner, in duplicate, and shall set out the following information: 
(1)  Full name and home and business addresses of the applicant. 
(2)  Financial status and responsibility of the applicant. 
(3)  Name and address of the person lending money or furnishing capital to the applicant. 
(4)  Motor number, kind, seating capacity, design and color scheme of each taxicab. 
(5)  Convictions or pleas of guilty, if any, for violation of any law on part of the applicant. 
(6)  Experience of the applicant in the transportation of passengers for hire. 
(7)  Reasons why the applicant believes public convenience and necessity requires the granting of the certificate applied for. 
(Code 1974, § 29-18) 
Sec. 90-68. - Filing of application; investigation and report concerning application. 
    An application for a certificate of public convenience and necessity shall be filed by the owner or proposed owner with the town manager prior to applying for a business license for operation of a taxicab business. The town manager shall promptly investigate the matters stated in the application and report in writing to the taxicab commission prior to the next meeting of the commission. 
(Code 1974, § 29-19) 
Sec. 90-69. - Authority of taxicab commission as to grant or refusal; filing of approved applications with town manager. 
    The taxicab commission, upon report to it relative to an application for a certificate of public convenience and necessity, shall determine whether the public convenience and necessity require the operation of the taxicab for which application is filed. The taxicab commission may grant or refuse the certificate applied for or grant a certificate for a lesser number of vehicles than specified in the application. Upon determination by the taxicab commission to grant a certificate, the approved application shall be filed with the town manager. 
(Code 1974, § 29-20) 
Sec. 90-70. - Time within which taxicab commission to act on applications. 
    The taxicab commission shall consider and act on the applications for certificates of public convenience and necessity within 30 days after receipt of such application. 
(Code 1974, § 29-21) 
Sec. 90-71. - Notice to applicant of action upon application. 
    The town manager shall immediately notify in writing the applicant for a certificate of public convenience and necessity of the action of the taxicab commission upon the application filed by such applicant. 
(Code 1974, § 29-22) 
Sec. 90-72. - Report to commissioner of revenue as to certificates granted. 
    The town manager shall report in to the commissioner of the revenue all certificates of public convenience and necessity granted by the taxicab commission, together with the number of vehicles allotted. 
(Code 1974, § 29-23) 
Sec. 90-73. - Issuance. 
    When an approved application for a certificate of public convenience and necessity is filed with the town manager by the taxicab commission pursuant to section 90-69, the town manager, upon the filing with him by the applicant of a receipt indicating the payment of the requisite license tax in section 78-108 and the filing of the insurance policy or bond required by section 90-35, shall issue to the applicant a certificate in accordance with the terms of the application as approved. 
(Code 1974, § 29-24) 
Sec. 90-74. - Contents. 
    The certificates referred to in this division shall give the name of the owner, the motor number, the kind and description of every vehicle covered thereby, together with the date of issuance and the date of expiration. 
(Code 1974, § 29-25) 
Sec. 90-75. - Term. 
    The certificates referred to in this division shall expire on March 31 annually unless revoked or suspended as provided in this division. 
(Code 1974, § 29-26) 
Sec. 90-76. - Transfer between persons. 
    The certificates referred to in this division shall not be transferable from one person to another. 
(Code 1974, § 29-27) 
Sec. 90-77. - Cancellation, revocation and suspension. 
    The taxicab commission may, for cause, cancel, revoke or suspend any certificate required by this division after notice to the holder of the certificate. 
(Code 1974, § 29-28) 
Sec. 90-78. - Substitution of vehicles. 
    No vehicle shall be substituted for any vehicle described in a certificate required by this division until the vehicle to be substituted has been investigated and approved by the chief of police and the fact of such substitution endorsed on the certificate by him. 
(Code 1974, § 29-29) 
Secs. 90-79-90-100. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - DRIVER'S PERMIT 

Sec. 90-101. - Required. 
    No person shall drive a taxicab within the town unless he shall have obtained a taxicab driver's permit for that purpose, as provided in this division. 
(Code 1974, § 29-30) 
Sec. 90-102. - Filing and contents of application. 
    Any person desiring a taxicab driver's permit, as required in section 90-101, shall file an application therefor with the chief of police. Such application shall be made in writing under oath and shall show the following: 
(1)  Full name of applicant. 
(2)  Present address. 
(3)  Age. 
(4)  Place of birth. 
(5)  Places of previous address and employment for the past five years. 
(6)  Height. 
(7)  Weight. 
(8)  Color of eyes. 
(9)  Color of hair. 
(10)  Sex. 
(11)  Whether or not the applicant uses or has been convicted of using drugs or any other form of narcotic and, if so, to what extent. 
(12)  Whether or not the applicant has ever been convicted of, pleaded guilty to or entered the plea of nolo contendere to the violation of any town, state, federal or other criminal law and, if so, the number of times and the kind of offenses and such other information as may be required by the chief of police. 
(13)  Whether or not the applicant has previously been employed or licensed as a driver or chauffeur and, if so, whether or not his license has ever been revoked or suspended for any reason. 
(Code 1974, § 29-31) 
Sec. 90-103. - Fingerprinting and photographs of applicants. 
    All applicants for a taxicab driver's permit shall be fingerprinted and submit two photographs, two inches by two inches in size, of himself to the chief of police department. One photograph of the applicant shall be attached to the taxicab driver's permit that may be issued to such applicant. 
(Code 1974, § 29-32) 
Sec. 90-104. - Issuance. 
    A taxicab driver's permit shall be issued to the applicant therefor unless such applicant shall, in the opinion of the chief of police, be disqualified because of addiction to intoxicating liquors, narcotics, drugs, or because he has been convicted of violating any law or ordinance involving moral turpitude, or because he is not of good moral character. 
(Code 1974, § 29-34) 
Sec. 90-105. - Signing by permittee. 
    Each person to whom a taxicab driver's permit is issued under section 90-104, shall write his usual signature with pen and ink in the space provided for that purpose on the permit issued to him immediately upon receipt of such permit, and such permit shall not be valid until so signed. 
(Code 1974, § 29-35) 
Sec. 90-106. - Appeals from findings of the chief of police. 
    Appeals from findings of the chief of police under section 90-104 shall be through the taxicab commission and the council. 
(Code 1974, § 29-36) 
Sec. 90-107. - Expiration date. 
    Taxicab drivers' permits issued under this division shall expire annually on March 31, unless sooner revoked, suspended or invalidated as provided in this division. 
(Code 1974, § 29-37) 
Sec. 90-108. - Posting in vehicle. 
    The driver of a taxicab shall at all times have the taxicab driver's permit, with his picture pasted thereon, as issued under this division posted in the vehicle being driven by him, in such manner that it will be in full view of passengers. 
(Code 1974, § 29-38) 
Sec. 90-109. - Condition; replacement when dirty, mutilated. 
    Taxicab drivers' permits issued and posted under the provisions of this division and the photograph attached thereto shall be kept in good condition. The chief of police shall require the holder of the taxicab driver's permit to replace such permit and the photograph attached thereto when, in his opinion, the taxicab driver's permit has become dirty, disfigured or mutilated so that it cannot be read or the holder of the permit cannot be identified by his photograph. 
(Code 1974, § 29-39) 
Sec. 90-110. - Invalidation upon conviction of holder of crime involving moral turpitude. 
    Upon conviction of the holder of a taxicab driver's permit of the violation of any criminal law involving moral turpitude, the permit of the person so convicted shall become void and the holder of such permit shall forthwith surrender it to the chief of police. 
(Code 1974, § 29-40) 
Sec. 90-111. - Power of court to revoke or suspend. 
    The county court may revoke or suspend a taxicab driver's permit for: 
(1)  Repeated violations by the holder thereof of the traffic laws; 
(2)  Failure to report an accident; 
(3)  Operation of a vehicle not in good order; 
(4)  Conviction of reckless driving; 
(5)  Charging illegal rates; 
(6)  Violation of laws and ordinances; and 
(7)  Failure or refusal to complete accepted calls in the absence of satisfactory reasons. 
(Code 1974, § 29-41) 
Sec. 90-112. - Employment of driver without permit. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner of any taxicab to permit such taxicab to be driven by any person who does not have a valid and effective taxicab driver's permit issued pursuant to the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1974, § 29-42) 
Chapter 92 - YARD SALES 

Sec. 92-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Yard sale means and includes all general sales, open to the public, conducted from or on a residential premise for the purpose of disposing of personal property including, but not limited to, all sales entitled "garage", "patio", "attic", "porch", "room", "backyard", "lawn", or "rummage" sale. This shall not include a situation where no more than five specific items are held out for sale and all advertisements of such sale specifically name these items to be sold. 
    Personal property means property which is owned, utilized and maintained by an individual or member of his or her residence and acquired in the normal course of living in or maintaining a residence. It does not include merchandise which was purchased for resale or obtained on consignment. 
(Ord. of 1-9-84) 
Sec. 92-2. - Property permitted to be sold. 
    It shall be unlawful for an individual to sell or offer for sale, under authority granted by this ordinance, property other than personal property. 
(Ord. of 1-9-84) 
Sec. 92-3. - Permit required. 
(a)  No yard sale shall be conducted unless and until the individuals desiring to conduct such sale shall obtain a permit therefor from the town office, at least five days in advance of the proposed sale (mailed applications must be postmarked at least seven days in advance of the sale), setting forth the following information: 
(1)  Full name and address of applicant. 
(2)  The location at which the proposed yard sale is to be held. 
(3)  The date or dates upon which the sale shall be held. 
(4)  The date or dates of any other yard sales within the current calendar year. 
(5)  An affirmative statement that the property to be sold was owned by the applicant as his own personal property or by his or her immediate family and was neither acquired nor consigned for the purpose of resale. 
(b)  Those exempt from the provisions of subsection (a) above are civic organizations, non-profit organizations, churches, schools and flea market licensees. 
(Ord. of 1-9-84) 
Sec. 92-4. - Permit fee. 
    There shall be no fee for issuance of such permit. 
(Ord. of 1-9-84) 
Sec. 92-5. - Permit conditions. 
    The permit shall set forth and restrict the time and location of such yard sale. No more than four such permits may be issued to one residence and/or family household during any calendar year. If members of more than one residence join in requesting a permit, then such permit shall be considered as having been issued for each and all such residences. 
(Ord. of 1-9-84) 
Sec. 92-6. - Hours of operation. 
    Such yard sales shall be limited in time to the hours of 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. on the days of the sale. 
(Ord. of 1-9-84) 
Sec. 92-7. - Signs. 
    Two signs of not more than four square feet shall be permitted to be displayed on the property of the residence where the yard sale is being conducted. 
(Ord. of 1-9-84) 
Sec. 92-8. - Inspection. 
    Permits issued in compliance with this chapter shall be posted on premises in a conspicuous place so as to be seen by the public and enforcement officials. A police officer or the building inspector shall have the right of entry to any premises showing evidence of a sale for the purpose of enforcement or inspection and may close the premises from such a sale or arrest any individual who violates the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. of 1-9-84) 
Sec. 92-9. - Penalty. 
    Any person found guilty of violating the terms of this chapter shall be fined not less than $25.00 dollars nor more than $100.00 dollars for each offense. 
(Ord. of 1-9-84)
